  1050. I had considered buying a new Braun (I'd owned two already), but I was a bit put off by the cost of the cleaning and lubricating cartridges for the high end models (one of the things I like about electric razors is that the only additional cost is periodically replacing the screen or cutters). So I thought I'd give this Panasonic a try. Note that I always use the razor dry right after I shower - never with water or in the shower. Right out of the box it gave me one of the closest shaves I'd ever experienced (this was on two days' growth on my face). It didn't seem quite as close on one day's growth, but it was every bit as good as my old Braun (before it got old). Some people mentioned a longer shaving time... it seems that I do spend a bit longer with this model, doing several passes to get my face just right, but that might just be my own idiosyncrasies and getting used to the floating head (the old Braun would just pivot). I've now owned it for almost 3 months and I'm still highly pleased with it. It charges fully in about an hour and the charge indicator takes the guess work out of when to plug it back in.

  1067. I already have had one of these for several months, and I enjoy its ability to provide close shaves of three-day growths as easily as one-day growths of my moderately stiff beard. The high speed of the blade is a great plus, as is the wet/dry shave feature. I tried wet shaves, but prefer a dry shave, although it's nice to be able to clean the blades operating and under warm water flow with the cover/comb headpiece removed. My only wish would be that the batteries would last longer between charges. I get about five days before needing to recharge. The charge indicator with a percentage countdown is a welcome feature. The charging cord is long...VERY LONG! I have to bunch it up and tie it off with a twisty. Also, there is no carrying case furnished, but I have an adequate one from a former razor. But, even considering those minor detractions, I bought another one on sale to keep as a spare, because THIS IS A GREAT SHAVER.

I suggested he shave before he goes on his date. &#34;I can't&#34; he says. &#34;I don't have my shaved.&#34; I suggested he use my new one. His thought, &#34;this is awesome!   1090. Good for the face. Not so good for the neck. Eventually it will work, but you have to apply it lightly to those stray whiskers.
  1091. I've been waiting and waiting for this to go on sale and it finally happened. I had an eight year old Braun shaver that refused to die. I replaced the rechargeable batteries and put a new shaver foil on it and it was like new again. But it still didn't give that great a shave.<br /><br />But now that has all changed with the Panasonic shaver. It arrived with a fully drained battery and I had to wait overnight for it to charge. This is a much lighter weight shaver compared to my Braun shaver and it has a much higher speed motor inside. It has a high pitched sound that my wife can't tolerate. I think I've lost all my upper end hearing, so it doesn't bother me. I can shave much faster now and the shave actually does approach that of a blade shaver. I still do a dry shave with my disposable blade shavers after using this Panasonic if I'm going out in public. But if I'm staying home, this provides a shave that is perfectly adequate.<br /><br />The battery doesn't last all that many days, especially compared to my Braun shaver. But it is good enough. The LCD display is easy to read and shows the amount of battery life remaining in percent. I leave it to charge overnight once it is depleted. I don't know what the more expensive versions of Panasonic shavers do, but this model is plenty good enough in my opinion. My beard grows fast and is fairly tough. I'm very pleased with its performance and price. I paid $55 on an Amazon sale.

When it was new I got exactly 2 weeks worth of shaves and as of today I still get exactly 2 weeks worth of shaves. Pretty good.<br /><br />Only 2 cons I can think of.<br />The trimmer isn't great. I keep another old shaver around for trimming. Not a big deal but it could be better.<br />It would be nice if you could lock the shaver in the &#34;off&#34; position.   1115. I purchased the Panasonic after reading Consumer Report's glowing review. I have never been sorry. It has been a year since I bought the razor, I have not shaved with a blade since I bought it. There are many great features. Charging is rapid. A full charge takes about 30 minutes. Cleaning is a breeze. You put some liquid soap on the blades and hold the start button until it goes into some sort of high speed function and then the unit shuts down when it is done. You don't clean the blades with a brush, and that is probably why they last longer. If you are considering a good razor, at a reasonable price, this is the one to get.

  1184. I bought this shaver to replace a Braun 5614 - expecting the Panasonic to shave closer and faster. That has not been the case. It runs much quieter than the Braun, but it is not faster nor does it give a closer shave. The user manual states that the shaver should supply roughly 14 shaves of 3 minutes each when fully charged. I do not have a rough, thick beard at all - I could go a few days without shaving and most people might not notice. Yet it STILL takes me 8-10 minutes to shave (wet or dry) using the ES8103S. Thus, I only get 6-8 shaves out of a full charge. Since the manual states a shave of 3 minutes, my conclusion was that Panasonic tested the model with 12-year-old boys -- or that I had a defect. So I sent my shaver back for a replacement and the new one is no different. This is not a bad shaver at all; just know that you won't get 14 shaves on a full charge. Expect 5 to 9 shaves depending on how thick/heavy your beard is. **Nov 2014 Update** - Now this last only 2-3 shaves. The display will say 30% or 40% yet the shaver will die 15-20 seconds later. So 4 years seems to be about the life of the battery.
  1185. This razor is a dream. It doesn't take a long time for me to get all the stubble (unlike my previous razor), and works will even if I go a couple days without shaving. Holds a charge for a long time too. Had considered the more expensive Panasonic models, but I'm perfectly satisfied with this one. I have sensitive skin and this razor doesn't bother me at all.
  1186. Seems to work reasonably well but doubt made by Panasonic. Farmed out product that is overpriced but we'll see how long it operates. Won't dare get it wet.
  1187. This is the best shaver I have used in the last 20 years. I have tried many brands cheaper & more expensive than the Panasonic ES8103S but, have always been disappointed until now. I am glad I read the review & gave this shaver a try. The shaver last about 10 days on single charge & does not loose power at the end like most shavers. I also like the counter that tells you when battery is used up. The shaver is quick & does not leave long hairs on neck like some shavers. I have been using the shaver for about 3 months & the blade still works like new. I am very happy with this shaver.
  1188. Wet shaving with blade will allow a closer shave but takes longer. This shaver gives a very good shave in a very short time. It may do even better with soap and water but not tried as I am satisfied as is. Of maybe a dozen shavers over many years, this is the best yet.
  1189. I've used a blade for many years because I like the closeness of a wet shave. But I'm now taking blood thinners for a heart condition and they make me susceptible to bleeding. Just a slight nick will have me walking around with a little dot of toilet paper on my face all morning.<br /><br />I decided to try an electric shaver despite bad experiences many years ago. Early models caused irritation and never gave me a really close shave. I wasn't about to shell out $200 to try one of the new electrics, but the $60 price on this one seemed reasonable.<br /><br />I've used it both wet and dry and have gotten excellent results both ways. I'm back to shaving daily again instead of skipping days. I've experienced none of the skin irritation that I always associated with electric razors. As a matter of fact, I even skip using aftershave lotion most days because it's not necessary. The shave is not quite as close as a blade but it's more than satisfactory for my needs. The only problem is a small area on my neck where the whiskers seem to lie flat instead of standing up. The shaver has trouble mowing these down so I've taken to giving them a once-over with a blade after I've shaved the rest of my face.<br /><br />The shaver is easy to clean and the batteries last for five or six shaves without recharging. I'd recommend this product.
  1190. This shaver has no problem handling 3 days of growth with no pulling, and gives a real close shave. The battery lasts a couple of weeks between charges. I love the digital battery life display.
  1191. i shave my head and face, i read a lot of reviews and this was so well received I had to try it. unfortunately it missed my head hair all over the place. I had to go over it so much that it left me with tiny bleeding spots all over my scalp. it was fairly smooth over my face.
  1192. I've had this razor for 15 months. Shaves were fine, but today while I was shaving I felt a mysterious burning on my hand--I thought I must have cut myself. Eventually I figured out that the chalky substance on my hand was the source of the burning sensation--the battery had corroded and leaked out on me. Sadly I did not keep the warranty paperwork...

I clean this with liquid dishwashing soap, takes about a minute, let it dry and hit it with a quick shot of Remington Shaver Saver. Replace the blades and foils every 8 to 9 months and it's good for about 3 years, after that the batteries won't hold a charge for more than one or two shaves.

  1258. I read the many good reviews from others who have a similar beard problem as I do; easy to shave face but very difficult to shave neck (hairs don't grow straight and skin is somewhat sensitive). Since I wanted to get away from the pain of a regular razor, I thought I'd give it a try. I received my Panasonic ES8103S the first week of June. I followed the instructions on proper handling, care and shaving technique in order to allow my face the recommended 30 days to get used to the new shaving technique. Things started out good, but then it was all downhill. Initially I was quite pleased. The shave wasn't perfect, but there was no irritation, it did a nice job on my face and a decent job on my neck. I thought things would improve over the 30 day \\"get used to\\" period. WRONG! It now takes me longer to shave and the result is horrible. My face doesn't feel smooth and my next barely looks like I touched it with the shaver. And the more I try to get my neck clean, the more irritated it becomes. I've tried a variety of shave creams but nothing helps. Dry, it just hurts. I really want to return this thing but since Amazon only gives a 30 day window, which, when counting the day of receipt and time required to charge and then adequately go through the trial period, you pass the return period. So, now I'm stuck with a product that is essentially a useless waste of money. If you want to take a chance with this product, I recommend you buy it from a store that has a more reasonable return policy... you're gonna need it!
  1259. Bought this shaver as a result of not being completely happy with the shave I was getting with a Norelco Arcitec shaver. At first I was very happy with the Panasonic shaver, but enthusiasm has waned over the period of several weeks. The Panasonic shaver is very loud and seems to run down the battery faster than a Norelco. It also seems to now cause more skin irritation than it did at the beginning. Bottom line is that I just put a new blade set in the Norelco Arcitec and will probably go back to that as my primary shaver.
  1260. I decided to go back to using an electric after years of using a blade after getting a good deal on the Panasonic ES4026NC Sonic-2 Pro Curve. I liked that shaver but had a few reservations about it so, after reading reviews, I decided to purchase the Panasonic ES8103S Vortex Wet/Dry Shaver. So far, it's been a very good purchase for me. The shaver comes with a charger, a travel pouch and the instructions. Operation is simple enough. Plug it in for about an hour to get a full charge and away you go. There's also an option to plug it in for about 5 minutes if the battery's dead and you need a quick shave. There's a LCD screen that displays the status of the charge in 10% increments as well as displaying when the shaver should be cleaned. In my experience, the battery goes down about 10% with every shave so, you get about 10 days worth of shaving before you need to charge it again. There's also 2 settings for the head to allow more or less pivot. Even when the firmer setting is chosen, the head still pivots to some degree just not as freely. There are 3 heads on this model; 2 foil heads that float independently and another head in the middle of them to grab longer hairs. I've been using this shaver now for about 3 months and my experience with this shaver has been very good. I get a nice smooth shave time after time. Like any new electric shaver, it did take a while for me to adjust to it but honestly, the shaves just keep getting better and better. It doesn't grab the longer hairs quite as well as a rotary shaver but if there are any stragglers, I hit them with the pop out trimmer and then go over them with the shaver. Not really a big deal to me. About every 3rd shave, the LCD displays a faucet and it's time to clean the shaver. Simply rub a little liquid soap over the head and hold down the power button until it enters Turbo Mode which oscillates the blade at 17,000 rpms. I run it under water until the unit shuts itself off then, pop off the head and rinse it off. Nice and clean. People have complained that the shaver is loud and compared to others, this may be true. To me, it's not annoyingly loud so, the noise is really a non issue. Overall, I'm very satisfied with my shaver and look forward to many more close, comfortable shaves from it.
  1261. It's simpler for shaving on those mornings where you feel like a zombie but it doesn't get close enough and I have to go back later and shave again to not look ragged by the afternoon. If you have the time the ol' razor is still # 1.
  1262. boyfriend is really happy with this product. All his roommates try to use it too... at least its easy to clean!
  1263. I am still in the market for a new shaver.One final point the new shaver feels very light and delicate not like the older model.I am curious how much abuse the ES8103S will be able to handle with extended use.

I purchased the whole razor since it wasn't much more money that a couple of new blade and foil sets. At the same time it's considerably less money than the ES8109.   1268. I'd used Braun electric razors for 40 years until I was given a Panasonic for Christmas about 8 years ago. It was one that came with a cleaning system. I'd usually leave the cleaning fluid in too long, so my razor began to smell--to the point that changing the fluid/filter didn't get rid of the odor. My wife was threatening to have me keep my razor outside, when luck would have it...the spring mechanism that holds the blades in place broke. Probably an easy fix, but it gave me an excuse to buy a new razor. I didn't want one with a cleaning system...way overpriced gimmick if you ask me. So I bought this one. Amazing. Shaves close. Very quiet.<br />On the downside, the grip isn't quite as nice. More plastic. And it requires a cord with an ac converter on the end (the old panasonic had it built in). But it holds a charge longer, and I swear shaves better. Would highly recommend this one.
  1269. I used to use a Norelco and switched to this based on the good reviews and price. It does allow you to shave very close...closer than my Norelco did. I have noticed however that it takes multiple passes over the same spot to get the hairs cut all the way down. I also found that it feels much warmer, almost hot, as it passes over my skin. That's probably due to the high speed of the head as it rubs against the very thin foil. If you use it wet, it probably wouldn't feel so hot, but I'm used to shaving dry and not having to mess with shaving cream.<br /><br />Overall it's a very good shaver at the discounted price under $100.

  1272. I got this product three days ago and this are my observations: PROS: Good for my skin (I have sensitive skin and this product didn't cause any irritation. Can be use both, wet and dry. Indicates the power level as ¡00%. 90% Etc. Battery charge in one hour. CONS: Cannot be use with the power cord attach (you need to use the battery). Is not as good when shaving corners and Adam's apple. I use my old Phillips for this purpose. Battery does not last long (but it charges in an hour). Not as good if your bear is longer that 3 days. Conclusion: Still a good product, I use to be able to shave two times a week, with this product I can shave more often since is good with my skin. Update: I am happy with it, it is not perfect, but does the job. As I said before, is not ss good for a long bear. You may want to shave often if you want to have a good shaving experience.

  1277. I very much like this shaver. I ordered this after reading reviews of a number of men with extra heavy beards got close shaves with this shaver (my beard is like having a wire brush growing out of my face; I have to keep it shaved or my boss might use my face to sand the hardwood floors we refinish to save on the cost of sanding belts) Just kidding, maybe.<br /><br />I get the best shave with this Panasonic ES8103S I have ever gotten (excepting a blade)! It isn't very noisy. Fits well in the hand. Easy to maneuver into the hard to reach areas of the face and jaw. Easy to clean. Very fast recharging (one hour maximum)! Glides easily across the face.<br /><br />Replacement foils and blade cartridges are not too bad in price (around $30 or less).<br /><br />My criticisms are as follows:<br />The posting on Amazon is misleading. In the product description the last line says, \\"When you're done shaving, simply rinse clean under water, click the shaver into the HydraCleanTM dock, and your razor will be ready the next morning.\\" There is no HydraClean Dock included in this package. Product packaging does not show the HydraClean Dock is available as an accessory. To get the HydraClean Dock with this shaver you need to order model ES8109S (for an additional $60).<br /><br />I selected this shaver believing it included the HydraClean Dock and wanted that feature. I am not going to return because Amazon can't write accurate descriptions in this case. This is \\"good enough.\\" I don't think the HydraClean Dock is worth an additional $60 to the cost of this shaving system.<br /><br />The other point is Panasonic doesn't describe enough about the battery care.<br />> Rechargeable batteries need attention to how you care and charge them to give you the longest useful life. Most rechargeables require a long initial charge to ensure the battery will work well.<br />* Panasonic doesn't give any information about the initial charge only simply saying the battery takes a maximum time of one hour to recharge.<br />* The shaver should have been allowed to run while plugged in (as the recharger is in the outlet plug to the wall socket and other, less expensive brands/models do so).<br />* There is no specific statement that the shaver, while recharging, cannot be \\"overcharged\\" (another way rechargeable batteries useful life can be shortened).<br /><br />Researching the Panasonic website doesn't provide any answers to the about points either.<br /><br />I will see how long this shaver actually lasts. I am very happy with the purchase at present.lowed to run while plugged in (as the recharger is in the outlet plug to the wall socket and other, less expensive brands/models do so). * There is no specific statement that the shaver, while recharging, cannot be \\"overcharged\\" (another way rechargeable batteries useful life can be shortened). Researching the Panasonic website doesn't provide any answers to the about points either. I will see how long this shaver actually lasts. I am very happy with the purchase at present.

  1294. I bought this 2 months to replace my 2 year old Norelco rotary. It's fine, but not right for me. Perhaps it's my fault, but in order to get the same close shave as I got with the Norelco, I have had to keep going over the same area several times with this shaver, which caused irritation on dry shaves. I now do a wet shave every 4th time, to get a really close shave. Part of the irritation may be from the fact that the blades get quite warm on this with dry shaving after 2 or 3 minutes of use. I'm sure a lot of people prefer foil shavers to rotaries, and that they work well for them. What I can say is that after using this for two months now, my next shaver will be a Norelco.If you are used to Norelco, stick with it would be my advice. Maybe it's all in what you are used to.

  1349. What a shave and a great razor for the price.
  1350. I have used Remington electric razors for decades going back to a few of the corded type. I have had two other brands, the last one with the expensive cleaning cartridge system. The foil got a hole in it so tossed it and bought this Panasonic which I have had for about 4-5 years now. I like it the best on any I have had plus it has an easy to use pop out trimmer. This is my first wet/dry shaver so I shave mostly in the shower with glycerin bar soap which I also use for bathing.<br />I wrote this tip in another Amazon area to advise on keeping the razor blades sharp as long as possible: I always clean my razor after every use. Remove the foil and shake the water out of the blades, then blot the blades on a dry towel--do not rub dry. Then activate the high speed mode to finish the drying. I keep the foil off until next use. The reason for all this is to reduce oxidation of the blades sharp edges. Oxidation is a slow process that prematurely dulls any sharp steel edge when wet. You normally see this as traces of rust but stainless won't show you this and process takes longer but does happen. This is true of your electric razor or throwaway razor. Do your own research. You should not keep the razor in the humid shower stall between use. Last, I would not remove the blades unless replacing them because they have seated themselves with the foil and reversing may render a less close shave.<br />I recently gave it it's first tune up with new foil and blades, the display still operates like new and now the shaver does too.<br />Someone wrote that the razor will shave while charging--it will not but charges rapidly.

  1361. Due to the high cost of replacement razors for Gillette Fusion and the inevitable nicks and cuts that come from using even very good cartridge razors, I started looking around for an electric razor. The price on this Panasonic made it a low risk option to try after ~20 years of shaving with Gillette cartridge razors. There is definitely an adjustment period switching to an electric razor, and I had to fight through a week of skin irritation on my neck and chin. But after getting through that unpleasantness I have had a very good shaving experience with this razor. I have tried it both dry and with shaving cream, but always after a shower and washing with a scrubbing face wash. I prefer the wet shave; it actually seems to go a little faster than dry although it definitely takes a little longer than shaving with the Fusion. The best part is I haven't cut my upper lip since I've started using this razor. The battery doesn't last as long for me as some have suggested. I only get about 5 shaves before it needs a charge, which still isn't bad in my book. Hopefully the battery does not wear out too quickly. Update November 2011: After about 10 months using the Panasonic I've decided to try a Merkur safety razor. The electric is still superior to the cartridges in that I haven't had the cuts and ingrown hairs I experienced with the Fusion and I have already come out ahead on the cost. But I do find that I have to touch up on my Adam's apple with a disposable. I'll give the safety razors a try but will have this as a fallback option as I continue the quest for the perfect shave (which may not exist!)
  1362. I had previously owned a Panasonic linear shaver and that is why I purchased this one. This one is even better. It gives a close shave, has a very nice grip, plus it has a battery life indicator. I charged the unit in about an hour on Christmas morning and then I used the shaver for 16 straight days before the charge indicator showed 10% remaining. It has a cleaning mode that is activated by holding down the power switch for about 2 seconds. Since it is a wet or dry shaver I simply hold it under cold running water and turn on cleaning mode. They do not recommend cleaning under hot water. You can not go wrong purchasing this shaver for less than half it's suggested retail.

  1367. Can't decide which electric shaver has what you need without breaking the bank??? Do you want all the bells and whistles like shooting soothing shave gel on your pretty face while taking a shower or more doo-dads than a swiss army knife...MOVE ON FOLKS!!!!! There is no super shaver out there, unless you find it at a firesale or craigslist (Do you want a deal that bad?!?), that does all those things for less than 100 bucks. If you're looking for a relatively inexpensive quality shaver then put this on your list. The question is, does your face like linear shavers like this one, Norelco type tripple circular floating blades or some other fangled contraption? But that's assuming your face can even handle an electric shaver at all. I have only had it a short time but it's a great shaver and the replacements won't break the bank. It saves me the hassle of using a traditional blade and seems to be of decent quality for the price. You save on replacements in exchange for a less fancy shave. It works for me and does the job. This shaver has linear blades and a foil screen that are recommended to be replaced every 6 months to a year and cost under 27 a set here on Amazon. [[ASIN:B001J6O0JG Panasonic WES9013PC Combo Replacement Shaver Foil and Blade Set]] The Norelco type shavers need to be replaced 2-3 times per year and cost roughly the same if purchased again, here on Amazon. [[ASIN:B001AJ8YGC Philips Norelco 7340 Men's Shaving System]] The key is shopping online for blades and parts because if you don't, you'll end up spending the price of the shaver or more for each replacement set. I know because I had a Norelco shaver 3 or 4 years ago and by the time I realized I could have paid a lot less online for the OVERPRICED replacements, my model was discontinued and the price was expensive no matter where I went. Please don't make the mistake of buying a shaver without knowing it's repair/replacement costs and where to buy them for the best deal. That is no more sillythan finding a great deal on a BMW and finding out you can't afford to fix it. The one thing you have to keep in mind with this unit is DON'T LOOSE THE POWER CORD!!! It's a great little shaver but it is meant to be used until dead some years down the road and thrown away. It may last 5 or 10 years if you're lucky enough to have replacement parts that long but if you are careful not to leave it somewhere when out of town, then you should have nothing to worry about. ***( Just keep in mind that all shavers are meant to be discarded over time and replacement parts are normally priced extravagantly no matter what shaver you get, so don't pass this shaver by just because of the cord issue, this is an industry reality)***
  1368. I am very satisfied with this shaver. It is more expensive than some other shavers, but is worth it (after all, you will use it every day). It cuts closer than any other shaver that I have ever used, fits the hand well, and cleans easily. Being able to use it in the shower is very handy. I will buy another when my present one dies.
  1369. I've owned this and other Panasonics for years, and they're the best electrics I've ever used. I'm pretty compulsive about shaving - I want my face to feel as if hair has never grown on it. The option to use Panasonics wet with shaving cream provides remarkably close shaves with little irritation. The \\"linear\\" feature on their higher-end models is excellent, moving the blade so fast that the the beard seems to evaporate. I've used Brauns and Remingtons in the past - and liked them - but my first Panasonic made me a convert, and the upgrade to linear deepened my enthusiasm. The curving, pivoting, \\"soft\\" shaving head makes it conform to various parts of the face with minimal irritation. When you need precision, a switch lets you lock the head. As electric shavers go, it's pretty quiet.<br /><br />I've owned this shaver for, maybe, 2 years. It just died. All the others I've used have also died dismayingly quickly. My guess: that's the price you pay for using it with water. Replacing them so often makes Panasonic an expensive option. On this model, the little display screen is poorly thought out. It flashes icons that are not explained in the owner's manual. Suddenly, a little faucet with a drip appears. What does it mean? Am I supposed to do something? The owner's manual gives no clue. The screen also began to malfunction pretty quickly. It died completely a week or so before the shaver croaked. There is no option to use the shaver with a cord, so if it runs out of juice, you can't plug it in and continue. But - five or ten minutes of charging will be enough to let you finish - and a complete charge is pretty quick, too. Like other such models, the cleaning base is a nuisance and, to my mind, a negative rather than a positive. If you go on a trip, you have to pack the bulky base, too.<br /><br />Later: I bought another one. 49 weeks after I purchased it, it has died, too. I think I'm going to switch back to a dry-only brand. This frequent replacement is silly. Also: Amazon gives me no information on warrantee, so I don't know if I can get a new one.<br /><br />Still later: I told the company that I was dismayed by the early death of my shaver. They contacted me immediately and sent me a new one - an upgrade, even. I'm bad with time, so I don't know how long it's been working, but I continue to love these electrics.
  1370. Ive always had Rotary Norelcos and wanted to try a diff kind. This Panasonic had great reviews and was on sale half price. Ive Used it for 3 weeks now and it works great. Much smoother shave than with the Rotarys, cleans easily, and I have used it 8 times before it needs to be charged. Charge percentage indicator is a plus. Great buy. 4 stars, only negative to me so far is that I cant seem to get a straight line shave precise just under my side burns..prob user error..
  1371. I've been using this razor for a bit more than a month now. At first I was delighted with it, but gradually noticed that it takes repeated passes to give a really close shave. It is very noisy, and the high pitched whine can be annoying. The shaving head gets a bit warm, though not enough to burn the skin. It does have trouble with neck hair, though persistence will get the neck smooth. I like the looks of the razor, the hand comfort, the cleaning process, and the displays. One charge lasts about a week. I have not used it wet, as I only dry shave, so I don't know how it performs with a wet shave.<br /><br />Addendum...After using it for several months, I decided to try it with a wet shave. So I wet my face, dabbed some shaving cream on, and was pleasantly surprised to get a smoother, more comfortable shave. I had never before done wet shaving with an electric shaver, but will continue doing so now. So as a dry shaver, I'd rate this one three stars, but as a wet shaver five stars. Thus I average it out at four.<br /><br />Addendum after using it a year and a half.....Well, now I actually regret buying this razor. The reason is that the longer I used it, the noisier it has become, until now the noise is extremely aggravating. It still shaves well as a wet shaver. But it is by far the loudest razor I have ever used!<br /><br />Addendum...Now after using this razor over two years, I am trashing it. The reason....it has now become so noisy that I can no longer stand it.
  1372. I bought this newer Panasonic shaver because the cost of replacing the foil and blades of my previous 5-blade Panasonic cost almost as much as this new, less expensive shaver. The shave takes a little longer than the higher-end unit, but that's OK. What I am NOT happy about is that water has leaked into the LED display in just two months of use. I shave in the shower and then rinse the shaver under the showerhead - nothing contrary to instructions. What bums me is that I have to pay the return shipping and wait for two weeks for Panasonic to replace the unit.
  1373. I wanted a Panasonic Shaver because I have had good luck with Panasonic products. It was hard to decide which Panasonic Shaver to buy from Amazon because there are so many models to pick from. I picked one that had the features I wanted and was about in the middle of the price range. I was thinking that maybe I should have spent more, but this one turned out to be the best shaver I have ever owned. It does an excellent job and actually gives you about 12 shaves before it needs recharging. I am very happy with it and highly recommend this shaver.
  1374. Pros: Fast & very close shave. Feels good in the hand. Glides easily over face. Easy to clean. Cons: Trimmer is WAY too small and is at an awkward angle. No induction charger base. I replaced my obsolete Panasonic ES8097 (which I thought was the best shaver ever) with the ES8103. At first use I didn't like it much. It just didn't feel as good in my hand but I'm glad I didn't rush to review it then. As with any new product there is an adjustment period. Now after getting used to it, I like it as much or more as my old model. I used my old one again and now IT feels strange in my hand. The ES 8103 shaves even faster and closer than my old one. It glides over the face nicely and the closeness of the shave is superb. I would have given it 5 stars if it were not for 2 things: first, for that awkward and WAY too narrow of a trimmer. The wider trimmer that slid straight up on the ES8097 was far superior. The angle on the new trimmer is awkward to use. For those occasions when I have a few days growth, I like to 'pre-shave' by running the trimmer across my neck and face first to remove the longer hairs before using the shaver head. This is where the wide trimmer really excels. Or when trimming a beard. Secondly, there is no induction charge base. You have to plug the cord into the bottom of the shaver like a tether and let it lay on your counter. The old charger base was so much nicer to use. Just stand the shaver in it and it was ready to go for the next use. Plus, it took up less space on the counter and looked much nicer. I REALLY miss that charger base! If Panasonic would put the pop-up trimmer from the ES 8097 on this shaver and add an induction charger base to this shaver, it would be phenomenal.
  1375. I have used Braun shavers for the past 15 years and always felt they were a quality product. After seeing some of the reviews of the Panasonic shavers over the last 5 years, it was time to try one. This is an absolutely tremendous instrument. It shaves closer than any electric I have ever tried and is very comfortable to use. The motor is much quieter and considerably faster than everything I have experienced. I would highly recommend this shaver.
  1376. Much superior to my OLD Norelco..closer and smooth shave without pinching..love it
  1377. I've used the Panasonic ES8103S electric razor for over a month now and I love it. When cutting your beard in the \\"wet\\" mode you can't tell the difference between a razor blade and the ES8103S. I have sensitive skins and am a fussy customer when it comes to shavers. Highly recommend it!
  1378. I haven't had an electric razor for more than 30 years. Thought it was time to give them a chance. The Panasonic works good but it isn't as close as a razor shave.   1379. After two Braun shavers that were good but not special, read the Amazon reviews and decided to try this. I've had it for a month now - needed all that time to familiarize myself adequately - so am finally pretty comfortable with it. PRO: Powerful: doesn't slow down like the Brauns when shaving 2-day whiskers, especially toward end of charge Comfortable: hasn't ever pulled at a whisker like happened occasionally in the past Effective: very good (but not great) shave; easily shaves virtually all hairs growing tight against the face, unlike previous frequent exceptions Long-lasting charge: as claimed, charges last about two weeks with no slow-down toward the end - best I've ever had in this respect; fast charge too Convenient: readout of charge remaining is nice; blinking \\"charge me\\" icon is convenient Well made: solid and nothing flimsy here CON: Trimmer is small but even worse quite awkward; however, when used it works quite well While it easily shaves most areas very well, to me it's harder to get equally good results on my chin and just under my nose - a bit frustrating Shaving surface gets just warm enough at times to be slightly uncomfortable Overall, generally well satisfied and would recommend this to others with the caveat it's not perfect (what is?).
  1380. Great razor<br />In fact just bought another one for myself. It gives a good close shave and is very quite.
  1381. Reliable razor - my first electric. It's now been 3 years since purchase and use, and still reliable. Change the blades about once a year, runs wet + dry. Easy to clean, easy to charge.   1382. I love this shaver. It quickly cuts through my beard and leaves my face smooth and with relatively little burn. While I have to tilt it different directions, I find it ultimately does a better job than my previous razors that used a circular cutting motion. It charges very quickly and six months in demonstrates no irregular loss of charge. I would highly recommend this product.<br /><br />My only complaint is that it doesn't come with a brush to use for cleaning. I have one from an older razor, but this should be a part of the package.<br /><br />Finally, I have only used the razor dry. I cannot speak to its wet shaving capabilities.
  1383. I find modern life pretty empty and pointless without the possibility of a good shave looming in the future like a raccoon under your bed, so I thought I would try an electric Panasonic. Panasonic makes my favorite other electric items like a camera and also a cassette \\"Panasonic Walkman\\" music player that I used to use (with Panasonic \\"tapes\\") so I decided to try this one. Boy was I! I especially like the \\"wet/dry\\" aspect ratio of this unit. At first glance I will admit that I was confused and a little alarmed. Why use electricity around water? It seemed hazardous in potential. Also, if you can use it both wet and dry, how would you know which way was best? It seemed like the only thing to do would be to do an experiment, so I proceeded to order the Panasonic and also got a bunch of regular razor blades and, as a control, one straight razor like the barbers used to use, which I got on eBay. After some sleepless nights I had all my purchases, so I pushed aside my jars of facial pleasurer and lined up the shaving equipment on my bathroom counter. To be totally fair in the process, I thought I should test each razor in both advertised modes, \\"wet\\" and dry. I decided to use water for the wet mode (cheapest) and air for the \\"dry\\" mode (plentiful). First up was the regular razor, which was the generic twin blade kind I get at \\"Pay Cheap.\\" Shaving in dry mode seemed really not the most efficient. It took about eleven passes to get a good shave and an additional nine under my chin to make that area as smooth as I prefer, which is pretty smooth, let me warn you. There was a certain amount of discomfort in this process though and a bit of chafing also, so I waited a few months for that to resolve before trying the twin razor in wet mode. Better! Still couldn't help thinking that maybe shaving cream would have been a good idea, but I was on a roll and didn't want to start over (chafing!). I next planned to move onto the straight razor but realized I'd accidentally thrown the whole thing away with the shipping box because it was \\"recycle your boxes\\" week at my local garbage establishment. So I was able to move on to the main contender, the \\"Panasonic\\" with Panasonic technology! In wet mode it seemed to shave my face, and in dry mode it seemed to also shave my face. Both were shaves! Equally competent! And no waiting two months to shave again! So, in conclusion, wet shaving with a blade might be better with a cream, and wet shaving with an electric Panasonic seems fine, plus it makes a pleasant humming noise to indicate that your hairs are being ground up effectively (use them as fertilizer). Shaving! \\"Save your face for PANASONIC!\\"

  1390.   1393. Bought this for my father who is blind. Been through three Norelco shavers and they all eventually slow down, and none provide a closer shave than the Panasonic. This shaver is a beast. It cuts fast and clean. The side burn cutter is also amazing. Some great features are the battery level display which shows the percentage of battery life left; the ability to keep plugged in and not over charge (my father is 80 and forgets it all the time); and the water proof feature. Also, it's shape is better than the circular shape of most electric shavers. It provides for a realistic shave compared to a razor cut and gets closer around and above the lips. If you are looking for an electric shaver, stop looking, this is it.

  1427. I've always used foil razors and needed a replacement for an old Braun series 5 model. I decided to try the ES-8103s due to the high ratings and significant price difference from the current Braun 5. The Panasonic has been very good in every respect. The shave is close but comfortable. It's much quieter than my old razor (not a fair comparison, though, I'm sure Braun has also improved over the last 10 years). The battery life has been consistent with each shave using 10% of the battery (i.e. up to ten days on one full charge). A full recharge with 10% left takes about 1 hour. It appears solidly built and I've had good service from Panasonic products before so I expect to use it for several years. I factor in the cost of replacement parts when buying. The price of a foil and cutter was reasonable given replacement every 18 to 24 months. The cost of ownership is why I skipped models that use an alcohol cartridge for cleaning the foil and cutter in the base. I'm happy with the performance and the price was exceptional due to a limited time offer.
  1428. This was and is my first electric shaver. I have used for years and just replace the head/blades once a year. Extremely comfortable, reliable, and holds a charge. Love it!!!

  1439. Gets a close shave, very high power - stays charged for days, and it was a very good price before Christmas. Excellent product!

  1441. After reading several reviews and comparing it to its competitor offering in the same range I pulled the trigger on this shaver .<br />I am very satisfied with this and it really takes care of my daily grooming needs swiftly.<br />The shaver isn't the most silent one And the rechargeable battery is kinda short lived.<br />Nevertheless it works great and I'm happy with my purchase . I recommend this to anybody looking for a well priced kosher Shaver.
  1442. This is my first modern day panasonic shaver. I have facial hair of medium thickness and have been using electric razors all my adult life(20 yrs) Tried all the brauns starting from the 1990's models all the way to their most current 7 series shavers. Loved the braun 6520 (which is now obsolete) but was somewhat disappointed in their new 7 series model when I bought it a year ago. It gave a great shave on the cheeks, mustache, and chin but was ineffective on the jawline and neck area... so I decided since the overall shave wasn't good enough I had to try a new brand. And that's why I decided to go for this panasonic es8103s last month. I'll admit after reading all the positive reviews here I was almost expecting the thing to be perfect when I got it. After using it for about a month I can say that its good but not perfect. It gives a close shave on most areas of the face and quickly. It does get close on the neck but you have to press the foil pretty hard against your neck and do a few repeat passes to get it smooth. On my face the shaver caused no irritation, but because you have to press the foil so hard against your neck skin it can give a slight burning sensation for the next few hours even after lotion is used. But not bad.. It just seems like the cutting blade may be a tad bit too far from the foil and that's why you gotta press hard on the foil to get close. Overall this shaver is good for the $70 price, so with the price factored in I'll give it 4 stars. I still prefer the braun 6520 foil/trimmer design and its overall shave though even though that one isn't perfect either.
  1443. 'm a Black man with very coarse facial hair that grows in multiple directions. I've been using this shaver for just over 30 days. It will provide a close shave on my face, jaw line, and neck given enough passes. However, the extra contact can cause irritation, even when using wet. Using shaving gel made it less effective for me and didn't help reduce irritation. The shaver also cuts a little too close for me. I believe I would have fewer ingrown hairs if the foils left the hair a little longer. Technique is critical, and it will take time to figure out the best way to use it on different parts of your face.<br />The battery charges quickly and usually gives me 3 to 4 long shaves before recharging. The unit is very easy to clean -- simply pop off the foil and rinse under the faucet.<br />The absolute biggest drawback of this shaver is the pop out trimmer. The blade is too small and the action is pitifully WEAK. I can't line up my goatee with it without major effort. I still have to use my clippers if I want to look clean.

  1450. I had moderately high hopes for this shaver, and expected it to, at least, shave my face well. Unfortunately, it does not do so. I shave once every 2-6 days, and usually will trim all of the hair down with the trimmer prior to shaving, to avoid the hairs getting pulled out. This shaver, while it eventually can get all the hair off of my face, takes an annoyingly long time to do so (about 10-15 minutes in total, usually), and requires me to go over the same spots many times. Furthermore, for those with a protruding jawline, you will need to stretch your skin quite a bit to be able to get into those corners, whereas some shavers, regardless of expense, can do a much nicer job of this. I usually have to essentially scrub my face with this shaver to get solid results, and I didn't expect to have to do this. It leaves my skin more irritated than it should, and turned out to be a downgrade from my much older, less expensive shaver. My hair is rather thick, though not coarse, so perhaps those with thick hair should be wary of this...idk.<br /><br />On a positive note, the shaver is easy to clean, retains a charge fairly well, feels nice, and the blades don't appear to be getting any duller. Nice to have it be waterproof, as well.<br /><br />So for whatever reason, this shaver has poor performance for me, though obviously many others are satisfied. My product doesn't appear to be defective in any way.

Very light to pack, feels like it weighs 1/3 of my Braun.<br /><br />Its only flaw is that unlike my trusty Braun, it will not work well on 2-day growth or longer, it just takes too long, and you migt as well break out the blade.<br /><br />Although my Braun can handle any length of stubble, it will never shave as close as this one does.   1485. Bought this approx 2 months ago. As you can tell from my tag line, got a little caught up in reading all the reviews and variations on the brands, price points, features, etc... I know some people can not go that route, so this is not a bad alternative. Does seem to shave a little closer, and it does clean well with a little liquid soap added when rinsing off. I do have a hard time understanding why anyone would spend more than this...really, its just an electric razor -- a good shave is what I needed, and this is doing the trick.
  1486. I've tried electric razors periodically over the years hoping to find one that gives a shave relatively comparable to safety or disposable razors. Inevitably, I've found the electrics notably inferior to blades and have switched back. Fed up once again with the rising cost of disposable blades, along with the accompanying nicks, cuts, and irritated skin, I decided recently to try the Panasonic ES 8103s based on the strong positive reviews on Amazon.com. I'm truly glad I did, and encourage those looking to switch from blades to an electric razor to give the ES8103s serious consideration. I should note that I have a relatively light beard, so those with heavy beards might want to look for a review of this product by users with similar features. I also have a mild case of psoriasis, with patches of affected skin near my sideburns and on both sides of my neck near my larynx. This chronic, genetically inherited skin condition means I have a sensitive face that is prone to razor burn and other shaving-related irritations. Thus, a clean, close, comfortable shave is particularly important, since nicks and other problems associated with shaving tend to get magnified. I've used the Panasonic ES 8103s for about two weeks so far, and can honestly report that it has delivered by far the best shave I have ever had, blade or electric. It's easy to use right out of the box. Just unpack it, plug in the detachable charging cord and when the digital display reads \\"100%\\" it is ready for use. Right away you will notice a very positive feature: the ES8103s charges very quickly, going from 0% to fully charged in about an hour. The razor holds a charge (based on my shaving needs) for about a week. Cleaning is simple. When the razor needs to be cleaned, a \\"spigot\\" symbol shows in the display. Press and briefly hold the on/off button until the razor enters the \\"turbo\\" mode (a digital indicator will show, plus the blade sound is clearly different), wet the foil (bladecover) under running water, apply liquid hand soap to the foil and allow the razor to clean itself. The foil is then easily removed by depressing two black buttons on either side of the razor head. Rinse the now-exposed blades and the foil, and let dry. Quick, easy, and efficient. What about the shave? Five stars. The razor looks big, but is actually light and well balanced in your hand. Never mind the few reviews that call attention to what the reviewers perceive as a \\"freakishly large\\" head. It just looks that way. I find the ES8103s makes fast, nearly effortless work of my beard. Virtually no pressure is needed to ensure a very close clean shave. Even problem areas (just under your nose, for example) are a snap. The result has been an astonishingly close shave that leaves my face smooth and clean. The shave it delivers lasts longer than a blade shave. No bumps. No nicks. Absolutely no razor burn. Best of all, the ES8103s absolutely does not irritate my sensitive skin. In fact, I swear it does the reverse: it leaves my face so clean and smooth it actually reduces the underlying day-to-day irritation that accompanies mild cases of psoriasis like mine. The ES8103s simply delivers the best shave I have ever head. Every time. If you have sensitive or prone to chronically irritated skin like mine, this product is worth every penny. PS -- you may note that Amazon shows other users purchasing the WES 9013PC replacement kit (outer foil/inner blade) plus a second inner blade only replacement kit. Don't make the mistake of doing this. Just get the WES 9013PC replacement kit on its own. Panasonic recommends replacing the outer foil once a year and the inner blades every OTHER year. Assuming that's right, you won't need 2 sets of replacement inner blades. PROs: GREAT shave. Zero irritation. Lightweight razor. Fast charge. Easy to use. Very decent price for the quality of the shave. Works wet or dry (I have only used it dry). CONs:None. USER UPDATE (12-30-2010): I have now been using this product daily for a month. I can report no changes necessary to my earlier review, except to say that it takes less time to fully charge than originally reported (30 minutes or less as opposed to 1 hour). Bottom Line: Great shave, great price. Highly recommended.
  1487. I replaced a Panasonic ES-8068 razor because of problems with the pop-up trimmer and it wasn't until I started using my new ES-8103S that I realized how worn out my old razor had become. The new razor is so much lighter in weight and gives such a trouble-free shave that I can't wait to use it again. An all-around great razor for me, I love it.
  1488. Charges quickly enough; I get 10+ shaves from a full-charge. Shaves are pretty good - best results have been right after a hot shower or with shaving cream. Shaving after splashing some warm water on the face yields pretty good results too. Note: if you are switching from using a blade-razor such as Gillette Fusion to using an electric shaver, be aware that the electric generally does not give as close/smooth a shave as the blade-razor. It took me a week to get used to that. All-in-all a great razor. I would buy it, knowing what I know now.
  1489. Bought this shaver when my 11 year Braun finally quit working. I am very impressed. Shaves very close and shaving takes very little time. Unit is very quiet, easy to clean and battery charges quickly. Shaver comes with a fabric bag to store or transport. Wish Panasonic would have spent more money on a case. Bag is too small to store the charging cord. Great service from Amazon. Got free shipping and a $10.00 rebate. Noticed that price of the shaver went up $25.00 since I ordered it. Would recommend buying this shaver.
  1490. Edit - July 13 2012<br /><br />I've been using this razor for about 18 months and although in its first weeks its job was not that great, I can say that nowadays its performance has been pretty solid. As long as I don't grow too much of a beard, I can get a clean face very quickly
  1491. I'm upgrading from my 3 year old Norelco rotary type shaver. I paid about $60 for it. It wasn't holding a charge and didn't shave my neck very well. I did a lot of research, starting with Consumer Reports' ratings and a lot of user reviews at Amazon and other sites. I'm happy with my choice of the Panasonic ES8103S, and at $53 it's a great value. I was set to pay $150 or so.<br /><br />There have been many comments on battery life. I have a pretty light beard. Having used it 8 days, it says 70% charge. So in my case it looks like I'll easily get the 14 three-minute shaves out of one charge.<br /><br />As to closeness of shave-- the old Norelco left a lot of stray hairs, esp. on the neck. Not so with this Panasonic. I only use it dry... have never tried the wet shave option. I suppose it would be good for someone with a heavier beard.<br /><br />Some say it's noisy. Well, it would be nice if it were muted a bit. But hey, it's not a blade shaver!<br /><br />Some say it gets uncomfortably hot. It does get warm, but not at all uncomfortable. Maybe if I had a heavy beard and took longer to shave it would get hotter, but it seems to get warmed up and not continue getting hotter as I shave.<br /><br />I think a lot of one's reaction to the first use of this (or any) electric shaver is affected by what one has been used to. If it was a blade, it will take some adjustment. Since I was used to a rotary, it felt comfortable and smooth from day one.
  1492. First, I used safety razors. Gillette Fusion gave me the fewest scratches--but even then, I could barely shave every day. Then, I used a Norelco. I could shave every day, but it left me with a 5 o'clock shadow. Moreover, I still had to use a hefty amount of aftershave (which stung) and lotion, otherwise my face would hurt from irritation. After a few hours of online research and reading numerous reviews, I bought this shaver. Differences? + No more 5 o'clock shadow. My face actually feels as it I'd used a safety razor. No stubble when I go against the direction of the hair. + Barely any stinging when I apply aftershave. 3 seconds, and then I feel nothing--as if I haven't shaved. + Cleaning the shaver with running water is a plus. Now there's no need to retrieve the tiny brush, and the results are much cleaner. + It's not noisy, despite what I read in other reviews. I definitely recommend it to everyone looking for a new shaver.

  1503. I normally shave with a Braun Series 3 Model 8985, which is a terrific shaver. Because I forgot that shaver on my two-week vacation, I bought the Panasonic at a local Target on sale.   1504. This is the first time I have used an electric razor after 45 years of various blade systems. The factors that were important to me about this Panasonic were that it is cordless and can be used in the shower. I find that it has taken a couple of weeks to get used to the way it shaves, and now get a close shave without any of the irritation a blade can cause. I experimented with several pre-shave protocols... dry, wet, light shave oil, light shave oil with Dr. Bonner's pepperment oil soap, and just the soap. I didn't like the scent of any of the easily available commercial pre-shave preparations. I have found that using the soap on lightly wetted skin is enough lubrication to let the razor move smoothly, and does not clog the razor or foam excessively. There may be better ways to do it, but this works the best for me so far. The razor charges very quickly, from 10% to 100% in well under an hour. I find it takes me approximately 10%-20% charge per shave, with the biggest variable being if I have not shaved for several days. I am also finding that as I get more familiar with an electric razor it takes less time. I rinse it out after shaving and wipe it off, blow through the foil and the cutters to get rid of most of the water, and leave it open on the counter to finish drying. I recommend the razor for its ease of use, ergonomic qualities and how well it works. After a fair amount of research it appears to be one of the best values available. Amazon delivered it earlier than expected and packaged appropriately.
  1505. I bought this for a 99 year old man. Alex is completely satisfied with it. I've not gotten any complaints as of today.
  1506. I have a really rough beard and sensitive skin, especially when using an electric shaver in the neck area. I've used a lot of shavers over the years, Norelco with gel, Braun, etc. This is by far the best shave I've ever gotten from an electric, and I'm using it with cheap Barbasol, not some expensive cream, by the way. Usually, it takes 30 days of use to acclimate the face to a new electric shaver, but after 3 days, the skin is responding extremely well (even the neck area), as it did upon first use. I'm not sure what is so incredibly great about this shaver, whether it's the nanotechnology that produces a closer shave or if it's something else, but I'll be using this shaver or another one like it for years to come.
  1507. After a great deal of research and reading reviews on several different razors I decide on the Panasonic ES8103S. The choice was a good one and exceeded my expectations. This razor is gentle on the skin no burn marks. It gives the closest shave of any razor I have owned and I have owned most of the popular brands out there. I have not tried shaving with lather and water but I get close enough shave dry. Razor is easy to clean just follow simple directions. Batery life is good and razor is very comfortable to hold and shave. As mentioned in other reviews this razor is a little on the loud side but you get use to it and it not bad enough to bother. I highly reccommend this product.
  1508. I always hated shaving until I got this razor when it was on the deal of the day for 54$. What a great deal, now I shave 2 times a day without any irritation, granted it does not give you the ultimate close shave but for my and my skin it's perfect. The batterie life is good for now, 5 days with one charge. Again great razor for the price but don't expect the same shave as a 300$ plus razor.

  1510. I've owned 6 or 7 electric razors, mostly inexpensive. This is certainly the best of the lot. It does well with long and short stubble, and the trimmer is more than adequate. I don't use the 'wet' option, so I can't speak to that. It does a great job of providing a close shave in a short period of time. Unlike some other razors, I don't have to press down hard to get a close shave. Honestly, I can't imagine a better shaving experience for what I paid ($54.99). Highly recommended, especially for people who have never had a good razor.

  1521. i am a first time electric user. so far I am very pleased with the results. my shave is close and comfortable.
  1522. My previous razor was a nice Braun. When it was new 10 years ago. This new Panasonic puts it to shame. It is the smoothest, softest shave of any shave I've every had electric or blade. I'm stunned how much better this feels than when my Braun was new. If your razor is old, if you're considering a new one and thinking (I'll just replace the cutters and screen\\" - don't. You will thank yourself daily when you use this. Aside from the close shave, I like the charge meter that lets me know when I need to recharge it so I don't wave up and try to shave with a dead battery. It's also got a \\"time to clean\\" indicator on the display. Very handy. I wish I could describe in words for you how smooth this will feel on your skin. But I can't so you'll just have to get one and feel for yourself.
  1523. It's pretty much awesome, but it's better used wet then dry bc it kind of irritates my skin when i try to do a quick shave.
  1524. It's pretty. And that is all. I have a real beard not some fuzz you need the sun in the background to notice. Fuzz is all this razor was ever built to cut. The actual cutting surface of the head is so small that you have to really work hard to cover your face in any reasonable time. The cutting blades actually dive away from the cutting screen when presented with a strong beard and it doesn't even cut the hair much. You have to constantly go over the same area again and again. Went back to my old Remington. Gave the razor to my girfriend and she promptly threw it out after trying it on her legs after a week. Finally, cutting your beard when your skin is hydrated and therefore swollen is not very effective. When you skin dries under normal air humidity your beard comes out and it feels like you have a half-day growth. Totally flawed in every respect.
  1525. The first time i used this shaver it was terrible. It took me 30 minutes to get some stubble off my face and even then it didn't do a very good job. But after a couple of weeks of using it, it started to work pretty well, even around the neck and adam's apple area. The battery doesn't last very long, but you will always know when it's about to run out because of the lcd displaying percent left. This is a nice feature because i've been caught before with a razor out of energy and only half way done with my shave. I probably wouldn't buy it again, just because i'm still looking for the perfect electric shaver.
  1526. Gave this to my brother for Christmas and the following day felt his cheeks. It was definitely not a good clean shave that he can achieve with a manual razor. Was quite disappointed.
  1527. I bought this as a Christmas gift to myself in 2010, and almost a year later and its working flawlessly. I've rotated the blades once to be sure that they weren't dulling, but I really think I could have gotten another few months out of their original position. I shave my head with this and can get 2 full face/head shaves off of a single charge and still have 10-20% charge remaining depending on how much growth I had. It recharges quickly and is easy to clean with simple running water and soap. For the price and efficacy, I can't think of a better razor.
  1528. I've had mixed experience with Panasonic razors - the first one I had was great, the second was pretty mediocre. When I wanted to replace that last one, I was hesitant to get another Panasonic but the reviews seemed better than the other options (except perhaps those the $200+ range) so I took a chance. I'm glad I did.<br /><br />This ProCurve gives a really good shave, and that's what it's really all about. Even working the post-weekend, three-day stubble it went through it quickly, leaving my face very smooth. In the past I've sometimes had to \\"finish up\\" with a blade razor over parts that my old Panasonic didn't do well on, but I don't have a problem at all with this model. It might be the first razor that I can honestly left my face smoother than a blade.<br /><br />Other than the quality of the shave, there are a few good things about this razor; it's very comfortable and light in the hand, making it easy to maneuver. The head of the unit can be put in to \\"soft\\" mode with a tremendous amount of pivot in two planes of motion, or put in to \\"lock\\" keeping the head perfectly fixed. I find that different parts of my face are best served by using different modes, and it's a quick flick of the switch to move from one to the other. The trimmer on this is small but effective, and I appreciate that it flips out a good inch, which makes it easy to see where sideburns or mustaches need to be trimmed. The unit doesn't vibrate much at all, and is pretty quiet, though I would still say it's going to wake up the spouse if used in a nearby bathroom. And of course I like the fact that it's a wet/dry shaver, which makes it good no matter how you like to shave and also it's easy to clean.<br /><br />The only downside I can think of is that it doesn't come with a cradle; the one thing I liked about my old Panasonic razor was that it had an inductive charging cradle which was very convenient, and because the charging was inductive it meant the shaver was completely sealed. This unit doesn't seem as well sealed, and there may be damage to the power connector over time if exposed to water. One good thing about the charger though is that it is relatively compact, and curiously is almost shelf-like when plugged in to the wall, which allows the razor to sit on top of it while charging, almost as if it were designed that way. I say almost because it's not exactly secure there - a bit of a bump might knock it off. If they designed it as a shelf while charging, that was pretty smart but because it's flat and the body of the razor is curved it's not a perfect fit. Just a little tweak and it would be a perfect shelf.<br /><br />All in all I'd say this was definitely worth the price, and I'm overall very happy with it so far. It remains to be seen what kind of battery life it has, but if it's like my old razor it should go a couple weeks on a charge, which is fine for most business trips. I'm giving it four stars instead of five only because I feel like, for the price, it should include a cradle, and because of my concern about the charging contacts standing up to rust over a few years.<br /><br />UPDATE: After a couple of months and a couple of trips with this razor, I continue to be happy with the purchase. The shave is still among the better I've had from an electric razor and it's very comfortable to use. My trips have given me the opportunity to test battery life and I'd say that overall it's a little low - good for probably a week long business trip (shaving every day) or perhaps a two-week vacation (shaving less frequently). I'm still satisfied with it though, I just need to remind myself to bring the charger if I'm going on extended business trips.and there may be damage to the power connector over time if exposed to water. One good thing about the charger though is that it is relatively compact, and curiously is almost shelf-like when plugged in to the wall, which allows the razor to sit on top of it while charging, almost as if it were designed that way. I say almost because it's not exactly secure there - a bit of a bump might knock it off. If they designed it as a shelf while charging, that was pretty smart but because it's flat and the body of the razor is curved it's not a perfect fit. Just a little tweak and it would be a perfect shelf. All in all I'd say this was definitely worth the price, and I'm overall very happy with it so far. It remains to be seen what kind of battery life it has, but if it's like my old razor it should go a couple weeks on a charge, which is fine for most business trips. I'm giving it four stars instead of five only because I feel like, for the price, it should include a cradle, and because of my concern about the charging contacts standing up to rust over a few years. UPDATE: After a couple of months and a couple of trips with this razor, I continue to be happy with the purchase. The shave is still among the better I've had from an electric razor and it's very comfortable to use. My trips have given me the opportunity to test battery life and I'd say that overall it's a little low - good for probably a week long business trip (shaving every day) or perhaps a two-week vacation (shaving less frequently). I'm still satisfied with it though, I just need to remind myself to bring the charger if I'm going on extended business trips.

I belive any battery will degrade gradually.<br /><br />Cons:<br />1. When turned on, ES8103S is louder than my another older model ES4026.<br />2. Doesn't allow shaving and charging at the same time. Shaving function is disabled when it's being charged. I thought it would, because the charger has a decent length of power cord connected to the shaver. This is a pity. What if the battery is too low to use and there is no time to charge? ES4026 charger does not have a power cord.<br />3. Doesn't come with a brush for cleaning. Some older models have. Cleaning is not as easy as ES4026.
  1537. Packaging was great, item met all my expectations.
  1538. This is my 4th Panasonic razor and I think they're great, mainly because the motor is just stronger than what I've experienced in other electrics. The Panasonic 13,000 RPM motor cuts right through with no grabbing or tugging, whereas my last Braun would freeze up because it wasn't powerful enough. The shave is close and comfortable too and of course you can use it wet, even in the shower if you want. Don't get a Panasonic with the cheaper 10,000 RPM motor. And don't get the docking/charging/cleaning stations that are a waste and force you to buy supplies you don't need. This is very easy to clean and it says when it needs charging, which takes less than an hour. One charge lasts me over a week. The only reason I've had four of these is that I'll replace the blades once after about 18 months or so, but then 18 months later I'll just buy a new one if it's a good price. This one's about half as loud and heavy as one from a few years ago. The only complaint is that the charging indicator isn't very accurate. When it says 10% there's still probably over 25% of a charge remaining. But still, highly recommended.

  1543. I've used this new shaver now for about 8 shaves and it's doing great. This is my 4th electric/rechargeable razor and this is the best one so far. The nice thing is I notice no drop off in power from 100% charged to the 40%. For the price this seems like a very nice razor. It can handle 120 volts or 240, so it'll work overseas if you travel without an adapter, too.   1555. I'm a young guy and have always had an issue with irritated skin and ingrown hairs in the neck area. I have tried just about every multiblade razor on the market as well as learning to use old school DE razors (Merkur HD). Success varied with these different approaches with the double edged razor giving me pretty decent results. However, I'd still have to go digging in my face to retrieve an ingrown hair pretty frequently.<br /><br />I decided to give this particular razor a try after reading some stellar reviews about them. I got it home, shaved away and woke up the next morning with an irritated face and neck. Worse yet, I developed the same ingrown hairs I've been trying to avoid for years. I decided to change my approach and apply a preshave (Afta pre shave ) lotion and buzz my neck area with an Andis outliner I used for my sideburns instead of shaving with the razor. If cut too short, my stiff neck hairs grow horizontally and then under my skin causing the ingrown hairs.<br /><br />This technique worked like a charm. I honestly don't remember the last time I had an irritated face or an ingrown hair. I still don't shave everyday, usually 3-4 times a week. If I get lazy and wait more than few days to shave I use the andis outliner as a beard trimmer and mow off the long hair so that the shaver can get the hair in its foils. Since I don't shave everyday the blades and foil have lasted this whole time with no noticeable drop in performance. After shaving I rinse it with antibacterial soap and spray the inside with a tiny bit of razor lubricant (Remington shaver saver).<br /><br />The razor itself is holding up fine. The pop up trimmer is still flimsy but I use the outliner for any heavy duty detail work, it's adequate in a pinch. Battery performance is still fine, I can get about 10 shaves per charge. My display is holding up great. I know people have had issues with displays going blank after some time, mine has not but I don't use the razor wet so that may havesomething to do with it. Overall this has been a great purchase and at this point much cheaper than going with Gillette's overpriced cartridges.

  1576. I just ordered this. Will write more after I get it.<br />This will be my first electric razor. Except one my parents got me 30 years ago. Don't know if I was doing something wrong or what? They lasted a decent time. They've quit making those. I've been buying blades. Feeling like I'm wasting money. They'd get dirty between the blades quickly. Keep buying. They've gone up to four and five blades now. They still get dirty quickly. Have to buy more. And they're expensive. So I decided to look for a good electric shaver.<br />I have a nice little Wahl trimmer that I've used on my sideburns. They always grew because I didn't want to get my blades stuck with hair in between. Would shy away from the long hair of sideburns. That would mean immediate throw out and using another. I'm counting on this eliminating that problem.<br />I really like that it has a Lithium-ion battery. They're great batteries. A charge indicator also.
