Have always gotten good honest value from Panasonic.<br />I just know I don't like keeping on spending the money on blades that don't last long. Why the heck did they quit making those Atra's?<br />So we'll see how it goes. I'll add to this.<br />7/19... Ok just received this.<br />Charging.... Max one hour. That's great.<br />First impressions. It's not all that light. It ain't heavy. It doesn't feel or look cheap in anyway.<br />Usage.... Now I checked first on using this wet with bar soap lathered up. That's because I have shaved like that for years. I can't see wasting money on shaving cream. I did shave this morning. Been about 5 hours. Could use it, so I did. Even though I know they all say to give this a month to get used to it. I have to honestly say it worked great. Not perfect, yet. In many ways, this is the best shave I've gotten in years. Checking critically. In other ways. I think I can do better. I think it's me getting used to it and how to use it the best it can be. Even then, I have to admit, I haven't been getting a very good shave with my disposable three blade razors. Maybe a brand new disposable on the first half of my face was better? This is better. I do think the wet soap on my face helped. I couldn't help but rinse it while running and shaving. Result is I kept lathering up soap that was on my face already. Worked great.<br />*Sideburns....This is wonderful. First time trimming the big stuff wet. I was afraid to go wet with my nice little Wahl trimmer. With this. No problem. Just release the trimmer blade. Go for it. Finish of course with the main blades. The best part is it's all wet now. Don't have hair going all over the place. Wonderful.<br />*Cleaning.... The way I shave, with the wet soap. I choose to not follow the cleaning instructions. I choose to clean immediately. It works great. Very happy.<br />Overall I'm extremely happy with this. Have no intention of ever going back to disposable blade razors. I'll keep this at a definite five star. Suggest to anyone to buy it. I have to agree with the ratings site. I don't know that any razor can do a better job of a shave than this one?<br />*Technique.... On the going back and forth for the technique with this razor. Heck, I had to shave at least two directions with my blades to try to get a decent shave. This is no problem. Don't even have to turn it around. And it does better.<br />*Under nose and around lips.... I always had issues doing both of these with my three blade razor. Two blade was better. Now with this, it's not a problem. Especially the lips. If I got too close with my blade, I would cut my lip. With this, I can go right over my lips. Works great. I was worried this wouldn't get close edges well. Like right at the bottom of my nose. I was wrong. It gets nice and close on edges.<br />*Overall quality of shave... I am thinking many are being too critical of electric shavers. This one specifically. I'm just starting to learn to use it. I find I can rub my hand one way. It's smooth as can be. Rub another way and I can feel stubble. I'll shave with this in many directions. Am learning to get it to where it's smooth as can be in any direction. This smoothness is something I haven't quite felt with a blade razor. Even feeling stubble. It looks ok? I'm thinking I'm just plain getting a better shave than I have in the past. I am thinking that I'm being very critical of this electric razor. I didn't think about being critical before like I am now. It's doing a great job.<br />I find it entertaining the lathering up of the soap on my face with this razor. Lathers more after I run water over the blades. Kinda a habit from when I used a blade razor and had to rinse it often.<br /><br />I'll probably add more later. After more experience with this. For now I couldn't be happier with this electric razor.m. Don't even have to turn it around. And it does better.<br />*Under nose and around lips.... I always had issues doing both of these with my three blade razor. Two blade was better. Now with this, it's not a problem. Especially the lips. If I got too close with my blade, I would cut my lip. With this, I can go right over my lips. Works great. I was worried this wouldn't get close edges well. Like right at the bottom of my nose. I was wrong. It gets nice and close on edges.<br />*Overall quality of shave... I am thinking many are being too critical of electric shavers. This one specifically. I'm just starting to learn to use it. I find I can rub my hand one way. It's smooth as can be. Rub another way and I can feel stubble. I'll shave with this in many directions. Am learning to get it to where it's smooth as can be in any direction. This smoothness is something I haven't quite felt with a blade razor. Even feeling stubble. It looks ok? I'm thinking I'm just plain getting a better shave than I have in the past. I am thinking that I'm being very critical of this electric razor. I didn't think about being critical before like I am now. It's doing a great job.<br />I find it entertaining the lathering up of the soap on my face with this razor. Lathers more after I run water over the blades. Kinda a habit from when I used a blade razor and had to rinse it often.<br /><br />I'll probably add more later. After more experience with this.   1577. I have had one similar Panasonic shaver in the past and it lasted for years. I had trouble finding a good shaver at this price point. I'm happy to have it.
  1578. I read the positive amazon reviews and decided to take a chance. I bought this for my 71 year old dad who has short term memory loss from a stroke. I wanted something that was easy to use, could get wet in case that were to happen, easy to clean and works well. So, I guess I want it all. LOL. Well I didnt get it all with this unit but its close. The three blade razor cuts close and provides a good close shave for loose skin types. The size is good because anything wider ( like the 4 or 5 blade razors) would be too wide.) My dad can operate this on his own and then clean it. For him it produces about 6 shaves before it needs to be charged but this is NOT NORMAL use since he takes an extended amount of time shaving due to his issues. I would recommend this unit. If this exact one comes out with longer battery life and it works with the cord plugged in when the battery runs out of juice then it would be almost perfect. In my opinion you dont need a five blade unit or even four unless you have a large head/face because the amount of razor head surface would be too large around rounded corners. I hope this helps you.
  1579. I bought the Panasonic ES8103S in December of 2010 and it is still going strong! There is no doubt that one can get a closer shave with the ES8103 when using shaving gel or cream but I usually dry shave on my way into work and still receive a pretty good shave. Best razor that I have owned...hands down!

I was hoping an electric shaver would save me some time & effort, but this thing simply wasn't up to the job. I tried fast, slow, holding it in the same place, wet, dry, shaving cream - nothing worked. I ended up tossing mine in the garbage.

  1596. I have had many electric shavers over the years, but this one is exceptional.<br />The four row shaver is only good if your face is totally beard free.<br />The three row means that the slotted, longer hair remover is always close enough to the beard edge.<br />Its high speed is a must have, do not waste your time with lower speed razors!<br />Getting the automatic cleaner is a total waste of time and money. Dab a bit of soap on the foil and hold it under the tap and you're done.<br />Some advice:<br />First time you use it shave with an unwashed face, the oils will help run it in nicely.<br />Then shave after the shower, when your face has dried just enough for the shaver to run smoothly over the face. The hairs will have absorbed water and will be softer and fatter. After the shave they will dry further and shrink into their pores.<br />Never, never use pre-shave powder, it may make the shave feel more comfortable, but it will soon grind the sharp cutting edges round.<br />Use light pressure when hair is longer, then at the end use more pressure to cut short hair shorter.<br />If the speed of the shaver is affected, then you are pressing far too much.<br />Wash the shaver and use a drop of shaver oil occasionally.
  1597. I love how you can clean it with hand soap. You can also use it wet and dry which is why I chose this over the braun.

I have tried using a shaving cream and it works well, but shaving cream is not needed to get a good close shave.<br />I can't imagine ever using a dry-only electric razor again.<br /><br />Panasonic also sells more expensive versions that have fancy cleaning systems. Save your money and buy this one. A simple hot water rinse while the razor is running will keep the razor performing well.

  1647. I am a lifelong user of electric shavers, and I have owned this shaver for over one year. I use it every morning to shave. I also use the trimmer to cut longer hair around my face. I have never used it in the shower, always shaving dry, with no shaving cream or oils.<br /><br />This is an effective shaver, although the cutting ability has declined moderately over time. It takes me longer to shave now than it did when new. I have had no other complaints with the quality of the device. The foil has been remarkably durable, more so than the remington micro foil shavers I had in the past. The cutting action is about the same as my prior remington shavers, and slightly better than norelco electric shavers. It cuts better on the flat surfaces of the face than it does on the curves.<br /><br />The battery allows me to shave four or five times before requiring a recharge. My main complaint with this unit is the battery recharge. Unlike some other electric shavers I have used, this unit does not function while recharging. If the battery dies, it requires at least 20 minutes to recharge enough to finish the shave. Since I can't wait that long on most work days, I have to finish my shave with a conventional razor.<br /><br />I would buy this unit again. The price is pretty good, and the quality is equal to any other electric shaver I have used.

  1651. The shaver is not very good, I have to go over the same areas multiple times and still have to use a regular razor to clean up and get a close shave
  1652. great little shaver. can't use it while it's charging, is noisy, but who cares? easy to clean with soap and water.
  1653. it did nothing for my stubble
  1654. Great product for the cost.
  1655. I bought this shaver for my husband, he like the speed and the clean cut. But I do not like the noise it makes, the shaver woke me up every morning when he uses it. It makes a very loud noise. This is the loudest shaver I have ever known.
  1656. QUIET, compared to my old Remington. First thing I noticed.<br />The good: Very good close shave overall. Have to go over a number of times to get a good shave. Remington micro screen might get a closer shave. Panasonic does a good job overall.<br />The good: no missed hairs like with my old Remington micro screen.<br />The good: Performance good wet or dry shaving. I primary used wet with shaving cream.   1660. I ordered this Razor for my husband. He has had it about a month. He just had radiation treatment to the face/neck, very tender skin. He is able to shave with this shaver very comfortably. It gives a smooth shave and holds a charge for 5-7 days.

  1662. The instructions that came with the razor said to give the razor a try for at least 30 days. I had my doubts, but after 3 weeks my beard, face or razor is getting better, or all 3. I went from a full beard to a close shave and had reservations as to the ability of this razor. Now that I've become accustomed to the razor, it does a very nice job. I have to admit that taking an electricial appliance into the shower was an unnatural act, but it works very well. I would recommend it, but give it an honest try for at least 30 days.
  1663. Bought this for my husband's birthday. He really likes it. Smooth shave, easy to clean. You can even take it into the shower. Really good price through Amazon.
  1664. This is one of the best shaver i had!<br />The battery is charged very fast and lasts several shaves.<br />It picks up almost every hair at the 'first strike'.<br />I am not aware of any cons, but i own it only a few weeks...
  1665. I loved this shaver, and for about a year it worked fine.<br />Unfortunately it died on me. The display stopped working after a year and then the rest of the shaver died shortly thereafter, failing to turn on at all.<br /><br />I never once dropped it or ever used it as a wet shaver (even though it was designed for it). Also, I used it only 3-4 times a week and never over-charged it(if that's even possible).<br /><br />I bought this shaver because of the great reviews on it. Only after it broke did I realize that there where also a lot of reviews complaining of similar malfunctions that I had experienced.<br /><br />I just Ordered a Remington Shaver, I'm hoping that I can get more than a year of use this time :-/
  1666. I bought this when my $39, 5-year old Remington finally wouldn't take a charge. And I'm glad for that. The shaver gives a very close, comfortable shave. Isn't that what it's all about? It cleans under water, and the trimmer works very well without blocking your view when using it (I had once purchased a Braun that didn't allow you to see what you were trimming, believe it or not, and they took it back with no questions because they admitted they had had a lot of complaints). Anyway, back to the Panasonic - I purchased it at $69.00 and then the price immediately went up to $81.00. But even at that higher price, it's a great shaver for the money. There is a newer \\"ARC 4\\" model which I guess has an extra set of blades, but it had fewer reviews and they weren't as good as the reviews for this shaver, so I stuck with this older model. In summary, it gives a great comfortable shave, handles nicely, and appears to be of high quality. The only con might be the lack of a zippered, protective catrrying case (it comes with a cheap drawstring pouch) but that's ok, use the case from your old shaver. Conclusion: there are higher priced shavers out there that look fancier, and I'm sure they have some useful bells and whistles this one doesn't have, but this is a great, attractive shaver that feels good in your hand and is very reasonably priced.
  1667. better compared to norelco 3xxx series, but difficult to reach corner of nose and upperlip and folds on neck,<br />better get the automatic cleaning stand, messy to clean with soap and turbo mode.<br />price is descent, every shave will drain about 12-15% of charge.<br />displays faucet image when needs cleaning (showed that sight once after 10 shaves)<br />lock (used to lock the head) is slipping sometimes with force causing mobility of head

  1670. I used a three-headed, six-year-old Norelco electric razor that did fine. It was just getting old and needed to be replaced. Based on the reviews, I bought the Panasonic ES8103S and tried it for the first time yesterday. The shave is fairly close - typical of most electric razors - but it is really loud. It charges quickly, it's easy to use and to clean, but the noise is a huge drawback. Also, can't use it while it's plugged in and there's no stand. We'll see how good it is six months from now.

  1677. The best razor we've found. No pulling as others said. Easy to clean. Waterproof is a good advantage. Great buy!!!
  1678. We have two ES8103S now. The first one, I ordered to replace an electric shaver I used on my legs. This one seemed sturdier and to have overall better reviews than most of the designed-for-women shavers I looked at, and a little time searching around the web confirmed my suspicion that I would be FAR from the first woman to use a man's razor to shave her legs. I ordered a second one for a 91 year old woman who prefers to shave, not tweeze, the thick hairs that grow on her face and under her chin.<br /><br />For all areas, the trimmer first:<br /><br />If you're shaving hair more than about 3mm or 1/8 in. you NEED to use the trimmer first. The shaver seems much more likely to pass over longer hairs, leaving them uncut. The pop-up trimmer thing seems to work great. Moving it gently over skin leaves, basically, semi-long stubble that the shaver has a much easier time with. Looking at how it seems to work I wouldn't recommend pushing hard with the trimmer at all; it looks like it could pinch/tear skin that managed to get caught. So we've been using it with respect and haven't had it hurt either of us.<br />(There's no way to adjust the length of hair the trimmer cuts in case anyone reading this is curious.)<br /><br />For legs:<br /><br />I don't expect an electric shaver to get as close as a razor. Using this on my legs I can get the skin smooth to the touch, but the stubble will be back the next day as opposed to using a razor which usually leaves my legs feeling smooth for closer to two days. I use it in the shower with shaving cream on my legs. I have to go over most areas at least twice to get rid of all the stubble, and I seem to get the best results shaving in multiple directions instead of always with or against the hair's grain. I've never had it cut my legs or even leave razor burn/irritation.<br />I could use it out of the shower on dry skin, but I prefer the results I get using it to shave when the skin and hair are all wet and soft from the shaving lather.<br /><br />For underarms:<br /><br />I did try using this to shave under my arms, but I gave up. The only way I could ever get the skin to feel smooth to the touch required many passes pushing pretty hard. I'd wind up with scratches/welts from where the edges of the foil scratched me. So I stick to a disposable razor for shaving my armpits. After that experience, I'm in no rush to test the shaver on my bikini line.<br /><br />For 91 year old female face:<br /><br />We use this on her face after she's had a shower. It would probably work better in the shower, but there are non-shaver related reasons which make that impractical. I can shave her even if she hasn't recently had a shower, but I get better results when the skin/hair is still soft and damp right after bathing. Like my legs, it usually requires multiple passes and directions to get the skin to feel smooth. I have the most trouble getting hairs near the corners of her mouth and under her chin where her skin is very loose. Best results seem to come if we can manage to pull the area of skin we're shaving taut.<br /><br />Overall:<br /><br />I have no complaints about the quality. The thing seems sturdy enough and looks like the pictures. It doesn't strike me as complicated to operate. It recharges within a few hours; it's always finished charging when I think to come check on it, so I'm not sure exactly how long it takes.<br /><br />If speed is an issue, I would not recommend this over safety razors because it always takes us longer to shave with this. I use this on my legs to avoid the irritation and cuts I get from razors and to reduce the number of disposable razors I go through. I advised it for the old lady because her hands shake too much to shave herself and none of us, her caretakers, are confident enough using a razor on the rather loose and wrinkly skin on her face.<br /><br />I give it four stars for, \\"I like it\\" because it pretty much does everything I was expecting. I'dgive it five stars if it didn't take multiple passes, but it might be more apt to irritate the skin if they redesigned it to cut more aggressively.
  1679. I purchased this shaver on Amazon because I had had a previous Panasonic that had performed well, and the price was attractive. I've used it for about a month, and get about a week's worth of shaves per charge. The percentage of charge remaining display is quite helpful. Unfortunately, it does not give a very close shave; my old one did better. I have only used it dry, and it may be that it works better wet, but I would expect it to shave well in either mode.
  1680. After my Norelco gave up being just a year and a half old, I decided to go with this one. I figured it was a good middle-range price option. I didn't want to go super cheap or super expensive. I've been using it for about two weeks now, about 4 or 5 shaves, and I have some very good first impressions. First of all it doesn't feel cheap. It has a nice weight to it. You can also take it in the shower and clean with soft soap, which is nice. It gives a really nice close shave, and even gets the hairs around my neck and throat with little effort, which were impossible with my Norelco. It only has 3 drawbacks. One, I feel like it heats up a little faster than the Norelco did, so for extended use it can wear you down a little. However, it does shave quickly, so it hasn't really been a problem. After 3 or 4 days of hair growth, a 10 min shave will do the trick. Two, the clipper is the only thing about this shaver that feels cheap. It flips open from the back and looks nice, but it doesn't really do that great of a job. Still, since the shaver itself does a great job, I haven't had a big need to use it. And finally, it's a little noisier than my Norelco was. It's not a big deal for me, because it again it's really quick, but I mention it in case any one else needs a quiet one.<br /><br />Final thoughts, totally worth the price in my opinion. You're not spending $400, so don't expect the world. Yet still, it's a very close shave, and feels like a well designed, thought out product. It's got my vote.
  1681. Great shaver, recharges fast (in about 1 hour at 220V) but the LCD display is dying with segments disappearing only after 6 months of use. Now it will be harder to know when to charge and how long to charge it for. It wouldn't be cost effective to return it to Amazon even though I could. Shaving function still works great though.
  1682. Hi this is the best shaver I have ever purchase excellent on everything charge quickly and not to noise and when I shave is like shaving whit the razor blade thanks
  1683. Have had an opportunity to use this shaver over the past several weekends, and I am impressed. It holds a charge very well, and has an indicator with the percent of charge left. The fact that you can use it wet or dry is a very nice feature. I've experienced zero razor burn, and get a good, clean, shave. Highly recommended!
  1684. This is the third replacement (under warranty) of this razor. The first two the batteries self destructed after 1 year, and the next, six months. The shave is good, however, after six months the battery life has degraded from 1 week of shaves to 4 days. The liquid crystal display failed after about 2 weeks. I've been a loyal Panasonic shaver user for about 25 years but am really dissappointed to watch the quaity degrade in the recent models.
  1685. I bought this product because I heard that foil shavers are much better for those with sensitive skin than rotary shavers. After a couple months of use, I've found that to be confirmed. I've experienced literally no irritation since I started using this shaver. It doesn't pull the hair at all, and the high rpm on the blades is very reassuring.<br /><br />It doesn't do as well with longer hair, however. If I let my beard grow too long, I have to use the trimmer (which is top notch, by the way) before shaving. I've also noticed that it doesn't get as close a shave as my old rotary shaver, but that's because it doesn't pull the hairs up to cut them. The difference is marginal; it still cuts very close and clean.<br /><br />It's easy to clean, too! I haven't had the display tell me I need to clean it yet, but I have. Very simple and well made.<br /><br />I'd buy it again for the price, especially when compared to other options.
  1686. Before purchasing this razor I had been using a Braun shaver. However, it became difficult to purchase blades for the shaver I had. After checking various web sites, I selected the Panasonic ES8103S because of the features and the excellent price I found on Amazon. So far I have been very satisfied. The shaver is quiet, charges quickly and has a readout which shows the amount of charge left and when the razor needs cleaning. The razor gives a good shave although not as close as my old Braun did before they began manufacturing their shavers in China. I have used the Panasonic now for about a month and am glad that I selected it over the other shavers I researched.
  1687. Went from a razor to this product without the pain expected. With the cost of razor blades continually raising, this is well worth the money. Highly recommended
  1688. The Panasonic ES8103 and 8109 (they're the same) shave well when they work. I have owned 3. But there are two big problems with both. One problem is the battery. It just doesn't last. Yesterday my shaver died after less than one year. My two other shavers also had battery and charging problems. The other problem is the little screen that indicates how much charge is left. That screen begins to lose characters and definition within weeks and after a few months they go blank, meaning that you don't know how much charge is left. These Panasonic models will give you a good shave if you plan to use them for just a few months and them throw them away. If you hate wasting your money and want to have a good shaver that will last a reasonable amount of time, then buy a different brand.
  1689. I read the good and the bad review on this product. I have to say that I am impressed with this shaver. It feels very solid on the had, It shaves very well (I used it right out of the box with just 10% power on it) this is something I have never been able to do since I have very sensitive skin. The shaver gave me a painless, and close shave. It makes a humming sound that is not too loud. All in all, I can recommend this product.
  1690. This is my second of this brand and style. I like the high speed of the Panasonic razors. The first one was generallly used as a dry razor, and has lasted three years, with a replacement blade and foil at year one. It is still working and is my travel razor. The new ES8103S has been used almost exclusively as a wet razor with Edge foam. It provides a very good shave. Keep the charge up, because it does not run with the charger cord plugged in - the only drawback I can mention, but it makes sense as you probably do not want to be wet shaving while plugged into a wall outlet.
  1691. The shaver doesn't cause irritations on the skin at all and can be washed with water. My brother is very satisfied with it.
  1692. Let me start my review by saying, if you're looking for an electric shaver that won't mangle your neck into a red blotchy mess, look no further!<br /><br />I've previously owned electric shavers from Remington, Norelco and Braun, all of them but the Remington cost more than this Panasonic. Every one of those other shavers I owned would randomly irritate my neck and leave patches of stubble. They say that you need to keep using the shaver, tough it out and your skin will get used to it, I've owned all of them long term and this was not my experience. All of my other shavers were like a skin torture device to some degree or another on seemingly random days. The Norelcos and the Braun that I owned were all top of the line models as well, I'm not a cheapskate. I will say that I was skeptical about a Panasonic brand shaver at first; since Remington and Norelco pretty much exclusively concentrate their product development efforts on personal care technology like shavers, you'd think they make the best ones, wrong. I don't have to push and stretch and repeatedly go over stubble that would otherwise be left by my previous shavers. I've been using this Panasonic (dry) for over a month and this is the closest and most consistent shave I've ever had. Unlike the Braun electro-foil shavers, this Panasonic seems to oscillate at a much higher frequency, I'm guessing that's why it's so much more superior.<br /><br />If I have to find any negatives about it, I would say that the flip-up trimmer is kinda weak, it tends to bog down and miss hair if you plunge it into a patch of thick beard, but if you're patient it works ok. The other annoying thing about the flip-up trimmer is that you can only effectively use it in a downward motion, if you push up ever so slightly, it starts to flip shut and disengages from the motor. The battery life indicator seems to be rather dumb, the shaver does charge very quickly and holds a charge long enough to work for at least 2-3 weeks off charge, but the indicator predictably drops by 10% intervals every morning that you use the shaver. Once you're at 10% it doesn't indicate any lower, but in my experience it will shave at least 5 more times after it reaches 10%. Beyond the 10% though, there is absolutely no other warning, when the shaver decides it's out, it stops abruptly. Really these are minor issues in an otherwise excellent product in my opinion.<br /><br />I rarely write reviews as my review history will show, but this is such a good shaver that I actually felt compelled to write a review about it. This Panasonic is hands down the best electric shaver I've ever owned!arge, but the indicator predictably drops by 10% intervals every morning that you use the shaver. Once you're at 10% it doesn't indicate any lower, but in my experience it will shave at least 5 more times after it reaches 10%. Beyond the 10% though, there is absolutely no other warning, when the shaver decides it's out, it stops abruptly. Really these are minor issues in an otherwise excellent product in my opinion.<br /><br />I rarely write reviews as my review history will show, but this is such a good shaver that I actually felt compelled to write a review about it. This Panasonic is hands down the best electric shaver I've ever owned!

  1709. I tried a Norelco in high school 20 years ago, it stunk, so I have stuck with razors ever since. I saw this on Amazon for $69, read the great reviews, thought I would give it a try and am very glad I did. With my beard, shaving down with a razor looked just o.k. and was rough. Shaving up on the face got me really smooth, but it was hard on my skin, and shaving up on my neck was not an option. In just a couple weeks of getting used to this Panasonic, my face gets near-up razor smooth, and my neck is closer than I could ever get it with a razor. And no burn, rash, nothing. Very comfortable. It's not quite as good if you let your beard go a few days and the hairs start to lay at all, but otherwise it's great. If you can get this razor for anywhere close to the price I paid, I am not sure why you would spend more on anything else.
  1710. I decided to buy this shaver after I had read all the positive reviews here on Amazon, and I'm glad I did.   1711. I bought this shaver a little over a month ago. I was looking for a specific set of specs and this seemed to fit the bill perfectly. I'm taking a trip overseas and wanted a single shaver/beard trimmer combo (at the time I was using a separate ancient Remington Triple Action shaver and Wahl trimmer) that also had an international power supply (neither previous device had). I can say that this is an excellent shaver. It shaves cleanly, quickly and efficiently. I have thick, dark facial hair and this goes right through it. I get about 10 shaves per charge, though I do have a full beard and so am only shaving my cheeks and throat. Others' uses per charge may vary. I've had no razor burn from it and only once has it pulled a hair in the month I've been using it. Clean-up is fast and simple using soap and water. I have no particular complaints with it. The sound is not quiet (as others have pointed out) and quite high-pitched, but I don't find it painfully so and it is still quieter than my previous shaver. All in all, I'd say it's one of my best purchases of the last year.

  1713. Months of skin treatment required use of electric razor instead of blade razor. Purchased ES8103S due to excellent reviews.<br /><br />So far I'm very satisfied. I'm already getting a decent shave. I've tried both dry and with gel and gel is closer for me. At first I failed to keep the foil flat against my skin, was using too much angle...need to have all three blades in contact...duh! I estimate it takes about twice the time to shave with the electric than it does with my blade razor. I was pleasantly surprised how effective the shaver is around the mouth/chin area. There is less irritation than the blade.<br /><br />The instructions are a bit vague and could be better, especially re cleaning. However, cleaning is fairly easy. If the razor continues to perform well over time, I will raise the rating to five stars.
  1714. Great shave and use it to shave my head as well. Battery life is not so great and have to charge very few days. Probably not terrible for the time it is in use each day shaving that big head of mine. Have two, one for travel so I never forget it. Good backup as well in case I drop it or otherwise damage it.

  1718. This shaver is the second electric wet/dry from Panasonic I have purchased. The first one lasted several years even after being dropped numerous times. This shaver works fine in, before or after the shower. The charge lasts approximately one to two week. It recharges in two hours or less. The shaver is very lightweight.<br /><br />The shave itself is close, but not as close as a blade. However, the trade off in closeness is worth it because the razor never cuts my face. I have had the best results using any brand shaving gel with the shaver.
  1719. THE MOST QUIET, SMOOTH, EXTREMELY COMFORTABLE SHAVE I HAVE EVER USED. FAR BETTER THAN OTHER BRANDS COSTING MORE DOUBLE THE PRICE.
  1720. Having formerly used a Remington two-blade Titanium electric razor for many years, I feel qualified to review this Panasonic two blade.<br /><br />Pros: Quiet, good close shave, nice floating head, waterproof and easy to wash, battery charge state indicator easy to understand, plastic protective cover fits well and stays on. Reasonable price for what you get. I've never used a Bosch, so I can't offer any comparison to that.<br /><br />Cons: Hard to use sideburn/long-hair trimmer (it's on the back and you have to work to get it open, and then turn the whole shaver 180 degrees to use it. The Remington design is better and easier to use.) The charger is a small wall-dongle, not built-in, so you have more to carry when traveling than with the Remington. Replacement heads are somewhat pricier than Remington's.<br /><br />Waiting to see: Can't tell if the battery is replaceable when it dies, unlike the Remington. Hated to throw away the Remington just for that.

  1724. I got one of these as a gift over the holidays. I am really disappointed in its performance. I've been using electric razors for at least 15 years and for the price, this has got to be one of the worst I've used. It takes FOREVER to shave with it and the trimmer is just terrible. People say the battery lasts a long time but I completely disagree. And the worst part is you can't even use it while it's charging. I did not like my previous Remmington razor either but I got an equivalent shave with a battery that DID last forever and I could use it while charging. Not to mention it cost about half as much and the trimmer was functional.<br />I will say it is one of the more comfortable razors I've used but I believe it's because it does not cut that close. I feel I need another shave in a few hours.<br />Razors in general with a straight head design are just comical to me. I will only shop for ones that have the 3 circular blades in the future. There's almost no place on my face where you get most of the blades to contact your skin. The other style with 3 circular blades covers so much more of your face at once and shaving takes half the time. Plus they actually pivot with your face and make so much more sense.

  1740. My favorite razor. Does a nice conferrtable shave. Light, easy to clean, and holds a good week charge.
  1741. I'm not a hairy guy. I used to use a Gillette Fatboy flat razor but only shaved every other day. That was enough. But since my doctor put me on blood thinners and I nicked myself and bled for 3 hours, I decided to buy an electric razor. Years ago my wife bought me a Nurelco electric razor. It did a mediocre job but what I disliked the most was the noise. It was incredibly loud. Fortunately, it died about 15 years ago and I switched to the Fatboy. In doing research for this purchase, I decided my top price would be $100. I cannot imagine spending more than that for an electric razor. But I wanted something that gave me a close shave and was quiet. I chose the Panasonic ES8103S and I am glad I did. The shave is close - as good as I ever got from the Gillette Fatboy, but there's no chance of nicking myself. And it's quiet too. I did notice that because of the way the razor works I have to shave regularly on a daily basis. I also noticed that because the blades do not touch my skin that my skin is not irritated as it used to be from shaving. I still use skin balm after shaving, but now I do it to smell nice. The only CONS for this razor is that the charging wire should have been coiled, and the razor should have included a cleaning brush. But for under $100 I cannot complain. (Perhaps I'm just cutting hairs??) And if my Panasonic ES8103S were to be stolen or broken by a mislaid hammer blow I would not hesitate to purchase another one just like it. One more thing - other reviewers have complained that the razor won't work while charging. Well, this is a WET/dry electric razor. If it's plugged in and you decided to use it WET then it could kill you, so just maybe that's why Panasonic decided to disable this feature. Eh? UPDATE: I do not always shave on a daily basis yet find that this razor does an admirable job. I do not know why my shaving is better than I found initially, and I really don't care. I'm very pleased with the Panasonic ES8103S razor and highly recommend it.

I cleaned the foil and blades daily, with soap and warm water (and sometimes rubbing alcohol), and lubricated them with light mineral oil (baby oil). I expected the foil and blades to last much longer than this. At about $30 a set, replacing the foil and blades for this shaver every 6 months would cost $60 per year. No thanks.   1764. A little over a year ago my Remington electric razor was stolen while on a trip in Las Vegas. I had the razor for several years and it was about time for a new one so I wasn't too sad over the lose. For the past year I have been shaving with regular straight razors. I tried several brands from expensive ones to the cheap multipacks you can find at any drug/super store. I could not seem to find any razor that would shave me as close as my old Remington would, especially under the neck!<br /><br />For Christmas my wife got me a new razor. I had sent a wish list of several that I was interested in and she settled on the Panasonic ES8103S. It was such a good choice! After charging and shaving with it just one time my skin has never been so smooth and I can tell how much I missed having an electric. This electric is much smaller than my previous razor and it's contoured to fit the hand nicely. The trimmer works as expected and it's a nice simple design. Upon reading over the manual I was pleasantly surprised this was truly a wet/dry razor, meaning that you can actually use it in the shower and not just get the head wet. It can even be submerged in water but not for long periods of time! I don't plan on using it this way but it's nice to know that I won't damage it with a few drops of water here and there. The cleaning process is pretty simple and taking it apart for cleaning is a breeze.<br /><br />I've had several electric razors over the years from Norelco and Remington and the Panasonic ES8103S is by far my most favorite that I've owned. For under $100.00 and a host of features I don't think this razor can be beat. If you've had other electric razors you might be pleasantly surprised. If you've never used an electric give this a try for at least 30 days and you'll probably never go back to a straight razor again!

The Norelco was a simple pop open and rinse with all parts still attached. This one is not bad, but requires soaping and dis-assembly into separate parts. The dry time is also longer.   1779. For the money, this product performs an adequate job.<br /><br />Things I like:<br />-Trimmer<br />-Shape/size<br />-How close of a shave it can potentially get<br />-How quickly you can shave if your beard is short (see below)<br /><br />Things I don't like:<br />-Does not do well with longer hair. This can lead to really long shave times and irritation<br />-Pretty much have to go over the same area multiple times in different directions to get all hairs<br /><br />Overall this shaver does a good job.   1780. Cleaner shave and plenty powerful! This razor gives a shave near as smooth as a straight edge. I highly recommend it.
  1781. The reviews tell a good story, the overwhelming majority of people give this one 4 or 5 stars because that makes sense. If you read through the reviews it will tell you two things: 1. people that got a defective unit complain instead of getting a new one and trying it out with a fair review. 2 No consumer product is perfect and nothing is ever going to make everyone perfectly happy. If you have reasonable shaving expectations from an electric shaver then this product will not disappoint.<br /><br />Keep the battery between %30 and %80 full and you can get many years out of it. Lithium Ion cells like the one used in this shaver do not like being fully charger or fully discharged repeatedly. Do not let this shaver sit on the charger for more than 40 minutes ever. The included charger dumps 5.2volts at 1.2 amps into the handle (fast charging), so you can easily get many shaves out of the unit from 20 minutes of charging. Again keeping the state of charge % between %80 and %30 is the trick to getting super long life out of the battery. By shallow charging and shallow discharging it, you will be rewarded with a battery that lasts and maintains its functional life for more than 10 years. The linear motor used in this shaver will outlast every other component in its assembly. Change the foil every year and the blade every 2 years according to the manufacturer/ and that said you can have many many years of high quality fast electric shaving.<br /><br />This thinner 3 foil (2 blade) unit is better for curved facial surfaces than its 4 foil wide cousins. Stick to this one is you are accustomed to the facial contour following characteristics of a pivoting rotary type electric shaver.<br /><br />Be aware that this shaver is loud. I have not reviewed many electric shavers, and my old faithful Remington Rotary 460D titanium sounds tame and calm by comparison (and I just changed out the NiMH in that one so it lives on). It has a loud but not unpleasant buzz noise when operated.<br/><br />I have shaved with it 3 times now and love it :) Well done Panasonic/
  1782. Works great. I have used an electric razor for years and this one works just as well if not better than any other I have used. My last Panasonic lasted about 8 years so I figured i'd get another. So far, so good.

  1785. Good and fast shave. Easy cleanup, and it wasn't that noisy compared to my 20 year old Norelco HP1122 that died.<br />However, I researched shavers for at least 3-4 weeks trying to find a quality corded only powered non disposable shaver. I wanted to avoid having a battery that will fail no matter what and own a shaver that might last me 20-30 years if I took really good care of it.<br />I found one corded only powered shaver made by Norelco for about $30 but I was pretty sure that it was a piece of junk that wouldn't last but a couple years so what would be the point. Although many of the shavers I looked at, bought and took back stated they would work corded as well as cordless, they will not work without a functioning battery. So, I think that is false advertising to make one believe a shaver will work without a battery. It won't.<br /><br />In the end, I couldn't find one quality corded powered only shaver anywhere.<br />I am really astounded that all the shavers made now are basically disposable. How many shavers hit the landfills around the world every year with the toxic batteries still inside them?<br />It's amazing to me that we as a civilization are so aware of what kind resources are wasted by making such disposable products but yet we allow this to pass as OK. On top of that, what are the effects of all these toxic batteries going into our environment?<br />Why then with this knowledge do we allow these companies to get away with making and selling toxic disposable products?<br />At the very least the manufacturers should be mandated to take back the shavers they sell and remove the toxic battery. An added benefit to this would be that the manufacturer would be able to determine if the razor could be refurbished with a new battery and new parts then sold and used again.<br />How hard would that be?<br />Oh, I forgot profits first and the living planet and future generations last is our civilization's mantra.<br />All hail the mighty profit and dividend!<br />If you think this practice is unacceptable contact the company and or policymakers/lawmakers and tell them to fix it.<br />The Panasonic ES8103S seems to be the best shaver for the price (@$68), Consumer Reports rated them high too, plus allegedly you can take one to an authorized Panasonic repair shop and have them replace the battery. I assume though that this will cost one about as much as just buying a brand new shaver. However, at least you'll attain peace of mind knowing that your shaver and toxic battery didn't end up in the landfill.<br />All the best.<br />sw

For convenience and ease of memory I simply clean it every time it needs to be recharged (I don't leave it plugged in all the time).<br />Finally, I like how quietly this shave hums when it shaves.
  1790. I bought this based on the reviews from customers on the product. My experience was the razor does NOT give a close shave. I shaved with this once and by 10am (after a 6am shave) people were asking me if I forgot to shave.<br /><br />I would like to return this Panasonic for a refund!<br /><br />Buyers beware.
  1791. Great shave, very easy to clean without a complicated cleaner and solution - just soap and water
  1792. This shaver fulfills the task for me. I do not sport a heavy beard and simply dry shave<br /><br />I do recommend product to someone not wanting to spend large monies to get the task done. It's recharging capabilities are excellent and last every bit of the fourteen days.
  1793. The shaver delivers a close shave. It is easy to clean with just a little liquid soap and and water. This is important to me because I can't carry around one of those cleaning pods especially when traveling out of the country.
  1794. Having used Braun shavers for many years, I was looking for a good shaver with a lithium-ion battery so the shaving speed would remain the same from recharge through discharge. Consumer Reports rated this Panasonic shaver near the top of its ratings so I gave it a try, and so far, it is the best shaver I have ever used. The shaver is fast and has a meter indicating the percentage of battery charge remaining. The price of this shaver from Amazon.com is very good for a shaver with a lithium-ion battery. Update: I have stopped using this shaver as the battery will not retain a charge after only 3 years.
  1795. I think in this price range we know what we are getting - not the bottom of the barrel cheap electric shavers that don't stand up to the test of time, nor provide a good shave. We are also not geting the premium products that are very good but are quite more costly. We are getting something in between. I've had this shaver for almost 2 years now and have no major complaints. It gets the job done. Nothing spectacular.
  1796. I love this new shaver. It delivers the the best shave I have ever had with and electric shaver. It is pretty close to a razor shave without all the prep.<br />Works far better then my old Norelco shaver. Cleaning is very easy and charge last about 2 weeks.
  1797. I've been using this since July of 2012. It's now Feb. 2015. While you cannot use this when plugged in, the battery has lasted all this time, and holds a charge well. Works through my stubble so long as I don't let it get too scruffy. When I do get lazy, the sideburn trimmer works decently enough to cut through everything, but there's a trick to how you have to angle it. Don't go straight at it, but angle the blade a bit and take your time. Then use the foil head to finish everything off. The best part of this shaver is the cleaning. I've had Braun shavers for years with the cleaning bases, and having to buy the cleaning solution things all the time was really hurting my wallet. Those shavers are a waste. Get something like this that you can just clean off in the shower/sink.
  1798. The Panasonic ES8103s shaver works great. It gave me a clean shave usint the Dry application.( Have not tried the Wet).<br />I had purchased it as a replacement for my travel shaver. It size does not work that well for replaceing the one that I had.
  1799. I got 5 PERFECT years out of this unit. I purchased my Panasonic ES8103S right here on Amazon in January 2010 and it has worked excellent up until just yesterday February 19, 2015 when it suddenly stopped taking a charge. You do have to replace the outer foils and inner blades about once a year to keep getting a good smooth shave with no tugging and as of the time of this post you can buy the replacement foil/blade set - Panasonic WES9013PC - for about $34. Been very happy with it and like I said - it worked perfectly for 5 years, held charge well, charged fast, shaved great for cordless electric. I'm actually kind of surprised that it just suddenly stopped charging yesterday out of the blue. I've dropped it several times over the past 5 years but not recently. Whether you think 5 years is a good run or not is up to individual opinion. For me - for the price of the unit and yearly foil/blade replacement, it sure saved me a ton of money on traditional blades and has been a very convenient / quick part of my daily grooming, so I'm not too disappointed in the 5 year span I got from it.<br /><br />FACE / NECK SHAVING EXPERIENCE - I use this for dry shaving my face and neck with no pre-shave products, and it only took about a week for my skin to get used to it. During the first week of use I did get some minor irritation on my neck area under chin and around adam's apple, but after that it was smooth sailing. It gives a smooth shave as close as you can for an electric. Fast, light, and comfortable. Just be sure to replace the foil/blade every 12 months which you can get here on Amazon - kit Panasonic WES9013PC.<br /><br />TRIMMER EXPERIENCE - The trimmer on this Panasonic ES8103S is VERY small (but also very sharp) and in my experience easy to make a mistake with. I personally find the trimmer on this too small and awkward for trimming around my beard/mustache. I've resorted to buying a wider cordless trimmer with &#34;guides&#34; to use in addition to this. As a shaverthis unit is great, but for me personally the trimmer on it is placed in too awkward of a spot to trim with because the tiny trimmer sticks out of the side which makes it very hard to see exactly what I'm trimming with it.<br /><br />FOR BALD HEAD / SKULL SHAVING - I shave my head bald and and from my experience - it's great for face, but NOT so great for top of head / skull. Some reviewers here say it works good on their skull so I guess this is subjective to individual skin / hair types. If you want a good cordless shaver for both head and face, check out the Bald Eagle by Skull Shaver here on Amazon. While this Panasonic ES8103S gives a better face / neck shave under the chin, the Skull Shaver Bald Eagle does a better job for skull / entire head (especially for getting around ears and easily reaching around to do back of head and neck). If you do decide to get this Panasonic ES8103S and plan to use it on a bald head, then be prepared to by replacement foils/blades every 6 months because top of head stubble is tough and will dull the Panasonic ES8103S blades quickly.<br /><br />CHARGING and OTHER FEATURES - This thing charges FAST and held the charge well over past 5 years of daily use. The LED indicator is very easy to read and makes it very obvious how much charge you have left. I only have to charge it about once a week and the shave is great all the way down to 10% of battery charge. The unit is very lightweight and the rubber grip is comfortable to hold at all angles. The ability to lock the head or switch it to pivot mode comes in handy for different areas of neck and face. The buttons to pop the foil cover off and dump stubble / rinse the blades are easy to press and make your daily routine quick & simple!<br /><br />OVERALL - You can't go wrong with this shaver for fast dry close face/neck shave. It's reliable, portable, comfortable, high quality, and super easy to clean / super easy to replace the foil and blade. I will not hesitate to buy another and I definitely recommend it!

  1818. I've tried several shavers and s;pent a lot of money trying to find a decent shaver for my son. Even bought a $90 Braun Series 3. It worked for awhile but the mesh grill got holes in it after a year and having to pay $30 for the snap on head replacement is ridiculous. I researched on the internet and came across a website where the guy actually uses every shaver he reviews and writes a blog about his experience and makes videos of him shaving with each shaver.   1819. Been using the ES8103S for several months now and have had no problems so far. Purchased this to replace a 6 year old ES8077 shaver which was no longer giving close shaves even with a new cutting block and foil. It had also gotten really loud (more about that below). It did however still hold and deliver a full charge - very impressive compared to some Braun shavers I owned in the past.<br />I really liked the ES8077, and I still have one that I use as a backup (it's almost still new). I had a little concern going from a &#34;flat&#34; cutting head to a curved &#34;arc&#34; one. This has turned out to be a complete none issue for me (everyone's face is a little different so your mileage may vary). The battery in the ES8103S lasts just as long as my old ES8077, and the shaving results are similar compared to a new ES8077.<br />I have to comment about some reviewers saying this shaver is so loud that it hurts their hearing. Here is what I measured using an android sound meter app. Sure, it's not scientific but good enough for a quick apples-to-apples comparison. The new ES8103S measured at 52 dB, my almost new ES8077 measured at 54 dB, and my old, retired ES8077 measured at 75 dB. I guess when these things get old they get pretty mechanical loose and subsequently very noisy. I have fairly sensitive hearing, and I can say for certain that the ES8103S is not damaging my hearing.<br />All in all the ES8103S has turned out to be a good replacement for the ES8077. Will update this review if any problems develop.
  1820. good price~<br />good item~
  1821. Had the raiser now for more than 6 months, maybe a year? Will get another one once the battery dies on this one. Shaving with a Gillette every day and only use this one for some detail work under the nose, etc. Not good enough to use by itself, but that might just be me as I have that problem with every electric shaver.

  1824. Update Dec 2016: I've been using this razor for nearly 4 years. It still works well. I changed the blade and foil set together a few months ago. I think the battery life has fallen a bit. But everything works. LCD, trimmer etc. Compact and no fuss. I'm glad I didn't spend any more to get a fancier razor. I still recommend the razor. Original June 2013: I have always used a blade and shaving cream and I continue to use a Gillette Fusion razor. I needed a razor to keep in my laptop bag for those days one gets up too late for a proper shave. I researched a lot before picking up this razor. Ultimately I wanted something that was cheap to maintain (replacement blades/foils), comfortable and durable. The durability bit is still to be tested, but it is a comfortable razor to hold and it is not too noisy. Just to get the hang of it, I have been using it everyday and I get results as good as a razor and blade. That said, if I start with a couple of days of growth (say after a weekend), the razor takes some time to give good results. I have to go over some areas repeatedly to get desired results. Given the time it takes, one is better of using a plain razor and shaving cream. I would recommend it as a backup shaver. Will update this review after some time (Panasonic mentions 30 days) to see if extended beard growth can be handled more effectively.

  1827. I bought this Panasonic Wet/Dry electric razor last February 2013 to replace my tired Braun 5614 Wet/Dry. The price of replacement blades for the outdated Braun were as much as I paid for the new Panasonic, so no contest.<br /><br />The Panasonic gives me a much closer shave than the old Braun was capable of and I am now a fan of the Panasonic brand. However there is a downside and therefore a good reason for not giving this unit a 5 star rating. As much as I have come to appreciate this particular razor, it appears that the small digital LCD-info display has given up the ghost; that is to say that the display has become unreadable and therefore unusable after just nine months of service. This is somewhat of a disappointment as the razor continues to deliver a close shave and is otherwise a fine product. But that is what these reviews are for, full disclosure to help other potential consumers make an informed choice.<br /><br />UPDATE; XMAS day 2013: This is a follow-up to my original 4-star review as shown above. This unit just died today and is now completely unusable. I have not been hard on this razor, using it on average every other day. A few weeks ago the LCD display started acting up and became unreadable; however this did not seem to affect the shaver function, so I continued to use it thinking it would become my travel razor. Then a couple of days ago I went to use it and it was completely dead. I was able to use it plugged in (which I'm not sure it's suppose to do?), but worked. I then left it to fully charge and later noticed with the bath lights out that the LCD was blinking/flashing and would not stop. This morning when I went to use it was completely dead, so I tried the plug-in routine again and that did not work-nada, nothing, dead! I would be very hesitant to buy another Panasonic w/LCD display or otherwise and must face Xmas day with stubble. Any suggestions for a replacement wet/dry shaver would be welcome.

The battery lasts quite a while, as well.<br /><br />This also recharges pretty quickly.<br /><br />I have used this both wet and dry. It works well dry. It also works well with shaving cream. Cleaning is easy.
  1881. I've used electric shavers for decades and this is the first that didn't have the option to run off of household current. I was a little hesitant to rely solely on a rechargeable battery but this Panasonic works as advertised. I charge it about once each week and rinse it under the hot water faucet about twice a week for the past two years. I would give it 5 stars but I have yet to own an electric shaver that didn't require two passes over my heavy beard to get all the stubble. Still much more convenient then a safety razor.
  1882. I don't use it in the shower but it is nice being able to wash it off and wet it to shave with. Makes shaving my neck easy too, something I would never have done with my Norelco.
  1883. I hate shaving but unfortunately I am part bear so I need to everyday if I want to avoid looking like a hobo. The reason I hate shaving with a regular blade is it takes so long and I cut myself 95% of the time. When I received this razor for Christmas I was very excited to alleviate these problems. Now instead of cutting my face it becomes irritated causing my neck to break out. It does a terrible job on my neck no matter how many times I go over it. The only real benefits of this razor are it makes less of a mess than regular shaving and can give a decent shave quickly in the morning. A good shave can take a very long time and even then with my neck I'd need to use a regular razor to truly remove the hair. I clean it more than needed to try to improve performance and go slowly but neither of those show much improvement. A huge disappointment that's not worth the price for the slight convenience.
  1884. He absolutely loves it and uses it everyday. It really does give a nice close shave! I highly recommend it!
  1885. I ordered this because I was sick of buying shavers for my Gillette. The cost for a 12 pack was about the same for this, so I figured it was worth a try. The reviews mainly swayed my purchase. I've been using this for a few weeks now, and I have to say it gets a little getting use to. I love the features this has, like the light up LCD screen that shows the battery level and when it's time to rinse the blades clean. It also has a trimmer that folds out for precision trimming. It is a wet/dry razor, which is nice if you like to change it up once in a while. I use it for dry shaving only. At first it felt funny and I could feel a little bit of a pull when running across my skin. It did however get pretty darn close to the skin which I was surprised with. The head can be switched to stay in place, or move with you as you shave which I found leaving it in the moving position gave me a closer shave. I have noticed a considerable decrease in razor burn which I am super grateful for, however the first 2 shaves I noticed my skin had to &#34;get used&#34; to the switch. I mean that I had a few bumps, primarily by the throat area, but on my cheeks & chin the shave was great. Once thing I would like to note though is when dry shaving, I noticed that my skin became a lot dryer while shaving. I just threw on some lotion afterwards and I was good to go! Overall it did a great job, however it had a tougher time on the neck. I learned that shaving towards the hair on the neck seems to get the closest shave though. I think you just need to experiment in different directions until you get the right one for each section of your face. I use up & down on the jaw line, mouth and chin. And I use a diagonal back & forth for the neck and throat areas. I will probably never go back to shaving cream and a blade after this because its so easy, quick and the clean up is SO easy. Just empty the hair clippings, and rinse the blade under running water and it's done.
  1886. Among Shavers I bought, this is best.<br />Low price drive me happy.<br />..<br />.<br />.<br />.<br />.<br />.<br />.<br />.
  1887. I've been using the Panasonic ES8249 for about one year. It's a marvelous shaver deserving the highest rating.   1897. I have used electric razors for more than 25 years. I have a dense course beard and sensitive skin and found that using an electric foil razor gave me the closest shave with the least irritation. Prior to this purchase I have exclusively used Braun razors. After my latest Braun's battery ceased holding a charge I decided to look at other companies products. I found this Panasonic highly rated and at a good price. I decided to take a chance and bought this ES 8103s. I have now used the razor for almost six months.<br />I have been very pleasantly surprised. This razor has exceeded my expectations. I am getting the closest most comfortable shave of my lifetime. Minimal irritation and no cuts. By the way, I highly recommend using Afta pre-electric shave lotion if you shave &#34;dry&#34;. This razor shaves both wet or dry. I have not tried shaving in the shower or with a shaving cream. As a &#34;wet&#34; razor I clean it with liquid soap and rinse it under running water in the sink. No need to pay for more expensive razors and their cleaning systems.<br />All is not perfect. The razor did not come with a travel case. The hair trimmer is mounted on the rear of the razor and as other reviewers have noted this limits the users ability to clearly visualize where the trimmer will cut. I consider both of these as minor complaints for a razor that superbly performs it's primary function.
  1898. I purchased this for my husband for Christmas. He loves, loves it. Very close shave without the nicks and burns! Our son tried it, and guess what, I had to order him one too! Holds a charge for 6 to 7 shaves and is very lightweight. The Amazon price was AWESOME!!

When I first turned it on the display showed 10% charged so I charged it and a half hour later it still showed 10%. I ran the battery down until it was 0% and charged it again and it charged to 100%. I don't have a heavy beard and shave about every 2 or 3 days. The instructions say to use it for 30 days to see best results. It gives me a good shave so far.   1925. Like pushing a steel garden rake thru a Berber carpet.<br />I'm a long time Amazon and Panasonic shaver customer and I've never been so disappointed in a brand name appliance.<br />No wonder they ask you to try these things out for a month to adjust to your beard.....because most retailers only give you a month to return these things back to them for a full refund. Time's up, you own it.<br />This review is based on 3 Panasonic shavers in relation to this current product:<br /><br />The ES-SA40:<br />PROS:<br />Real smooth and close shave that was a cheap and light weight work horse.<br />CONS:<br />Noisy, single blade, heavy vibrate, 8 hour charge and most of all.......no good for two day old shaves. This unit can't cut long hairs like your tri-blade shavers can.<br /><br />The ES-8018:<br />PROS:<br />Comfortable, linear tri-blade that shaves close with shorter charging periods.<br />CONS:<br />Heavy to hold and use. The trimmer broke off for no apparent reason as it wasn't abused.<br /><br />The now ES-8103S:<br />PROS:<br />Light weight, linear tri-blade that's relatively quiet and charges in about an hour.<br />CONS:<br />Like pushing a steel garden rake thru a Berber carpet.<br />I found this shaver painful, particularly in the mustache area when using pre-shave lotion or not.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />I personally believe that style had priority over performance with this unit.<br />After using this shaver, mainly for long hairs, I still use my ES-SA40 for a once over to pick up all the missing stubbles that the ES-8013S left behind.<br />\\"Oh, you'll get there with this ES-8103S.....it's just that you'll feel every irritating scrape/jerk/bump along the way.\\"<br />I'll be moving to a Braun for my next shaver.

Since it was still under warranty, I sent it back to Panasonic for repair or replacement. They sent me a replacement. In less than a year, the display on the replacement also began to fail, so I could no longer determine the state of charge. On a positive note, I still have this shaver and it shaves very well. But the unreliable display is a serious inconvenience, and is clearly a problem with this model.

  1948. With almost 1400 reviews of this venerable old-timer already posted on Amazon, there isn't much I can add. However, the fact that it constantly runs neck-and-neck with Braun's 790cc as the number one seller of foil shavers at Amazon tells me there are two types of electric shaver buyers out there; those who are prepared to lay out the big bucks for what is often heralded as the best shaver money can buy (it isn't) and another group who think that about $80 is the proper amount to pay for such an item. Having owned and used both and many others, I'm starting to think the latter group has it right.(As an aside, this model has been replaced by the LT41-K, which is currently selling here on Amazon for only $6 more than the 8103S. The only difference between the two is that the newer model has a travel lock switch like most Pannys. It's also a little sleeker-looking and dressed in black instead of silver.)<br /><br />I really like this shaver. It looks good, feels good in the hand, has good ergonomics and doesn't feel cheap at all. Most important, it shaves<br />very well and gets almost as close as any of the more expensive models,<br />Panasonic or otherwise. In fact it shaves closer than some I've tried. The battery holds a charge well and it self-cleans easily with the sonic-vibration mode.<br /><br />All in all, I think this shaver is a steal--but if I were buying today I'd get the updated LT41-K.

  1962. Bought this on a whim and wow am I glad. Over the years I've used the Mach 3, Hydro 3, Edwin Jagger safety with a variation of razors, but have never tried an electric thinking they were just a shortcut and would shave like one. Now after using this for a week, I don't think I'll ever be going back to non-electrics. I don't have a lot of facial hair, I'm in my mid 20s and it's still coming in, but the closest shaves I've had -- with the safety razor after doing numerous passes in various directions spending like 20 minutes over a sink with shaving cream everywhere -- can't hold a candle to this. The razors always left my skin a bit raw and the prep work felt like a choir. Even with a good shave, when I would run my hand against the grain, I could feel the stubble. The very first shave I did with this unit, it took me a couple of minutes dry and my face was smooth in any direction, I couldn't believe it. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone. It's fairly easy to clean, the battery lasts about 5 shaves, and so far I haven't nicked myself or had any irritation. The best way to shave with it is to use it every other day at most. If you let the beard grow any longer than that, this shaver will start missing hairs and require more passes. I tried a wet shave with it but unfortunately I didn't care for it, it was still better than any other razor, but the dry shave is just superb.
  1963. Sturdy Construction, packaged well, works better than any Razor I've ever purchased. The price was under $90 with shipping. I do not normally purchase Panasonic items, however the previous reviews and cost convinced me to try this. I only wish I'd purchased two.

  1967. I can not speak to the long lasting effects of the razor and I will follow up after I've had it for awhile. I own the Panasonic Body Groom and thought I would stay in the same family of razors. I straight-blade my face. However, I wanted this for my head. I have moles on my head that a straight blade opens up and they bleed horrible. I usually need a trained medical staff to stop the bleeding and a couple units of blood before it's all done. So as I bald, I don't want to hang on to any amount of my hair. I like the way I look bald and allowing it to grow makes people think I want to keep it or I'm \\"holding on\\". I am not. I pulled this out of the box, charged it for one hour, and then went to it. It worked WONDERFUL! I would say as close to blade close as humanly possible with an electric razor. I have used Norelco products, but only on my face. I did not use this razor wet and I'm still out on whether or not to do that. I have the face soap that I use with my straight blade and I may give that a try. However, dry, it worked great. It was quick and easy. Clean-up was a snap. I missed on spot on the back shaving without a mirror. I was able to kinda go all around after I thought I had gotten it all and it caused no irritation. I usually get irritation on my head and face from electric razors. For the head this baby is perfect! I did use it on my face and like all electric razors that I have desperately tried to like, it fell short. But it was better than any other I have used. It will work in a pinch in the morning, if I forget to shave the night before. My biggest issue with my face is the neck area! This just is an area that in order to get every hair I have to go over and over my neck and pretty soon it gets red and irritated. I didn't go over and over, but it shaved that area the best of any electric razor I've ever seen.<br /><br />But for what I want...this is perfect. Great for the HEAD!!
  1968. Wonderful gift, easy to use, great price and easy to put together and keep clean. Has a great wet to dry option. Over all my man loves it.
  1969. This razor is so much better than my old piece of crap Remington triple head razor its not funny. The Panasonic gives a very close,quick (2 minutes if I shave daily) irritation free shave and so far I'm getting 10 shaves a charge. I've twice tortured test the Panasonic by going 5 days between shaves. The old Remington I would 1st have to charge for 15 minutes (did not hold a charge with beans) then use my Philips Norelco Bodygroom Shaver to make the whiskers short enough for the Remington to cut or else it would just skate over the top of my beard about after 15 minutes of shaving and loads of razor burn I'd be done. The Panasonic razor no problem in 5 minutes my 5 day beard is gone with a almost razor close shave with zero irritation. This razor is so much better than my old Remington I honestly regret not replacing that piece of trash a year go and at 70.00 this razor is a steal. Just get it the Panasonic is 5 star product. BTW its nice to just wash it after every shave there no need of the more expensive models with their pricey washing systems and I can use it in the shower too (rarely) also I find I get the best shave by locking the razor head so it doesn't pivot side to side. Its just freaking amazing how this is the best razor I've owned and I've used electric razors over thirty years,
  1970. i had an older model of this razor, which i bought a few years ago, and it suddenly stopped working one day (it hums with no blade movement). took a few years to break, but i was disappointed, as i really enjoyed the product. i don't enjoy shaving with a blade because it irritates my skin, especially under the jawline. the Panasonic was a very acceptable alternative, not quite as close as a wet shave, but very comfortable and way, way better than a Braun i received as a gift before that. battery lasted forever, and it worked wet and dry.<br /><br />anyway, this newer model is about the same in terms of shave quality. however, it is much lighter and thus feels a bit cheaper; not saying that's the case, but we'll see how long this one lasts. my only real complaint is with the trimmer. the previous trimmer was as about as wide as the head of the razor, and slid up to use. it was awesome for buzzing down facial hair - i often don't shave clean but just do the stubbly look, and the very wide trimmer made that easy. this model has a ridiculous flip-up trimmer that is only about as wide as your sideburns. i suppose it would be ok at trimming that, but it's much more difficult to use for buzzing your whole face, and because it flips up instead of sliding up, you have to prop it up with your thumb to really use it.<br /><br />the overall impression i got was of a cheaper build. but really, something being lighter is not necessarily indicative of lower quality and might be a good thing to you, i personally enjoy a certain heft. the actual shaver head is basically identical, and works great - thus the 4 stars. battery life seems about the same, as does wet performance. really wish they had just left the trimmer alone. if i could find the older one, i'd definitely buy that instead. this is a perfectly reasonable product and price, however.
  1971. I have very sensitive skin and very coarse hair. Not a great combo. So I naturally turned my back on electric shavers long ago as I figured if I couldn't get a close enough shave with a razor then how on earth would i get one with an electric... Well I was wrong. After running the gauntlet of razors with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 freaking blades and messing with various shaving creams I finally decided to give this a try. And I'm extremely happy with the way things turned out. Basically now all I have to do is shave with this thing in the shower every day for a minute or two and I get very close to the same smoothness I received before MINUS the razor burn, irritation, and ingrown hairs. This razor is extremely easy to clean and use too! And Panasonic really seems to have hit a home run at balancing the size for this shaver. It's just big enough that you don't have to go over too much ground, and yet it's small enough to comfortably maneuver around the cut of your chin and under your mustache. Best of all, this ins't even that expensive in the realm of electric shavers!
  1972. Smooth shaves with little heating and face soreness. Does not pull hairs as easily as other razors I have used.
  1973. Love this razor...it works well, with minimum effort. I have sensitive skin and it leaves less rash then a high end Gillette 4 blade razor did...The charge lasts for about a weeks worth of shaves ( once a day) and charges quickly ( an hour or 2 tops)<br />Ive used it in the hower with no issues, though I prefer the dry shave as opposed to wet with this razor..I seem to get a better shave. It does shave really close...In my experience with electric razors, none of them shave as close as a blade, none of them!!<br />a few have come close, but only after dragging it over my face repeatedly while pressing hard, the resulting rash made this pointless...that said this razor does shave really close with just a couple few passes, and I do have coarse hair of facial hair, with an average amount
  1974. Fantastic electric shaver! Took my skin a couple of weeks to completely get used to it, but after that it was smooth sailing. I've been using it daily for 2 weeks now and the battery still shows 50%. I however, only have upper-lip and chin hair, so it only takes ~2 minutes per shave. I wasn't expecting this much battery life after reading some reviews saying it lasts about 3-5 shaves. I guess it depends on how long your shaves are really.
  1975. i am only 15 but recently, my facial hair started to grow like crazy. My dad had shown me how to use a regular razor. I didn't mind the shave but still i wanted to see how my skin would react to an electric razor. it would be cheaper to use an electric razor. i was told the the shave is never as good as i can get with a regular razor but i still gave it a try...<br />about the battery... the papers that came with it say that a 100% charge is the same as 14 shaves at 3 minutes each... the grip is nicely made and the head can be locked so it doesn't move or unlocked...<br />the seller i got the razor from sent it with a little travel baggie... the shaver can be used wet or dry and the screen shows how much battery is left...<br />the shave is not as good as a regular razor but i dont mind this one...<br />i think its a keeper... but keep in mind... ive only shaved with it a few times....
