  1977. This one is especially easy to clean (can use hand soap even). Like most electrics, it definitely gives a better shave on me when not in the shower (does work if that's what you are in to). Shave is close and I have had no problems with irritation at all. Way to go Panasonic!
  1978. I hate when somebody loosely applies a title like &#34;diva&#34; or &#34;phenom&#34; to any product. But this is the best razor, bladed or electric that I've used...phenomenal.
  1979. At the beggining when i first used it, i was a little shocked because it cut my skin in my neck area, but it was because I press it too hard against my skin, and it needs to get use to it before I do that, so after that i continued using it and till now is working and doing its job just fine.
  1980. I have used a Braun razor for 10+ years, but am tired of how long it takes to shave. I have tried several Norelcos, but they seem to snag my hair after about a month of use. So, I read some reviews on consumer reports, and took a chance with this one. Excellent shave + excellent timing! I highly recommend it!
  1981. I got this for my 21 year old son. He recently got a great job that required him to be clean shaven every day. Up till now he has had a very nicely manicured beard, which he just used a trimmer on. He loves this razor. He is very happy with the closeness of the shave and has only needed to use it dry. I told him the reviews said a wet shave will be a closer shave, but he said he is perfectly happy with the dry shave. I am glad I went with this razor.
  1982. Used a couple of Norelco shavers for years and was happy, but this shaver gives a much closer shave. It also runs a top speed, even with just 10% left in charge.
  1983. I used this for about 60 days and the foil screen tore. I checked the price of a new one and it was almost the same as a new razor. I threw it in the garbage.
  1984. This was purchased for a picky shaver and he loves the smoothness this product delivers. It works great as a wet or dry shaver.
  1985. I replaced a Panasonic ES8092 that lasted over 15 years. And I'm hoping to get the same from this one. By the way, I left it on the charger 24/7 and never had a problem with staying charged long enough to shave my head and my beard.<br /><br />I have read reviews stating that there are other shavers out there that are better. For a much higher cost mind you. And this is more of a backup/last minute device as I usually use a [[ASIN:B000NL0T1G Merkur Model 180 Long Handled Safety Razor]]. I purchased this one because of the longevity of my last one and expecting this new razor to be as good as my old one.<br /><br />Just FYI, I do not have a tough beard and only need to shave every other day or more.<br /><br />Here are the facts:<br />1. This new razor is 5db more quiet than my old one. And THAT is a significant difference.<br />2. It's lighter in weight.<br />3. Replacement blades for the new razer are cheaper than my old razer.<br />4. Used in conjunction with [[ASIN:B0038JKYAQ Kyoku for Men Electric Pre Shave Optimizer, 1.7 Fluid Ounce]] I got a shave pretty much equal to what I get with my double edge safety razor!<br />5. I am aware the new razor has new foil and blade but my old razor with new foil and blades never got this close.<br />6. In the last 6 months it's sold here twice for less than $55.00, yes you read that right. And it's still worth it in the $70.00 range.
  1986. It holds a charge for days and delivers a really close shave wet or dry. I could not be happier with this purchase.
  1987. I used Consumer Reports to select a replacement for my current working razor. The Panasonic gives me a closer shave although the sideburn trimmer is a little smaller. In part the closer shave is because the shaver head pivots to the contour of one's face.<br /><br />If one likes a foil shaver, then this is the one to buy.
  1988. I totally love this razor I can't say enough about it it does exactly what it says it can do.
  1989. Terrible shaver and foil. It's the worst shaver I've ever owned over the past 36 years, especially compared to the Braun shavers I owned before Gillette bought them out, jacked up prices and added Chinese parts. Even after replacing the foil three times the blades continue to hit the new foil and in the past they quickly broke through and resulted in cutting my face. The trimmer is poor and extremely abrasive. The battery doesn't have a long charge. This a low quality and unreliable product from China, which is obviously the source of the problems. I've got to try something else.
  1990. Shaves very tight and I don't have to go over the same spots more than twice. I love how it's waterproof and I can shave in the shower and clean it under water.
  1991. After thoroughly evaluating many reviews here and elsewhere, I picked this Shaver out for a Christmas gift my wife could put under the tree for me. My now 5 year old Braun 9565 was beginning to fall apart and was always very loud. I'd replaced the blade/foil assy annually at $35.00-40.00 each and it was time. I was initially impressed with this Panasonic ES8103S for its low price and very good reviews. My wife ordered it on Amazon and I received it at Christmas.<br /><br />Right away I was happy with the fact that it was perhaps half as loud as the Braun was, and had a much more tolerable tone. I try to maintain things so they tend to last longer, which means in most cases I take the head apart and brush clean all the blades and foils. Again, when disassembling for the first time I was impressed with the simplicity of the design and the ease of cleaning and reassembly. Much easier than my Braun.<br /><br />I wish I could stop there and say this Shaver lives up to its other reviews, but it simply doesn't shave close enough and requires many passes over the same area to get an acceptable cut. But even then, it seems to cut exactly at the surface and seemingly lacks the \\"lift and pull\\" technology in use by almost every other manufacturer, which cuts the whisker below the surface. This simple and rather old tech gives you a shave that for an average growth person such as myself, will still look decent going out after a day at the office. With the Panasonic ES8103S, I'm back to the Flintstone's days of the old 5:00 shadow, only it's apparent by 3pm. No getting away with skipping a day now and then like I could do with my Braun.<br /><br />I can't determine whether I maybe got a defective unit or not, but I'm back looking at Shavers again as I'll be sending this one back for a refund. Too bad, it really seemed like a bargain based on its reviews.
  1992. This is a great linear electric razor for the money! It recharges fully in a matter of 45 minutes. Great buy!
  1993. Came quickly and works great. Smoother shave than the less expensive model I had been using. I would definitely recomment it.
  1994. This shaver is powerful and gives an excellent, close shave. The power monitor is helpful, and it is very easy to clean under running water. From my perspective it's certainly much better than rotaries I've owned, and my only small complaint is that it seems to need recharging a little more frequently than some others. I generally need to recharge every 10 days vs. 14 days with my old Norelco.
  1995. Pathetic. This was bought as a replacement for a solidly-built Panasonic which gave 10 years of service, but the new razor, unlike the one it replaces, has such a weak motor that I thought it was some kind of mislabeled toy.
  1996. The cutting area is too small so it takes a long time to shave. I had to re shave the same spot over and over to get a smooth shave. It did seem to work better in the water with shaving cream but it still took a long time. The foil got a hole in it only after 3 weeks. Could have bought 2 cheaper shavers that work just as well for the same price.
  1997. Having used electric shavers for 40 years, this is the smoothest, most comfortable and clean shaving shaver. This is the finest one I've ever owned.<br />I would recommend this to all my friends.<br />It is far better than my many Brauns, Norelcos, erc.
  1998. This shaver is a big improvement over my old electric shaver. Gives a quick and close shave. Easy to clean. Can use wet or dry. Good battery life.
  1999. I replaced a 3 year old philips rotary shaver with this model. It shaves much closer and is not much louder. The sideburn trimmer works really well compared to my old unit. The battery lasts about 8 days before needing to be recharged which is less than the 2 weeks with the older philips model. Agree with other reviewer it would be nice to have a stand so it is not lying in a puddle on the sink to dry. The cost of the new Panasonic shaver was just a few dollars more than the replacement head for my old Philips so that is why I bought it and I am glad I did.
  2000. So far so good. Faster and closer than Norelco and an older Braun. Only time will tell but I do not , at this time see any real faults.
  2001. this is the best shaver i ever got, this helps me shave around aera that i can not get to.<br />I have no bad points about this iteam<br /><br />all i am very happy with it.
  2002. It looks nice, works great, and I've had it for a while and still haven't had to recharge the battery.
  2003. I've had numerous other shavers, but I have not had a closer shave with any of the shavers. It's much quieter does not vibrate, and charges quickly. Will definitely buy another.
  2004. I choose the product due to the RPM. I was tired of cheaper, lower RPM electric razors pulling on my skin when shaving. I was also intrigued by the wet / dry feature.<br /><br />When I first got the product, I would have rated it a 4.8 out of 5. I got a closer shave with this razor than I have ever had with an electric and it charged quickly. The only negative is with this type of open face razor, you need to be bending over a sink because it does not capture all the shaved hair (be careful if wearing a shirt) so its a little messy.<br /><br />My disappointment came about two weeks after initial use. I used every other day due to its initial effectiveness. Then I started to notice in the second week that I could go over the same spot and miss hair repeatedly and not getting nearly as close of a shave anymore (req'd shaving daily).<br /><br />So I cleaned it (more thoroughly than just empting the captured hair), I tried unlocking the pivot head and shaving, shaving right after hot shower, razor fully charged, different angles to shave the hair, etc. Nothing helped. Its just an average razor in two weeks time. I am very disappointed, especially for the price.<br /><br />No report on the wet / dry feature, I have yet to try it. Good luck.
  2005. I have used this razor for approximately three months. It has exceeded my expectations! Dry shaving with the Panasonic ES8103S gives me a &#34;safety-razor-like&#34; smooth shave. It is recommended by Consumer Reports. Very reasonably priced on Amazon. I recharge it once-a-week.
  2006. works ok, not so good on neck. needs several passes on face.
  2007. Bought to replace a 15 year old Panasonic that still functions but won't hold a charge. This model is made in China, not Japan like earlier models. Still, it shaves well overall and is quiet. Percent charge remaining is nice as is the sonic setting used for cleaning. Battery life is good and it charges in an hour. Would have been nice to include some type of stand to use while charging (my old mode charged inductively). Only negative is the pop up trimmer. Because it is perpendicular to the shaving head, it can be hard to see what you're doing. Also, the rounded head shape itself can make it difficult if you need to shave very precisely. Satisfied overall for the money, but I don't think the Panasonic shavers areas good as they used to be. A little too much style over function.
  2008. Chose this over rotary razor. Shaves my head well.
  2009.   2010.   2016. After using Norelco rotary razors for more than 30 years, I decided to try something different when replacement time arrived this time. I considered several razors, but selected the Panasonic ES8103S -- and I am delighted that I did.<br /><br />After giving it an initial charge, which only required an hour, I tried using it. I prefer a dry shave and used it in that fashion. After a moment or two of getting accustomed to the different grip and different shaving motion required, I found that it was both comfortable and highly effective. The Norelco razors always gave a decent shave, but this Panasonic comes extremely close to the results obtainable with a blade. I have never experienced as close a shave with any previous electric razor.<br /><br />I'm extremely pleased and would recommend this razor to anyone.

It shaves fast, close, and comfortable, almost like a blade shave, and has an LCD displays that always gives &#34;percentage remaining&#34; for the battery.   2020. The shave is terrible especially for shaving the hairs under the jaw line and on the neck. It doesn't get the hairs within any contours and even the hair on flat surfaces where the skin can be stretched the shaver requires many passes. Despite passing over some areas multiple times it doesn't even touch the hairs. Even if you do get all of the hairs it absolutely destroys my skin even after the 30 days it suggests you take to get used to it. Past the 30 days of use it makes my skin raw, red, and painful. It requires all kinds of lotions and creams and after shave balms just to feel fine and hopefully get rid of the redness. Shaving also now takes like double or triple the time it used to. I just spend it going up and down and side to side over the same areas with little to no progress beyond the first sweep.<br /><br />I don't know much about other electric razors but this was my first and will be my last. I'd rather just buy the blades, get it done right the first time without red, raw, painful skin, and a short shave that is successful the very first time.
  2021. Now, at fifteen months, the razor is completely dead, and will not even turn on after a full charge.<br /><br />I had grown frustrated with Norleco wet/dry shavers, and had high hopes for this one, but this breakdown is totally unacceptable.

  2031. After reading dozens of reviews about each of the electric shavers under $100 (and some over) I decided to give this one a chance. I'll update if that changes over time<br />No issues of redness or difficulty adjusting at least for me.<br /><br />Cons<br /><br />The noise! I know people mentioned that it was loud, but this high pitched buzz is difficult to muffle in the morning<br /><br />For anyone looking to upgrade their electric razor, as I was, this was a great choice.<br /><br />Update 1/10/13: Battery life still seems to be holding up (couple of hours with each charge) and the razor is still cutting the same. I'm sure I will have to replace the blades soon, but for now they are still getting the job done. But that buzzing is still loud...

  2038. I've had electric shavers before, but this one is by far the best. Things have definately changed in the electric world. Was tired of cutting my face up with regular razor, so figured even if it wasn't a great shave, I'd try one of the newer model electrics out there. LOVE being able to use this in the shower - just soap up and shave. VERY close shave and pivoting head makes it a snap. Unexpected benefit is that since I'm not running a blade agains my skin any more, my skin is much smoother than with the razor. Shaving with a razor blade is a thing of the past - time to move on!<br /><br />All these machines claim like two weeks between charges - can't imagine where they get that concept, I get like five shaves between charges. But, charges up within an hour, so no big deal.
  2039. I've only owned it 6 weeks or so, but so far it's the best, closest shaving electric razor I've ever owned--and I'm 70 years old. If you're new to electric razors, give it a few weeks for your facial skin to become accustomed to it. Also, I purchased a shaving gel which really helps the razor shave closer. With the razor/gel combo my shaves are as good as a blade. I've never been able to say that about an electric shaver before.
  2040. i bought it as a present for my husband .this shaver made in CHINA. ONCE i switched it i was shocked by its noisy.dispointed ,my husband also dislike it,too noisy
  2041. I love this razor, it is my every day (or two) go to shaving mechanism. The battery is great. The shave is great. Easy to clean. The only problem I have is that the plastic cover on top is pretty fragile, and if you drop it 4 or 5 feet, you better be praying that murphy's law doesn't land it on that spot that makes it crack and break. Having said that, I am on my second razor of the exact same kind and would not trade it for anything. Just be careful with the piece that comes off when you want to clean it.
  2042. I have found the Panasonic Razor to be fast charging, quiet, reliable, and easy to clean after shaving. I would buy another one of these high quality shavers.
  2043. Of course it will not get you the &#34;smooth&#34; shave that a straight edge will give you but it gets the job done.<br /> It is fairly quiet, easy to clean.
  2044. pretty sooth shave. it took a few weeks to 2 months for my face to get used to it. does not snag and pull like rotary blades. cleans very easy. its not as loud as my panasonic rotary shaver. i have shaved wet with shaving cream and dry. trimmer works well. the charge lasts forever for me... overall well worth the cost and a great product.
  2045. After trying several different electric razors, I finally found one that actually works and works well. No issues at all.
  2046. Well worth the cost. A very smooth shavers.
  2047. Shaves well and is very quiet. I bought one for every member of our household and they agree. I would definitely recommend this razor.
  2048. Gave this to husband for gift and he is really enjoying it. He says it is a bit of a trick to shave the chin and neck but he's getting the hang of it. I like it because his early morning shaves are quiet!
  2049. What an outstanding shaver!!! I was using a Safety Razor with Feather blades and was very happy for some time but my disabilities/age began to make it difficult to stand erect at the sink for the time it took. I just couldn't shave the same way I used to. I suspected an electric would help. Before I ordered the Panasonic though, I pulled out an old ( but still in fine shape) Norelco/Phillips triple head that I used to use. I stopped using it some time ago due to the difficulty with my sensitive skin--particularly on my neck. Lots of red marks. I read recently where a foil was easier on the skin. Not only has the Panasonic not left mark one on me, the closeness of the shave is very, very similar to the safety razor. Just depends on the time you spend. Bottom line, I can lean over on my elbows or sit down when I get tired. Shaves just as well. No fooling around with blades, shave cream, sink full of water, etc. What a fine shave and under $80.00! I recommend this with no hesitation !!!! Three week later update-----still no skin irritation at all. I am taking my time while shaving and have to say I am now getting just as close a shave as I did with my safety razor and Feather blades. No problem going against the grain. Just making sure to use a light touch and a little extra time. Amazing!!!!!
  2050. I don't have a flat face, & I typically shave every 2 or 3 days. The razor is pretty far from anything I'd recommend.<br /><br />STRIKE 1: It takes 15-20 passes on my neck to get anywhere near done. Wet, dry, angle, sweet-talk ... doesn't matter. I end up using a disposable razor to get the hairs the Panasonic missed, after wearing the battery & my face down by 30% just trying to get the last few hairs. It works a little better with daily use but still not good.<br /><br />STRIKE 2: If you have areas where you let the hair grow (goatee, mutton chops etc), the razor pulls the longer hairs when you try to shave near them. It hurts.<br /><br />STRIKE 3: It's loud. Except in SonicClean mode, which I'm not convinced really does much. Can the cheap plastic vibration link really transmit sufficient ultrasonic energy through to the razor head to the point where it actually cleans, rather than just buzzing weakly? I'm not so sure. Can some ultrasonic engineering theorist-types weigh in on this?
  2051. Nice product. Does not shave as close as a blade.
  2052. I like this razor as a quick get up and go shaver. I have yet to use it wet due to reviews I've read of the display shorting out. but if you catch it on a good sale I wouldn't hesitate to buy it
  2053. I'm a head shaver, and frequently use this for a daily shaver. When I'm not being lazy and make time to share every day, this is a lot quicker than a razor because I can shave my entire face, clean it, half my head, clean it, and then finish up, whereas a bladed razor needs to be cleaned after every stroke.<br /><br />The clippers on this, however, are completely awful. Too slow and not sharp at all. They feel more like tweezers or a band-aid than clippers. If I let my hair, beard, and mustache grow out for a week, I need to use my Philips Norelco G370 All-in-1 Grooming System to trim back down to an easily shavable length.
  2054. This shaver does a good shave but not as good as an older Panasonic I have had for many years. The battery in this one is small and doesn't last long.   2062. I've been using electric shavers for probably 40 years, and I've tried most brands. Overall, I'm a Remington man. The Remingtons do the best job shaving my fairly heavy beard, and their trimmers are nice and wide for a bit of a trim around the ears. Unfortunately, my favorite model is out of production, so I tried Panasonic for the first time.<br /><br />What I like about this razor is that it's really quiet and the battery lasts a long time on a single charge. Unfortunately, it doesn't do that great a job shaving my face, especially the long hairs on my neck and those high on my cheeks. I use a disposable razor to clean up what the Panasonic misses.
  2063. I've had this shaver for something like 2-3 months now. It replaced an older Braun that I was finding more difficulty getting replacement blades/foil for (tells you how long I had it around). The Panasonic cuts well. It is extremely light and ergonomically sets well in my hand. The rapid charge is a pleasant change from my old shaver that took all night. Cleaning is a snap-just rinse under a sink.<br />Downsides; the beard/moustache trim feature is all but useless in its location. They engineered this to fit along the back of the shaver and is tiny. When engaged, it is not readily visible making any trim work blind. I can't see what I'm cutting....not good. I've since purchased a separate trim shaver adding to the clutter of my bathroom closet. Minor annoyance is the sound it produces; a high pitched whine similar to a lawn trimmer. All things considered a reasonable basic shaver that performs the basic function of removing whiskers well. As a trimmer, well, what may sound like one is not always one....
  2064. The shaver is good for a morning or evening touch ups but doesn't get as close as a razor especially on the neck area.

It works very well and quite fast and I believe it to be of professional quality. I find that it works the best when my beard is no more than one day old although it will handle longer stubble. I personally don't think it is as good as a wet shave but it is perfectly acceptable. Overall I am quite happy with it and would certainly buy it again. I have had it about a year with no issues and find the battery to be excellent.

  2075. This is the 3rd Panny shaver I've bought in the last 10 yrs. They do a good job of shaving close to the skin. BUT... be careful if you have any moles or bumps on your skin. This shaver can cut you. The high speed cutting action is that fast it can burn you, I've done it once or twice over the yrs.<br /><br />It works best if you go with the grain for the 1st cut, to get the high stuff out of the way. Then go against the grain for a smooth, baby face cut. Yes, it will take a little bit longer, but your face will thank you for it.<br /><br />I only gave this model 3 stars because they are being made cheaper with each one I buy over the yrs. This one has a plastic head where the outer blades are located. My last Panny, which was very similar to this one, was encased in aluminium. Also, you CAN NOT use this plugged in, as a previous person wrote in their extensive review. It will not turn on when it is charging.<br /><br />I do like the LED that tells you how much charge is left. It goes in increments of 10, from10% to 100%. This is a cool feature. With only 10% remaining on the charge, I was able to do a complete shave. It charges from 0 to 100% rather quickly. So if your charge is low, you can give it a quick charge to 20% in about 5 mins. Way more than enough to get a clean shave.<br />When charged to 100%, I get about 5 or 6 shaves before it needs a recharge.<br /><br />All in all, its a pretty good shaver. I do think the price is too high. It shouldn't sell for any more than $50. But, Panny shavers have served me well over the yrs. They are dependable.

  2081. I'm one of those guys who shaves with regular razors and gets cuts and really red/sore neck. Over the years I've had all the Mach 3's, Hydro's, etc. and nothing ever helped. Blades were also so expensive and hard to find for my favorite Hydro 3 (Schick). I heard that electric shavers help with the skin sensitivity issue and found this one with a great price so decided to try it. Holy cow, I will never go back. I still am keeping my Hydro 3 and the blades I've been able to find, but just for a backup. Of course, I don't get as close of a shave and I may have to use it every day (instead of every other) in order to not look too rough, but I just don't mind! Shaving doesn't hurt and I don't have to take a hot shower to soften up my beard like I used to. I use between 10 and 20% of the battery in one shave so normally just charge it on the weekend. It takes maybe an hour or so.<br /><br />I've used it for a few months now and my neck has never looked better. I use it dry so it is also very convenient. I know this will end up paying for itself in no time!
  2082. I've come to the conclusion that this is the worst razor in existence. I've used it 4 times now. This razor was created by Lucifer himself.<br /><br />For starters, the razor's back side has a tool that allows you to simply shave off hair, like you would with a shaving knife. The problem is, the razor can barely do this. Instead, the razor prefers to pull and rip your hairs on your face out, leaving you bloody. The first time I shaved with this razor, I did so with a full beard. Next 3 times, I cut down my beard as much as I could with scissors and tried shaving. Just finished shaving the 4th time. Face is a bloody mess.<br /><br />Second, this doesn't even shave well, even for all its sadistic marauding. After I'm done carving away my face with the back razor, I switch to the main one: The razor you see in the picture, on top. This would allow me to get closer to the skin and shave off everything the other razor couldn't.   2090. Purchased this item on Amazon for 53.99 and I am very happy to have made the switch from Remington to Panasonic! I was a little skeptical at first due to the &#34;different' shape of the shaver compared to my old school Remington MS2-390 but, now couldn't be happier. Had major problems with the Remington MS2-390 as the motor would rev up and down while plugged in and shaving corded! The switch was a major hassle too as you had to push it 10 times and hope it stayed on once.<br /><br /> The motor on this shaver is far superior to the Remington and you can rinse it clean under running water. It gives a close, clean shave and is a pleasure to use. The battery fully charges in under an hour and you can get 4-5 shaves before it needs recharging. There's a countdown LED on the shaver that tells what percentage of battery life is left. The unit cannot be turned on while charging so, it's cordless only. If you are going back and forth through reviews, consider this very good shaver and by all means trust that Panasonic doesn't just make cameras. They've done their homework here and it shows every time I shave. I'll never go back!
  2091. I was very skeptical about 5 months ago about switching to an electric razor, but I trusted the reviews on Amazon and spurred by my need for a more efficient and time saving shaving solution, I decided to purchase this Panasonic. Five months into it, I don't regret it! The initial break in period was the hardest since my beard grows back very fast. It took about 2 weeks to get used to the motion and to get a technique going. Now, I run it on my face dry twice every week when the stubble is pretty thick, and it works like a charm.<br /><br />Tip:<br />- For thick stubbles try a wet shave with foam and warm water. It is a great shave!<br />- Do not expect it to work smoothly right away if you're switching from the blade. Give it at least 2-4 weeks, just like the instructions and videos say.

  2109. I have used Panasonic wet and dry shavers ever since I first saw one in a hardware store maybe forty or more years ago. I have had at least a dozen and a half or various models. My single biggest complaint has been the overpriced replacement head and screens. My second complaint has been the ni-cad and NiMH batteries that never seem to last. My third complaint has been the screens that fail to pick up the stray fine hairs that seem to sprout around the lower neck area.<br />This shaver (ES8103S) scores with a lithium battery and has a slotted head that gets at the finer hairs. One complaint is that it does not shave as close as my cheap AA battery powered shaver I bought for ten dollars. I will keep searching for the perfect Panasonic shaver.
  2110. I was very happy with this shaver. I used another shaver years ago and it did not do as a good job as this one.<br />Very close shave.
  2111. I have been using electric shavers since 1949, and this one is the champ. Smooth and fast. It puts out a sound that seems to be of a higher pitch but not louder than other shavers I have had, and is not annoying.<br /> Feb 2014 UPDATE: I was of a mind to downgrade to 4-star because the power monitor drops about 10% for each shave, implying that it is good for 10 shaves, so you must pack a charger for a two-week trip. Recently I decided to see how long it would run after the monitor showed 10%-RECHARGE. What do you know---it gave another 10 shaves before stopping,more than ample for the two-week trip. Also, running it down to zero at home is no great inconvenience; if it stalls in mid-shave just a few minutes on charge will let you finish. I have learned to better appreciate the \\"clean me\\" message also. If the power monitor were more accurate this shaver would deserve a 6-star rating.
  2112. Reading several of the reviews, you'll notice a trend that the screen starts having issues but the shaver will still work. I noticed that fairly soon after purchasing it. In terms of battery life, I get about a week's worth of shaves out of it before it dies, invariably in the middle of shaving on Monday morning. Then I have to wait until it recharges enough for me to finish my shave since the genius designers decided not to let it be used while charging.<br /><br />It does give a very nice shave, it may take a couple extra passes in areas where the hair doesn't grow in a uniform direction but that's true with every shaver I've tried thus far.<br /><br />My biggest gripe is with the trimmer. It flat out sucks. It folds down when attempting to use it and really takes a lot of work to get it to actually cut anything. So if you don't shave for a couple days and have some longer hairs that are being stubborn about going down into the foil to get cut... good luck using the trimmer on them. You can completely forget using it on sideburns, mustache edges, or take down any amount of beard. It won't work.

I usually make one pass carefully shaving all the nooks and crannies; then another pass where I run my hand over my face to find the missed stubble.   2114. Nice convenient, but i sure hope this is NOT the best. I can use it to take down some stubble, but still need straight edge for that super date!
  2115. I used an electric razor early on...but then switched to a safety razor @~30. Now...30 years later...decide to try electric again. Electric is quicker & easier to use, and this razor does provide a close shave..almost as close as the safety razor.

  2124. I've always used electric razors and this is by far the best one that I've used. The swivel head is great. The battery display is handy. It looks great, too, not that that really matters to most guys. The timmer works just fine. The wet/dry ability is nice, too. Only complaint is that it can't operate while charging; it must be unplugged. That said, the batter life is VERY good and when it's down to 10% it lasts much longer than you would expect. Overall, this is a great item, and it made shaving SOOO much less of a unpleasant chore to accomplish.

  2127. The ES8103S is an excellent razor. It was acquired to replace an aging Norelco 8240XL, a Braun 1775 and the side cutters on a Panasonic ES4000. The aging razors provide my base for comparison. I would first comment that the ES8103S does a good job of shaving both fast and close. It does not hug the face and particularly the chin area as well as the Norelco, but it seems to cut a little closer. With its original screen and cutter, I liked the Braun 1775 a little better as a shaver. Unfortunately, Braun's replacement screen for the 1775 has a slightly different pattern and does not seem to cut as quickly or as closely. It is funny how a manufacturer &#34;improves&#34; a product and makes it worse. The side cutter on the ES8103S is good and better than the Braun or the Norelco. It is not as good as the side cutter on the Panasonic ES4000 because it is mounted on the side of the razor body whereas the ES4000 cutter extends beyond the head of the razor and can better access areas around the ears and dangling nose hairs.
  2128. I am disappointed in this shaver's ability to actually give me a shave. It takes twice as long to shave as the Braun that I retired and, frankly, I'll soon by another Braun. I just don't have the time to waste.
  2129. My son bought one of these and loved it. Then my other son kept borrowing the razor so I purchased another. Really a great product and still working great a few months later.
  2130. New to wet shaving and I like it in the shower. Hope it wears well but it is too soon to tell
  2131. Very quite, very close shave, long lasting battery life and the shaver is extremely light weight. Highly recommend this shaver.
  2132. I purchased this given the recommendation from The Sweet Home. I don't have a lot of facial hair, nor does it grow terribly fast, so the top recommendation from The Sweet Home seemed overkill. The Arc3 is a good size and has good features, including a sideburn trimmer, so I can get rid of another battery-operated device on my bathroom counter. The Arc3 is my first electric shaver; I've been sticking it out with a Gillette Sensor Excel but wanted a change in my shaving routine. The Arc3 is okay so far. I need multiple passes, particularly over my lip, but it does the job. The repeated passes means skin irritation, so I put on moisturizer or coconut oil right after the shave. For the money, it's not a bad product.

  2140. After using Norelco for many years, decided to try something else. Panasonic was a big disappointment and not just because I was accustomed to Norelco. Norleco is round and can move in any, multi-directional. Also, immediately noticed it was LOUD, who wants LOUD when just waking up in the morning (or anytime), next to my ears. Also, compared to Norelco it was much larger in the hand and overall and much heavier. It didn't give any closer shave, with a difference. On my upper lip it got so close, my skin hurt, that's too close. When finished with Norleco, just pop the top and blow out the shaving \\"dust\\", then put it back in the charging cradle until tomorrow. How easy and so quiet, fast, light (Already mentioned, Panasonic is much heavier and larger). Panasonic was like a Power Mower on my face, with no measurable difference it results. My neck is especially troublesome, but I've learned how to angle the blade properly to get those areas.<br /><br />This is a good razor and it performs better than the flatter-faced Norelco I was using before, but it does take a little getting used to.

  2152. I was sad when my old Panasonic wet/dry shaver finally died. The sculptural shape of the razor was beautiful (about the closest thing to an Apple product) and I loved the way it naturally fit in my hand. It's just a shame that they could not have incorporated the original design.
  2153. I think this razor is a great value. I've only ever used Panasonic wet/dry shavers, so I have no other manufacturer to compare to, but I find these razors to be a perfect blend of the closeness gained from traditional wet shaving with the general lack of skin irritation associated with electrics. Combine this with a nice cream - not foam - shaving product (like Cremo) and you are in business! Looking back at my purchases, it seems this razor lasts me about 3 years while shaving a heavy beard 25 of 30 days of the month. I replace the the foil and blades - regardless of foil health/appearance - every 6 months using Amazon's Subscribe and Save feature.
  2154. Frankly, I would not buy this (or any electric razor) to use instead of blades. The results are just too patchy no matter how many passes you make or what kind of technique you use.<br /><br /> What I use this for is to prepare my face or scalp (I shave my head too) for shaving with the blade by using it on areas that it works well on. I find it works very well in the back of my head (this area is difficult to shave with a Mach 3 because of frequent clogging). It also works well on the mustache area, the chin and the mid and upper cheeks (these areas are sensitive and get irritated easily when I use a blade so I'm happy to get any relief I can in those areas).<br /><br /> This unit does not work well at all on the neck area. You might as well not even bother unless you want to spend 20 minutes going over and over it and still having to finish it with a blade.<br /><br /> It may not sound like it but I'm satisfied with this shaver because I have owned several foil shavers in the past and I knew not to expect to be able to use it exclusively. I had a Braun many years ago and I loved it for the mustache area because I have a hard time shaving this area without pulling and pain.<br /><br /> The real advantages of this shaver are...<br /><br />1. Wet or dry. This is great. Not necessarily for shaving wet. I don't find it works significantly better wet but it's nice to just be able to wash the heads. Sometimes I do like to take it in the shower with me and shave the back of my head and neck with the water running on it to instantly wash away the stubble.<br /><br />2. The battery technology is much improved over older shavers. The battery charges in an hour and holds a good charge for a while. If you don't use it every day, you still don't have to charge it every time you use it. The battery meter looks nice and it's nice to know exactly how much juice you have. The shaver also doesn't slow down and stall when it starts to run low on power. The battery features alone areworth at least half the price of the shaver. Just to not have to worry about any hassle. About the only thing I can think of that would make this aspect of it better would be if there was a very easy way to replace the battery with a reasonably priced replacement.<br /><br />Conclusion - If there are people who use these shavers every day without finishing off with a blade, I don't know how they do it. This shaver is easy on your skin if you don't make too many passes but it can still cause irritation if you push it. I don't see too many men walking around with patchy shaves so I don't know what's up with that. Maybe I'm just spoiled with the smoothness of the shave I get with the Mach 3 on my neck area. Also, it should be noted I don't shave every day so maybe if you don't let your stubble grow much it will do better. But I still find it doesn't do a flawless job even on short stubble.<br /><br /> I have had this shaver for about 3 years (I think) and I don't regret buying it. The battery shows no obvious signs of weakness so far and I haven't even replaced the foil and cutters yet. Though I would say I probably should have.<br /><br /> It's especially nice to prep my scalp for shaving by going over those pesky areas that are hard to get at with the blade. I'd make a guess that anyone who shaves their head regularly would be glad to have this. If you know head shaving, you know it's a process and you tend to need a variety of tools to get a good result.
  2155. I am very pleased with the shave the Panasonic gives, but very disappointed in the battery life. It only gives you about 8 shaves per charge. Manufactures make better batteries.

  2170. As others have mentioned, the shaver gives a very close shave and the pivot motion is useful. The battery life is very long, lasting about 2 weeks for me between charges. It charges very fast, typically an hour from 10% to 100% full, and the digital battery indicator helps me decide if I need to charge prior to taking it on long trips.<br />The reason for 2 stars is the trimmer which I use for sideburns broke after only 20 months of use. There is a tiny plastic gear nub (for lack of a better description) that vibrates the trimmer blade, and the nub either wore down or broke. Therefore it does not trim any longer. Mind you I use the trimmer only every other day on average. The shaving part still works great. I tried to find a replacement part however could not find one; I would have to disassemble the unit to replace the plastic gear. I gave it to my wife who can use it for her legs but I'll have to buy another shaver/trimmer now.
  2171. Razor work great. I get a very close shave and it gets the difficults places like under the chin very well. Also, the handle grip is very comfortable.
  2172. This is my first electric shaver. I resisted the switch from manual razors for 15 years. Even when my wife gifted me one - I love gadgets - so she thought it would be a great birthday gift - within the first few years our marriage. But, I promptly returned it without even opening. These days she doesn't bother buying any electronics for me. So, I end up gifting myself on my birthdays. And I continued to fill the bank accounts of Gillette, religiously buying their sensor excel cartridges. But in the last 3-4 years, I haven't been satisfied with my shaves. It is not as close - and the blades seem to lose their edge soon - only after ~4 shaves. This time when it was due to buy new blades I did a quick math and realized that for the money I spend on the replacement cartridges, I can buy a new electric shave every year. I am all about saving money - so I decided it give it a try. Worst case, I can go back to manual, after a year. So, after the ritual of reading and re-reading the reviews of electric shavers at Amazon, I finally settled on this one. Firstly the cost - there was also a $15 off special - and the great reviews. First Experience: As I got this shaver out of the well packaged box, it felt quite good in my hand - I liked the ergonomics. It was not too heavy or too big. Seemed just right. Switching from manual shaver, I wanted a dry/wet shaver, which is why I chose this one. Looking back, I realize I don't really need the wet shave feature. Yes, the first time I tried with shaving cream, it was quite messy. With the foam on, I could not see which parts I missed. I finally ended up washing it all off and going over the missed parts again. Felt much better now. After 2 weeks: After first use, I started doing dry shave, and just love the result. It is very good and I agree with the other reviewers. I get a really close shave and really quick &#60;5 minutes (as opposed to ~10 minutes with manual shave). I clean it by rinsing off in the faucet, shaking the water and leaving it on the counter to dry. The trimmer is a nice feature - very useful for the sideburns, as I do grow sideburns. The surprise was that the battery lasted for whole two weeks - that is 6 shaves - before it got down to 10% and the charge indicator started blinking. CONS: IT IS NOISY - yes, particularly when you do your cheeks/sideburns - it is like a bee is buzzing around your head. One day my wife came upstairs wondering if there was a bee inside our house. I seriously considered using ear plugs - but didn't want to look at a goofy self image every time I shaved and so decided against it - at least for now. Hopefully I grow out of this noise, as this is a wonderful little shaver, except for the noise. I will come back after a few months and add comments about how the battery holds up. But, honestly, if this lasts for 2 years - I would have got more than my money's worth and would gladly buy another one. Update (July 2017): After 3 years of continuous usage - 3 times a week - it is going strong, except I had to replace the Outer Foil around 18 months, as it wore out and started scratching my face. The battery still holds up quite well - around 10% per shave. So, I recharge once in two weeks or so. I recently bought another one of the same, when the price went down - just to have as a backup. Yes, it is noisy; but I am okay putting up with it for 10 minutes every other day.
  2173. easy to carry and very easy to recharge. it has weight<br />, style and attractiveness. one might even call it sexy.
  2174. This is not even close to &#34;one-pass shaving&#34; or whatever they claim. I have pretty sparse facial hair that doesn't grow too rapidly and isn't very coarse, but I still have to go over and over most spots to get a *relatively* smooth shave. When shaving I can *see* spots of hair that the shaver is missing, but going over those spots again and again still doesn't remove them. It's just not that powerful of a shaver, I guess. I tried replacing the blade and that didn't improve anything. So I would recommend not wasting your money on this.<br /><br />HOWEVER, my girlfriend bought the slightly better Panasonic ES8249S model -- I think it's no longer sold, but it has 4 blades and 13,000 RPM and it works MUCH better (yes, she uses it on her legs but I use it on my face too). It's not perfect either (I'd give it 4 stars) but works well enough with the convenience factor that yesterday (Feb 17, 2014) I bought the current version ES8243A for $80 on a lightning deal. It was time for me to replace the blade on this ES8103S anyway, and since I really don't care for it, I decided to just put that money towards a new shaver that I know works better (the one I bought has basically the same specs as the ES8249S model that we also own, so I expect it to work similarly). So I would spend the extra money -- when the shaver goes on sale (and these Panasonic ones often do here on Amazon) -- on a 4-blade model. The new shaver should be here tomorrow, I'll review it after I have a little time to use it.<br /><br />Lastly, don't bother buying the &#34;Vortex cleaning system&#34; with that base thing that you plug the shaver into. These shavers all have a built-in &#34;cleaning mode&#34; and we don't ever use the base cleaning system or whatever. It's just an extra gimmick IMO to raise the price. Just buy the shaver alone.

  2177. This is my second Panasonic shaver. I have dense, thick facial hair and very very sensitive skin which bleeds under normal blade conditions. I had a top of the line braun which gave a mediocre shave and irritated my skin after about 6 months of use. The Panasonic is less expensive, and provides the closest shave of any electric ever tried before, with ZERO (yes ZERO) irritation. I Can use this thing once a day without a problem. I prefer dry with a bit of LECTRIC SHAVE oil which makes all the difference in the world. I have purchased this for friends and recommended it to colleagues. If you are in the market for an electric shaver, give Panasonic a try , you will not be disappointed. Battery lasts just about all week, and I rarely replace the foil and blade more frequently than once per 12-16 months. My last one lasted for over 5 years and was going strong, I simply wanted the &#34;latest and greatest&#34;.

  2182. I was lucky enough to buy this razor as an open box item for $45 (yay me) and I am very, very pleased with my purchase.<br /><br />I'd previously been using a cheapo, generic foil shaver and I was only able to use it dry.<br />It wasn't a particulary close shave (and resulted in terrible burn afterwards), but I've never had much luck with razors (I irritate very easily), so it was pretty much my only affordable (less than $90) option, 'till I found this lovely little piece of technology that is.<br /><br />When I first charged this baby up and shaved with it, I was pretty impressed (very impressed actually).<br />I had ZERO irritation, ZERO burn (after getting used to it, which only took about 5 days, otherwise very minimal burn the 1st time), and ZERO ingrown hairs.<br />My face was smooth and I could go out in public without looking like I landed face-first in a patch of poison ivy.<br />Being that this is a machine, it's not gonna be quite as close as a razor, but truthfully, the difference is so minimal that the trade-off is worth it.<br /><br />The shave itself is very, very nice.<br />I noticed that it doesn't quite shave the neck area as well as I'd like it to, and as such, I can't give the machine 5 stars.<br />It's worked very well for me along my jaw and for the majority of the cheeks, but just shy of the mustache, no matter how much I maneuver it, it always misses the same 3 or 4 hairs. I have to use the trimmer to get them.<br />The trimmer also does a wonderful job of shaping my sideburns.<br /><br />I've used the machine both wet and dry.<br />I usually go dry for the convenience (shave in 3-4 minutes), but I've noticed that, in my case at least, wet shaving yields slightly better results, particularly in the way of less missed hairs.<br />I also highly suspect that wet shaving will keep the blades from dulling as fast as they would when dry shaving, being that wet hair is easier for the blades to cut through.<br /><br />Whether I have bad luck or not,I can't say, but after only 6 months of using the machine (daily basis), it seems I have to replace the inner blades already. It's not cutting quite as nicely as the 1st time I used it. I can no longer shave dry and achieve the same smoothness I once did. I shave wet now to achieve the results I prefer.<br /><br />I've also used the machine on my legs and it does a pretty dandy job.<br />I can't stick a blade to my upper leg, due to the sensitivity of my skin, but the ES8103S achieves wonderful results without my needing to resort to a blade. Of course, it takes much longer to shave than with a blade (40 minutes or so for me), but I'm more than happy with the results I've achieved. Near-perfect smoothness with no irritation, redness, or bumps.<br />I've found that I get the best shave by using very, very light pressure on the initial passes while keeping the machine perpendicular to the area being shaved, and then gradually pressing just a bit harder while varying the angle of the shaving head. Always against the grain of hair growth at first. I usually follow-up with passes that are half across the grain, and half against the grain (45 degrees) to ensure a uniform shave.<br /><br />Cleaning the machine is a breeze. I just put a little soap on the foil, switch it to turbo mode while it's under hot water, let it run and then I'm done (yeah, that rhymed).<br />I usually run the machine in alcohol afterwards, then I let it air dry.<br /><br />The pros of this machine most definitely outweigh the cons.<br />For those who have sensitive skin and can't use razors, I highly recommend this machine, or the ES-LA63-S (for those with a slightly higher budget).<br />The zero-irritation factor is something that I just can't speak highly enough of.<br />Add convenience into the mix and that makes this machine a true godsend.<br /><br />After about 7 months of use, my LCD has half-started to fade, so instead of seeing 50%, I'll just see a 5. I can still at least tell when my machine needs to be charged, though. The problem seems to be intermittent. It's curious.<br />I would still definitely recommend giving this machine a shot, though.<br /><br />Final Score:<br />The Shave: 8/10 (since it's not as close as a razor and missed a few hairs which I have to get with the trimmer. The fact that there's zero irritation, though. HUGE plus, so I don't mind giving up a little bit more closeness for that)<br />Cleaning: 9/10 (stupidly easy to clean. soap, water, alcohol, air dry. I don't give perfect scores hence the 9/10)<br />Durability: 6/10 (LCD display starting to glitch after 6 months of use is a bummer. Needing to replace my inner blades after 6 months of use is also a bit of a drag.)<br />Maneuverability: 7/10 (the machine itself has little problem reaching any tricky spots, but the trimmer is very limited. If often closes itself on me, so I have to put my thumb under it to stop that from happening, which results in quite a bit of awkwardness when it comes to maneuvering it around my face. This machine isn't particularly cooperative when it comes to styling your facial hair, but I prefer to be clean shaven anyways, so it's not a problem for me)<br />Overall: 7/10 (The shave itself is great as far as machines go, but the fact that it misses a few hairs and doesn't do my neck as well as I'd like lowers the rating a bit. Other cons include the lack of maneuverability, particularly in the case of the trimmer, and the faulty LCD display.)

  2187. This electric shaver provides a close shave. I really like the pivoting head; it makes it easier to hold the blades at the optimum shaving angle when shaving my neck. I've used other electric shaves and have always had to clean up problem areas with a regular razor. Since using this I haven't had to do this. I was a little surprised with how high the hum of the motor is but it's understandable concerting how fast it is moving. There is only one design flaw. The charging cable has a sideways orientation (perpendicular to the tongs) and will not fit into the outlets in my bathroom because they are between two cabinets. Every other rechargeable device I have had a vertical orientation or one that rotates to allow for small spaces that many bathrooms have. I really like the shaver so I'll just continue to charge it in another room.

  2200. Four and a half years later, and it's still going strong (bought in May 2010). It'll still last through a four-week business trip without recharging. It also recharges really quickly, so if you've forgotten to charge it just before a week-long trip, half an hour will do.<br /><br />I haven't felt the need to change the blades<br /><br />I've used a lot of electric razors (Norelco, Braun), and this is as good as any of them. No electric razor is as good as a blade, but at 2.5 bucks a blade (geeez!), this baby has paid for itself at least three times over (and more like four).<br /><br />I also used it to shave my scalp for awhile, and it worked just as well there as on my face.
  2201. Very surprised at the quality. I have owned 12 or more shavers in the last 20 years, and this is one of the better ones, very close shave, I think closer than Braun's big one I also have. Braun's has a cleaning cradle and some nice touches, but actually this one became my favorite after one day's use. The super high speed must be a good answer to the shaving problem. It is pretty fast as compared to using the Braun, and is quiet enough as well. NOTE the charger is a bit clunky by comparison to Braun. No coil-cord and old fashioned looking plug-charger. One the plus side, one long shave seem to only use 10% of my first charge. The % battery left indicator is great, better than competitors I think. The price is among the lowest too. So for value I give this 5 stars, it is a very good shaver at a very good price. I will probably by another, when I find something good, they usually quit making it or &#34;improve&#34; it (not). Best to get two of anything you like, next year's models are not always (if ever) quite as good.

  2221. For the price, it is a great shaver. One plastic part that invariably breaks after two to three years use, is the one that moves the center blade. If it were made of metal, the shaver should last for another couple of years. Three of the shavers used in the past had this problem.<br /><br />Hopefully Panasonic people check these comments.
  2222. I bought this to replace my 10+ year old Braun 5414 electric shaver. I don't have a lot of facial hair but I like a close shave.   2223. I was excited that I was finally going to allow myself to spend more than the $49.99 I paid for my previous shaver, the Remington MS290 (I think that was it). Too bad that excitement didn't transfer to the model I selected. The ES8103S is a quality looking, feeling and sounding device. I just have had no success with the shaving part.   2224. I bought an electric shaver a couple years ago for the same price as this one (around $60). I wish I could remember the brand and model, as it would certainly help with the comparison I am about to do. But, I threw that one away after using this one for the first time, and I will tell you why.<br /><br />I have only used this shaver twice, but I couldn't be more impressed. I will usually use a manual razor in the shower, then use my electric to pick up anything I missed. However, if it has only been a day or two since my last shave, I will just use the elctric.<br /><br />When I first got this shaver, I plugged it in to charge, which it did within a couple hours from 20% to 100%. After using it twice, it is still at 100%, which the convenient LCD screen will tell you. My old one had no such indicator, and you only knew how much charge was left by the motor slowing down.<br /><br />Now, the quality of the shave is obviously the most important aspect of the product. This product delivers in a big way. It has been very hot here in the Pittsburgh, PA area, as many are probably aware, since ti has been pretty hot all over the US. As such, I would often be a bit sweaty, after taking a hot shower and drying off in a bathroom with little ventilation. My former shaver was very difficult to use under these conditions, and there were times I wouldn't even bother because I knew it would be too difficult to move around on my skin, which would cause irritation. This one, hwoever, has performed flawlessly, even under those conditions. It does not stick and jump around, as I move it over my face, even when it reaches a \\"sticky\\" spot from the sweat. The closeness of the shave is also excellent, which, again, is the key to a good shaver.<br /><br />I almost went for the expensive shavers that are sold by other brands, such as the SensoTouch. However, after reading the lackluster reviews on those, I couldn't justify spending the money. Now, I'm really glad I didn't, asI don't believe for one second that this shaver is lacking in any way over the more expensive models out there.<br /><br />I should point out there is one thing to be aware of. The noise this thing makes is pretty loud. When I was using it on Sunday, I kept thinking that it sounds like a weed whacker. Now, that's an exaggeration, but the somewhat high-pitched noise at a decently high volume is something to be aware of, as some people are sensitive to such things. My hearing is better than most peoples', and it didn't bother me. If someone was asleep in the next room, I suspect this would probably wake them up. That wasn't enough of a reason to justify me giving this product any lower of a rating because, like I said, it doesn't bother me a bit. All in all, if you're comparing this to the $150-$250 shavers out there, I recommend saving your money and giving this one a try. I'm not at all sorry that I did.

I have been diligent with rinsing and keeping it clean (hot water + dish soap, as the instructions suggest), but if I don't disassemble the unit to dry. It smells. I first notice how nice it feels to hold the shaver, so hats of to Panasonic for designing such a good grip feel. The shave is not bad - a very close shave but I think it could've gone even closer. The flex head is nice as it contours around your face. I liked the LCD screen showing how much battery is left. Perhaps the cleaning part if the most \\"annoying\\". Now I get that you don't have to clean it every day and you could just rinse it under water. But I like to clean mine everyday so it usually takes me an extra 1 minute to put soap it, put it in sonic clean mode, and rinse it out. Not too difficult, of course, but time consuming for me personally. I am looking into buying just the Hydraclean machine so I could just stick it in to self-clean. Overall, I would definitely recommend this shaver.

The rotary was good for at least 20.<br /><br />I decided to try this shaver after I lost the power cord for my rotary shaver. I was durned if I was gonna pay that kind of outrageous price for a power cord.<br /><br />This new shaver has performed well, and with several swipes, produces a shave that feels almost blade-like.   2266. First off: I'm 17 so i don't have the 5 o'clock forest yet, however, this razer gets very close, much closer than my old $20 Norelco (of course it was 3x more) It is easy to clean and most of the stubble shavings stay inside the razer so they don't end up all over the place. I have tried it wet and dry and wet definately gives a closer shave, however it is harder to get everywhere in the shower. It hasn't gotten the hair on my neck well at all, but that could probably be attributed to my relative inexperience and acne bumps. Excellent battery life; you could probably shave for 30 mins straight on a full charge and the 5 min charge is excellent. Also, once you charge the battery, it stays charged. I've left it nearly a week unplugged and it was still 100% The only real con i have noticed is its trouble with neck hair. I have had to use the rear trimmer to get my neck almost every time, as the main blades miss 55% of that area All in all, I probably could've given it a 4, but I'm happy with it. I hope it will fix itself as I get older and more experienced

I finally decided to dump those brands after reading that Panasonic and Braun were superior. After a couple of months, I can safely conclude that it does provide a close shave. I like the automatic \\"clean\\" icon and the sonic cleaning mode, which make it the easiest shaver to clean that I've owned. I find this shaver is less forgiving than my previous shavers if you don't pull the skin taut as you shave; for my skin and beard, anyway, that's mandatory. One aspect that I don't like is that the shaver will not operate when the cord is plugged in. This is strictly a cordless shaver, and the cord is only for re-charging. I have no buyer's remorse with this shaver, which is a first for me.

  2280. I've had this razor for approaching two years now. I previously had a Norelco that worked fairly well, but never really gave me a close shave and I was constantly missing hairs. With the Panasonic I get a good, clean, close shave every time. It does struggle with some of the longer hairs, but it's a pretty infrequent problem. On one charge the razor lasts me between 10 and 14 days, give or take. It generally only takes a shade over an hour to charge fully, and the battery life doesn't seem to have decreased at all since I first purchased it. It's easy to clean and empty. I have pretty sensitive skin, and this razor is very gentle.<br /><br />The only cons in my experience are the noise and the debris. It's pretty loud as far as electric razors go, but doesn't really bother me too much. It also seems to drop a lot of debris, so it can be a bit messy.   2283. I bought this Panasonic shaver to replace an old Remington DA-307 shaver. I wasn't unhappy with the Remington, I just couldn't get replacement blades/foils any more (they changed the design). The Panasonic is a decent shaver, a much more high-tech and precise instrument compared to the Remington. The Panasonic works well, is easy to use, and gives a close shave. It's not particularly fast, though - it takes me a while and I have to go over some areas multiple times to get the closest shave. The shaver head is easy to clean, but sometimes the foil falls out when you remove the head - the tabs to release the foil are in the same location as the tabs to remove the head. The pop-up trimmer works very well. I originally thought the numeric display was overkill, but it turns out to be a handy way to tell how many more shaves you can get before recharging (approximately, it shows percent charge remaining). This is important, because you can't leave the shaver plugged into an electric outlet all the time. The shaver will not work if the charger is plugged into AC. So after recharging, you must unplug the charger, and then you might as well put the charger away, due to its ugly and inelegant non-coiled cord. Before you buy any shaver, check out the price/availability of replacement blades/foils, because for some shavers, these parts are way too expensive. The parts for this Panasonic aren't too expensive, and I bought a full set with the shaver just to have them on hand.
  2284. Great shaver for the money. Its quiet compared to my last Panasonic shaver. It shaves a lot closer too. Its a keeper!
  2285. I have trouble shaving every day due to my neck area breaking out. I've tried all the sensitive skin shaving gels and after shave lotions. With the Panasonic electric shaver, I am able to shave every day with not irritation to my neck at all. I shave dry with no shaving gel or anything. It's definitely not as close a shave as a razor, but after you get used to it, you can get a rather smooth shave. It's really worked well for me. I highly recommend this product if you have sensitive skin.

  2308. I bought my ES8103 in 2009. It's still going strong, takes a full charge, and gives a good shave. However, it has become unpleasantly loud in the past six months. No idea what the problem is. Still, six years is a pretty good run, and no complaints. I was thinking about upgrading to a 4-blade Panasonic, but the blades and foil for those models can get expensive. The consumables for the ES8103 are at least reasonable (especially when on sale at the brand's online shop, hint hint). Panasonic recommends replacing the outer foil once a year and the blades once every two years. I generally split the difference and replace everything at 18 months. When shopping for a razor don't forget the recurring costs. The ES8103 has some of the lowest running costs. Great razor.

  2320. 5 years and still running strong! I bought the shaver after breaking my right hand. I was a \\"blade\\" shaver before that. Top of the line Remington foil and Norelco rotary razors relegated to the linen closet after abysmal performances from previous years. I was always a little curious about the \\"wet and dry\\" from Panasonic but, hesitant to waste any more $ on a closet relic. Breaking my hand was the perfect excuse to be adventurous.<br /><br />I've never looked back. A week after receiving the ES8103S the other razors ended up in the trash. The shave was closer than I was getting from the blade (dry shaving). I did not notice an improvement, and perhaps the wet shaving isn't as close for me. I don't have the coarsest beard, but it grows every which way. It takes me a lot longer than 2 minutes to shave. I would call the battery life extraordinary. Normally about a week on a charge for my 4-5 minute shaves. Amazing performance after almost 5 years. Did I say closer than a blade for me?<br /><br />The thing feels good in the hand. The trimmer works well. The noise is not deafening or overly \\"whiney.\\" Cleaning is a breeze. Don't waste your money on all those \\"gimmicky\\" cleaning stations. Not unless you're inviting people into your bath to \\"show off\\" (I'm thinking Braun snob). I only clean mine before recharge cycles. A little liquid shower soap on the foil, run it under a hot faucet after removing the foil/cover, done. It's never received any more attention than that. No lubrication, no nothing. There is no build-up of \\"gunk\\" whatsoever.<br /><br />Recently I came across the original receipt and operators manual. Purchased from Amazon in 2009 @ $92. That's about $1.50/mnth. It looks almost like new; I HAVE NOT CHANGED THE FOIL OR THE BLADE IN THAT TIME! I'm not easily impressed and think that's pretty incredible. I can remember my Remington foil reminding me when it was time for a foil change (let there be blood).<br /><br />I'm thinking: better purchase a replacement foil/blades. Panasonic recommends: foil - yearly, blade - every 2 years. Cost on Amazon = $30+. Battery? Don't see replacements on Amazon. Probably; no user replaceable internal parts recommended by Panasonic. As a technician, I could probably crack it open, obtain the correct lithium ion battery and perform the replacement. But, that's a lot of time and money to invest in a 5 year old razor. So, I thought I'd check on the price of a new one: $75 Amazon prime + $20 clip and save coupon. Cha Ching! I'm ordering two. Actually click and save coupon only good on one. So, I'm ordering one and my wife is ordering one.

  2346. I've had electric shavers for over 40 years and this one is the best by far. It actually keeps full power until discharged AND let's you know exactly how much battery life is left.   2347. Gives a good shave but have to do multiple passes over my trouble spots. Still better than the remington I was using. Does not handle long stubble as well.
  2348. This shaver provides a comfortable and close shave reliably, with very little maintenance. I haven't been nearly as careful with it as I should have; my dog chewed up the charging end, and I've dropped it more times than I'd care to admit. Despite this, and having used it daily for three years, it does as well now as it did the day I first used it.<br /><br />There are only two parts, really: the body (including the blade), and the foil. With the foil removed, the blade vibrates at a faster speed than normal to facilitate easy cleaning; switching it on under warm running water immediately clears any debris from the blades, and any surrounding mess has a hard time adhering to the plastic beneath. For this reason, the cleaning add-ons are completely unnecessary. Charging from 0-100% takes 1-2 hours, and you can't use the shaver while it is plugged in. However, you can get enough charge for a single shave within 5 minutes of plugging it in if you forget to charge it and need to get out the door.<br /><br />Assuming daily use, Panasonic recommends that you replace the outer foil once a year and the blade every other year. I am still using the original blade and foil, and do not note any appreciable performance decrease. My beard is of average thickness but is quite coarse, and I am surprised by this shaver's perseverance with such regular use.
  2349. I LOVE THIS RAZOR. SHAVES CLOSE AND FAST. RECHARGES FAST AND SURE BEATS A REGULAR BLADE.<br />WILL USE EVERY DAY.
  2350. I gave this as gift to a Norelco user. He said it shaves very close and is super easy to clean. Note: must shave daily if not very good on long hairs. He also said he will never go back to Norelco
  2351. This shaver is smaller than the Norelco I used before, so it is easier to hold. I like that it charges in only an hour, as opposed to eight hours on other shavers I have used. It shaves well on most parts of my face except in the lower part of the neck. No matter how many times I pass over certain areas of my neck, this shaver just does not pick up the hairs. So, to finish the job I use a Braun PocketGo shaver.

  2361. Great product! This was my first electric shaver I have ever purchased. It was an awesome price and works great. The best part is it works dry or wet, you can use it with or without shaving cream as well. The panasonic shaver is also waterproof so it does great in the shower. Cleanup is simple and easy and the charge on the device lasts a long time. It only takes about an hour to fully charge it. The only downside is it does not give as close of a shave as a razor but it is pretty darn close. I definitely recommend this shaver.
  2362. I purchased ES8103S from Amazon and have been using for longer than 1 year. Shavers are very personal and each person will have very personal experience - it is for referecen only but not really a thing to argue with. Here is MY experience;<br /><br />I personally thing this shaves better than the rotary ones (with circle-shape blades). What I meant by better is &#34;more closely&#34;.<br /><br />The battery holds charges very well and I often forget to re-charge it. I shave every morning and I just recharged it this morning when I saw 0% on the screen - I do not remember when was the last time I charged it. The battery does hold charge very well.<br /><br />Like the subject indicates, my experience in the wet condition was not as you can see it in the TV commercial. When you use it in a shower with some shaving foam, the foam gets stuck inside of the chamber and the blade movements are disturbed. Unless you find very light foam somehow, I found it more useful use it on dry skins.<br /><br />However, the wet function becomes very useful - after each use, you can actually clean it under running water! Or you can even use soap to clean it thoroughly! This is worse paying extra for the wet function I think unless you want to use dirty blade shaving your skin every morning.<br /><br />One last tip for the first-time electrical shaver users - for the smooth shaving, make your skin very dry or very wet. Somewhat-wet does not work too well....

  2371. I find this to be perhaps the best electric shaver I have used. It does an excellent job providing a close shave in about 3 minutes shaving time. It provides a much smoother glide over my face and does not draw at the skin as much as other multi-head foil shavers I have tried recently. I did try two other brands of similar shavers and another model from Panasonic. This one was the &#34;keeper&#34; without a doubt. I like the balance and feel of the shaver when I am using it. I like the design and the way the parts fit together. I think the smoothness of the shave is the result of Panasonic's use of narrower foils than other models so there is not as much metal contact with the skin. Also, the slight arc in the foils and the central long hair cutter probably reduces the amount of metal to skin contact and aids in shaving comfort. My reason for giving only four stars instead of five is because I have not experience using it during the summer when humidity levels are higher than now in February. Also I think the travel bag which comes with the shaver should contain a provision for storing the cord along with the shaver. However, if anyone asks I will not hesitate to recommend that they try this model before making a decision on purchasing an electric shaver.
  2372. I love my new razor. Big difference from the Norelco floating head razor I spent a lot more money to buy! I'd recommend it!

  2374. I get irritated very easily on my neck (where the hair starts) when I shave. This razor eliminated that problem completely.<br /><br />I gave this 5 stars because it is a great buy for the money, but there are some cons.<br /><br />1. You can not use it plugged in. This means that eventually, this thing will be worthless when the battery won't hold a charge.<br />2. It takes a long time to shave.   2375. I bought this shaver about 2 months ago, and it is only average in my opinion. On the plus side, it does recharge quickly, and keeps shaving for a couple of weeks before it needs another charge. My only gripe about the charging system is that the display has three digits, but the amount of charge displayed is by increments of 10%, so it only needs one digit.<br />The razor is quite noisy, compared to my old Norelcos, and doesn't shave as close. Also, since a man's beard doesn't grow in only one direction, it is difficult if not impossible to get all the hairs lined up with the one directional slots. It never could shave all of my sideburn on one side, so I had to touch it up with a safety razor every couple of days. I finally bought some replacement parts for my old Norelco, and am back to using that now.

  2380. I switched from norelco wet/dry for a few years and used Gillette in the interim. Now I decided to shave every day once more and of course wet/dry is what I wanted as my skin is sensitive to drag. I also never had foil shaver so decided to try this Panasonic.<br /><br />Got great deal with free shipping and coupon.<br /><br />Obviously the most important thing is how it shaves: No complains here. I can easily say that it provides closer shave than Gillette ever did. I have a fairly heavy beard but even so it can handle up to about 5 days worth of growth. Easy to clean as well as you just take the outer foil and run it under water. There is also an option to use hand soap. You should expect the charge to last for about 10 days. It is also much slimmer than Norelco rotary shaver.<br /><br />There are a few bad things but not enough to take away a star:<br />Pop-up trimmer lever is placed in the worst possible spot and often pops up. There is also an explicit mention in the manual to place your thumb i the spot between the outer foil and the power button lest you accidentally turn on cleaning more and injure yourself. Never happened yet but still is concerning.<br />The glass cap that comes with the product is useless and actually makes things worse by preventing evaporation, I just don't use it as the shaver is inexpensive.<br />The power cord is not a standard one. Would have to buy overpriced replacement from Panasonic.<br /><br />Overall those are nitpicks though. I can heartily recommend this shaver to anyone who's looking to get a clean shave daily on a small budget. The only question now is how long will this gizmo last.
