  2387. I have been using this for 22 months. This is obviously the best shaver I have ever owned.<br /><br />Before ES8103S, I had a Braun 7 series shaver which I think was one of the most expensive shavers at that time and cost twice as much as ES8103S. However, it broke in two years; the ON/OFF switch came off and finally stopped working.<br /><br />Compared to the Braun 7, my ES8103S has never showed an issue and is much more reliable. It is closer, the motor is faster, and the battery lasts much longer - one charge lasts more than two weeks even after use of almost two years.<br /><br />Anyway, I like my ES8103S very much.<br /><br />However, there are two complaints. First, it's a bit loud. Fortunately, it does not bother anybody in my house, so it's OK. Second, it is not easy to judge whether the head outer blade part is completely put on the body, and therefore the outer blade is easily damaged due to the incomplete installation. Since I wash the blades every time, I always take off the head part after shaving. One time I did not completely put it back on the body, which made a small hole on the outer blade. It's my mistake, but I couldn't figure out how I broke it. I didn't even notice that the head part was not correctly installed. Though it turned out to be my failure later, you should be careful. Even a single small hole on an outer blade scratches your face.

  2393. The last time I tried an electric shaver was about 15 years ago. I didn't have much success, and I vastly preferred a razor blade. I was very happy with the design and ergonomics. Overall, it felt very good in the hand, and seemed to be of a durable construction that would last a long time. The fact that they encourage you to use it wet speaks volumes about how confident Panasonic is in this product, too.<br /><br />Unfortunately, I couldn't manage to get a satisfactory shave. It does a GREAT job on the flat surfaces of my face- super smooth. But I just couldn't get it to shave closely in the more difficult areas, such as around my jaw line. The best thing is, I can run it under hot water to clean it. I used to have to brush my old shaver out, and even go so far as to use a compressor on it to get it clean. This is a joy to clean. I have not tried it, but this shaver can be used wet. Don't know if I would like that, but it can be done. All in all, I would highly recommend it.
  2409. Had the shaver 3 month and it's performing very well. Cuts pretty close albeit not like a blade. Charges much more quickly (30 minutes) than my older Norelco and cleans easily too. Haven't tried it in the shower since I always dry shave. Display allows you to see how much charge you have left. I get about 20 shaves from a charge

  2419. After my last electric shaver bit the dust, I tried going back to blade shaving with a new 3-blade Gillette razor. After a few weeks, I decided to buy a new electric model. Highly recommended as having exceeded expectations. It hasn't happened yet, but the only drawback I can see is that if it runs out of charge, you cannot shave while recharging.
  2420. I have been using electric shavers for over 30 years, and tried many different brands. I found that Rule #1 is that electric shavers cannot give as close a shave as a stright blade razor, and Rule #2 is you can't change Rule #1. But, Panasonic is getting very close with the ES8103S!<br /><br />Moving from a three-head rotary to this shaver did require some changes in the way I shave. You still need to use two hands - one to hold the razor and the other to stretch your skin. Experiment with different strokes beyond straight up and down to include circular and side-to-side motions. It takes a little longer to shave with the Panasonic, but I am getting to most of the hard-to-get whiskers like the ones around the Adam's Apple of the throat and the hairs behind the jaw under the ear lobe. I use Remington Shaving Sticks as my preferred skin lubricant.<br /><br />The shaver is very comfortable in the hand. It is a bit noisy, but far from irritating. Try to keep the cutter head @90 degrees to your face to get as close as possible. Keep at it! This is a decent shaver.
  2421. I decided to stop using Gillette razors, due to the high price of the replaceable blades and use an electric shaver. My Remington is quite old and decided to purchase the Panasonic.<br />The shave is as close as the Gillette! I am very satisfied.

  2432. I gave it to my son and he is happy with it.
  2433. Electric shavers are great for Ladies with sensitive skin issues as well as Men! All I can say is The Panasonic ES81035 3-Arc is a life saver, and I love it!<br /><br />The breakdown:<br />Cons: They cost too much! Electric shavers are EXPENSIVE (luckily, this one was on sale, for under $70 (so I went ahead and bought 2) :P, still a bit over the top for a `shaver', but, even on the low end they have been priced at over $150 and on the high end, over $500. people with sensitive skin issues and allergies don't have much choice, it's either this or waxing which adds up to a lot more over time...<br /><br />Electric shavers are larger than disposable shavers, so you will need to prepare for that (the first time you try one is like the difference between trying to manicure your bikini line with hand held disposable shaver or something the size of a small blow-dryer (awkward)...) :P Even though it is hypoallergenic, people with sensitive skin will still get some irritation if used every day, so it's still best to use up to only every other day (M W F, Sat), or 3-4 days per week only to avoid skin burn.<br /><br />Ok, so it says wet-or-dry shave (which I liked, and ordered for that reason), but you definitely get a better/closer shave dry than using it wet or with shave gel.<br /><br />--------------<br />Pros: It's Hypoallergenic, shaves close (only a razor will give you a closer shave, so no complaints here), can be rinsed clean, and unlike disposable shavers, does NOT leave a trail of razor burn/bumps, and it can be used to safely shave your entire body (as well as a man's face)!<br /><br />I use it on underarms, bikini line area- - I promise you, only a razor or waxing will get you a closer shave--A funny tip, if you want to use a cream hair remover a few days before you try it such as Nair/Neet/Veet, etc. and then maintain the areas with the shaver, it might make it easier the first time you try it on your bikini or speedo zone (it has this neat little sideburn groomer feature that can also be used to prep/remove those longer personal hair areas before shaving and manicure/shape the outline if you prefer to retain a modesty patch, -- and on the QT, it can even gently remove hair from a lady's upper lip) :P ... Best of All, you can dry-shave without fear!<br /><br />And the 3-Arc is waay smaller than the (albeit more powerful) 4 and 5-arc series which makes it literally much easier to handle for women's body or/and facial hair issues, or those men with lighter facial and body hair issues in general. Once you get used to the feel of it, it only takes a light hand with only a few passes to manage a clean shave. The electric shaver video tutorials are awesome and give great examples of how to use. The description, also tells you what replacement foil accessories you need, which is very helpful as well.<br /><br />Most importantly, no more underarm rashes and no more shave bumps! It's rechargeable. It has a digital read-out that let's you know if the power is low, and thus, needs to be charged, which doesn't take too long either which is also convenient, so in theory, it is a unit that should last a long time with reasonable care.<br /><br />A general note if you have sensitive skin or allergies:<br />Even though this model is hypoallergenic, the friction against the skin of day-to-day shaving can still cause some degree of irritation, so again, as previously stated, it is best to adopt a 4-day-to every other day shave regimen (M W Fri Sa), instead of every day. I promise you, allowing your skin to rest a day or two between shaves will make a huge difference in the condition of your skin, especially on those more sensitive areas (face, underarms, swim zone)...<br /><br />(Also: on a side note: If it is an issue, Andis has a nickel-free Titanium foil unit out now (also hypoallergenic) that is getting great reviews (at a fraction of the cost): Andis 17010 Professional Profoil Rechargable Shaver (with Titanium Foils).<br /><br />But,I love it and so will anyone else! The only reason why I won't give it a perfect mark is because of the price (I keep thinking of the hand bags I didn't buy so I could get this shaver--but, it was well worth the investment) and I think they can make an even smaller, more powerful unit for this purpose.<br /><br />In general, a great product to invest in your personal grooming needs and even worth the price. And you will save money over time...<br /><br />Overall Grade: B+/A- or About 4.25 stars!I love it and so will anyone else! The only reason why I won't give it a perfect mark is because of the price (I keep thinking of the hand bags I didn't buy so I could get this shaver--but, it was well worth the investment) and I think they can make an even smaller, more powerful unit for this purpose.<br /><br />In general, a great product to invest in your personal grooming needs and even worth the price. And you will save money over time...<br /><br />Overall Grade: B+/A- or About 4.25 stars!

  2438. You have to try it yourself to see if your face enjoy more with a Philips (tri-cyclone cutters) or one from Panasonic (parallel movement cutters).<br /><br />I change an electrical shaver/razor when the battery gets weak, or typically about 2-3 years. About 8 years ago, my first electrical shaver was a Panasonic, which I think it was easy to use when I found out how handy a electrical shaver could be and amount of time I could save!<br /><br />After my first Panasonic, I changed to a Philips and I realize Philips tri-cyclone style does everything the same but much more comfortable! So every time when I am shopping for a new electrical shaver, I still will try both Panasonic and Philips units before making my decision; and just in my last two purchase, I do believe the tri-cyclone style shaver works better with me.<br /><br />Pro:<br />-Panasonic units feel more powerful than Philips units<br />-Good to have a battery meter<br /><br />Con:<br />-Causing irritation on my face (well, I only have 4 weeks for testing... too bad because general return policy)<br />-Loud, too loud in my opinion, that it actually heats up fast (not I push hard against my face)<br />-Take a bit longer to wash, and requires both hands to take apart before cleaning (most of Philips only requires one click opening up for rinse!!!!!!!!!)<br /><br />Seriously, I hate to spend time on shaving and cleaning the equipment but it is a part of my everyday routine. That one click for rinsing the unit on Philips saves me time too.<br /><br />Philips tri-cyclone design actually forms a 3D pocket when laying the shaving surface on my face, unlike the Panasonic's lateral (parallel) blade(s) movements that only make minimum contact(s) to the face, and I have to go back to the same area a few more times, or I have to pressure it hard against my face with a Panasonic unit but I ended up getting the irritations.<br /><br />I love Japanese products but I have to admit Philips shavers beat Japanese shavers byfar. Hey, I still give Panasonic the opportunity~<br /><br />One last thing: The local shopping clubs (ones that require membership to get in, they offers better deals) has better deals because their shavers frequently come with an extra replacement head! These shaving heads can be pricy!

The last Norelco I got (AT830) is very slow and doesn't shave close enough requiring multiple passes over the same areas taking 3 times longer than it should. I got a Braun 380s-4 last christmas that did better but still required multiple passes. It has now stopped working completely, it is dead. Both of these were made in china. Norelco and Braun products used to be better before they started manufacturing them in China. This Panasonic shaver is also made in china. Don't know why Panasonic, a Japanese company, wants to use Chinese manufactures instead their own plants, but time will tell if this shaver will continue to perform well.<br />This Panasonic gives the closest shave I have gotten from an electric, ever. It requires only 1, 2 or sometimes 3 passes and my shave is done. The only downside with this shaver is that it will nick or burn more easily than the others. Do not press hard. Light to moderate light pressure is all that is needed. I got this shaver because it is a wet/dry shaver as are the Norelco and Braun. I also use Shave Secret which is a blend of essential oils and recommend it to any one that shaves with water. It greatly reduces drag and allows the shaver to do its job easier.<br />I do recommend this shaver to anyone looking to shave with water, but remember to not get too aggressive with it.

  2481. I have owned 2 other electric shavers previous to this one: another Panasonic, and a Remington. The Remington was a higher end foil model and it did well (but to be fair, I used that one when my beard wasn't as rough/thick so I can't compare), and my old Panasonic was a cheap $20 one that shaved surprisingly well. Anyways, about a year and a half ago I switched to razors. I used Schick hydro 5-blades, and while it cut close against the grain, it severely irritated my skin and caused moderate acne and razor bumps (me being an acne prone 18-year old guy). Then about six months ago, I switched to double edged safety blades. I bought a Merkur handle, feather blades, proraso shave soap, and I even put oil on my face before the soap, basically I had all the equipment I needed to provide me a supposedly superior shave.<br />Well, let's just say I was tempted to go back to Schick quite a few times. I kept trying DE, but in the end I think I had more irritation and nicks than with Schick. Don't get me wrong, I know some guys respond very well with the double edged (and even straight razor) shaving, but my face is just too sensitive and dry, and my beard too thick, all of which is a bad combination for any razor shaving. So about late February, I remembered my old electric razors and thought maybe a good foil razor would be the answer to my problems. I spent a couple days researching different brands and models and going through all of the \\"verified purchase\\" reviews, and I finally decided on this Panasonic.<br /><br />Week one: I did it completely dry. I noticed that there was absolutely no drag or irritation, but it did make my skin very flaky and slightly bumpy (I attribute these to having sensitive skin and going through the adjustment stage).<br /><br />Week two: I started shaving after my showers and it seemed to not shave as close, not really sure why. But I was getting maybe 90% less flaky skin, and only a few bumps on my jawline and neck when I pressed to hard.<br /><br />Week three: I am now shaving in the shower (I should mention that every time I wet-shaved, I never used my proraso or anything else on my damp face). My shaves are now as close as they were when I dry shaved, and even more comfortable and smooth thanks to the steam. The shaver also doesn't break my skin if I go over any raised acne bumps, which was a huge problem with the manual razors. In fact, I am not getting nearly as much inflamed acne anymore caused by irritation, mostly just hormonal acne now. I've even shaved dry a couple times this week as a quick touch up, or due to time constraints, and no more flaky skin! After shaving, I rinse my face a couple times with warm water and then splash it with some cold water to close the pores and prevent ingrown hairs.<br /><br />I haven't started week 4 yet, but I expect my results to continue getting better. A few more things about the razor:<br />-After all of my shaves, my stubble still appears to be a little dark, even though it is smooth to the touch. I actually don't mind the dark look, it's only minimal anyways. And like I said, my face still feels smooth which is what's important.<br />-One full charge lasts me about 6-8 shaves, but I also take longer to shave than what the instructions recommend, which is just 3 minutes. I usually take about 10 minutes to shave in the shower.<br />-It. Is. So. Loud. Every time I dry shaved, I put cotton balls in my ears because my ears would ring a little after using it. I have no problem with the noise in the shower though.<br />-I have not had any problems with steam getting under the battery screen even though I've held it completely under water a few times.<br />-Cleaning is very easy. The head easily pinches off and it just needs a rinse. Use soap every once in awhile to keep it most fresh.<br />-I find it very annoying that I can't use the shaver while it's charging, I could with my other electric shavers which is what extended their lives past what they probably should have been.<br />-I have absolutely no problem shaving on my neck like other reviewers have experienced. I have a pretty protruding adam's apple, and not even that gets irritated when I glide over it.<br /><br />I ended up giving this shaver 4 stars instead of 5 for a few reasons:<br />-One, I can't shave while it's charging.<br />-Two, it requires multiple passes for me since it doesn't seem to lift my hairs. I have to stretch my skin around more than I expected I would, and a couple hairs don't get cut at all if they are laying down completely flat. Since I shave every morning, the longer shave time is a slight bother, but only when compared to my old Panasonic. When I was using a safety razor, it would take upwards of 30-40 minutes to shave because of the 3-4 passes + touchups I needed to get close, and the extra slowness I took to minimize irritation.<br />-Three, the pop-out trimmer is relatively weak compared to my old cheap Panasonic, so I still use that to trim my sideburns every once in awhile.<br /><br />Other than these few cons, I am really enjoying this shaver, and my sensitive face is even more thankful that I made the switch!<br />I plan to update this review in a few months or so after I've spent more time with it, but feel free to make any comments.<br /><br />EDIT: I have now had this razor for a little over 5 months and it is still great. It doesn't shave my upper lip/cheeks as close as I'd like, but it does shave my neck really close. I now only shave dry at night time unless I forget, then I shave in the morning during my shower so my skin doesn't get flaky. Overall, I would still recommend this razor highly, but look at other razors to see if you can find a closer cutting one.
  2482. The purchase price and free shipping made this shaver a good value. I like<br />the light weight device, it is easy to use and does the job.
  2483. After comparing many shavers I decided to go with this one. The price was fair and the replacement blades are not as expensive as many others out there. I am happy with the overall product and future upkeep cost providing it lasts me a few years.

  2513. Doesn't cut near as well as my Norelco did
  2514. I've used Panasonic wet/dry shavers for decades. I purchased this one because it was on sale (around $60) and it had decent reviews. As someone who's used many different models, I can honestly say that it isn't much better than some of the lower-end models I've used. Some details:<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Three blades, so in theory it does a better job. It doesn't do a worse job than other brands or models, but I can't say that it's much better.<br />- It charges VERY quickly. I usually charge when it hits 10 or 20%, and it'll charge in under an hour.<br />- If you forget to charge it, you can use it while it's charging. Some models require you to plug it into the wall to charge, so you can't use it.<br />- It has a digital display that goes in increments of 10, so you always know how much charge is left.<br />- Super-easy to clean, as with all wet/dry models. Just open the top, add some soap, run under water, rinse.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- It's quite loud. It has a very high-pitch noise that my other models never had.<br />- It doesn't shave any closer than my two-blade entry model from Panasonic. In fact, I still have it just in case. I have to shave over the same spot a few times to get a close shave. I've had other similar mid-level models that shaved with one pass, so either they're using cheaper blades or it's something about this particular model, but it's definitely not the closest shave I've had.<br /><br />Overall:<br />If you want to save money, you can spend less and get a very similar shave. There are entry 3-blade models that are under $50 and two-blade models that are ~$30. There are similarly priced 3-blade models that I think give a closer shave, so I think the retail price on this is very inflated, and I would be hard-pressed to pay more than $50 for this.<br /><br />A side note about Panasonic wet/dry razors. For some reason, the battery seems to die just before the 1-year warranty. I've owned many of them and the same thing happens: the battery won't hold a charge after 11 or so months. You call the number and they say it's covered, you send it in (you pay shipping), they send it back (they pay for return shipping) with a refurb unit. They claim they &#34;fixed&#34; it, but it's clear they just gave you a refurb as my units were definitely not mine (they had distinguishing marks). The refurbs will last another 3-4 months, and then the battery dies again, but at that point they won't replace it.<br /><br />I like Panasonic razors, and I will continue to use them. I think this was a slight disappointment for me.

  2575. The Panasonic ES8103S is a great electric razor. I avoided electrics for years because they would cause me to break out. Initially you will probably have some irritation but as the packaged instructions say, \\"your skin will need time to adjust.\\" This is absolutely true. For the first two weeks I shaved wet with shaving gel. After a month it works wonders and any irritation is gone in an hour. The water proof feature is excellent. I run mine under the tap after each shave and let it air dry. You will get about ten shaves out of this razor before it needs a one hour charge. My best advice? If you have sensistive skin give this razor a try for at least a month and then reap the benefits. One last tip, even if your facial hair grows slow you should still use it once a day. With all electrics, if you let your stubble get too long it takes longer to shave and you will get more irritation.
  2576. Excellent shaver - Best one ever used. Closer shave than razor, very impressed with performance. Buying anything more fancy would be a total waste of money. I can't believe some people write negative reviews on this product, they probably have beards made of copper wire. :)
  2577. I bought this for my husband. He love the 3-blades and says it's very easy to use and the results are great... smooth face.
  2578. THIS IS A WONDERFUL PRODUCT - MY ONLY SURPRISE IS THE LOUDER THAN NORMAL OPERATING VOLUME. MAYBE THE 13,000 rpm HAS SOMETHING TO DO WITH IT. BUT IT'S THE SMOOTHEST NON-IRRITATINNG SHAVE I'D HAVE.<br />BUT THE ICING ON THIS ORDER IS THE GREAT SERVICE FROM AMAZON - ADJUSTMENTS PERMITTED AND SPEEDY DELIVERY! THANKS
  2579.   2580. I have had this shaver for a couple of weeks and it works great for a quick morning shave. Not quite as close of a shave as a manual shaver, but now I don't have to worry about cutting up my face. I would recommend this shaver to everyone.
  2581. I had a Braun razor for about 15 years. The battery no longer held a charge and it was hard to find replacement blades for it. I decided that I needed a new razor.<br /><br />After some investigation, I purchased the Panasonic ES8103S as it was relatively inexpensive and had all the features I needed (battery percent gauge, wet/dry).<br /><br />I am extremely happy with this razor. It cuts very close and doesn't give me razor bumps. It's ergonomically built and very light weight. It's very easy to clean - no need to get the razors with the cleaning stations where they get you for the cleaning solution. That's a total gimmick.<br /><br />Overall, I really like this unit and would definitely recommend a Panasonic razor.
  2582. Shaves well over the face but not good over the neck area and bellow the chin. The batery life is great and it charges very quickly and does not make much noise either. But I use a raser to shave my neck bellow the chin area. Cleaning is very easy. Overal, good product and I recommend it
  2583. Gives a close, fast shave. It does have a problem with the jaw line and neck -- seems to be typical of electric razors; so I use a safety razor for those areas. The advantage of using this method is saving money on blades --- and reducing the likelihood of nicks.

  2612. Update at the 4.5-year mark (April 2017): This same razor is still going strong! I clean it whenever the cleaning light comes on, and I change the blades and foil once a year. It's an amazing product! If/when it fails, I will try to buy it or another Panasonic shaver. Original review from Nov. 20, 2012: I have used electric razors for over 30 years. Early days were with Remington. Last 15 years with Braun. The Braun brand seems to have gone very high-priced and with features I did not want. I read the reviews on this Panasonic and decided to give it a try, since it had a 30-day trial period. I am very pleased with its shaving results. I get a close shave quickly. The only unusual aspect is shaving the moustache area. The shaver seems to struggle a bit and requires multiple passes, but in the end it does a fine job on the moustache area. I really like the longer lifetime of the cutter and foil vs. the Braun. The cleaning is unlike any other I've had. It uses liquid soap and water and cleans itself with a special turbo mode. I am a big fan after using it for only 3 weeks.
  2613. It has been well over a decade since I had a Panasonic razor that I can use in the shower. I have been using a Braun for years, and yes I have put new rotary blades in it, but nothing shaves me as close as this Panasonic Electric Shaver. It is a joy to shave in the shower, when your beard is wet, it works like a charm. It is now ten hours since I shaved with this razor, and my face and neck are still smooth. With my other electric razor, my skin was not this smooth right after the shave, let along ten hours later. Do not hesitate to purchase the Panasonic Electric Razor.

  2663. Electric shaves are never going to be able to replace a razor shave and I don't expect them too. Using it 3-4 times a week (and regular shaving on other days) the charge easily lasts 2 weeks (maybe more as I haven't really paid that much attention which means it's not annoying). It charges quickly and for those stubborn whiskers that don't want to get zapped (the ones beside the throat) you can flip it over and use the side burn trimmer which cuts just as close. All in all it's a very good part time razor for the price.

  2674. Below is the original review where I gave the product five stars. The comments below still apply. However, the quality of the product disappoints me. The LCD screen shows how much charge is left [i.e., 90%, 80, 70, etc.] After use, once it goes down to 10%, recharge. Just after one year [when the warranty expired, naturally] the LCD screen started giving me problems. Now, the only way I know it needs a charge is when it goes dead. So, concept 100%, quality 10%. Hence, now a three star review. Would not buy again.<br /><br />Original review:<br />I had been using a Gillette Fusion for quite a few years.   2676. The shave from the Panasonic isn't as good as a new disposable blade, but it's pretty close and is a lot better then an old used blade! My skin is pretty sensitive and I'd get ingrown hairs or raw skin if I didn't replace my (expensive) disposable blades frequently and the inexpensive ones tore up my face. The Panasonic on the other hand gives a pretty good shave when dry and if I let my beard grow for a couple of days I just do a wet shave with shaving cream and don't have any skin irritation. If you're in the market for an electric razor I highly recommend this model.

  2701. I have owned Panasonic electric shavers for almost 20 years. I have tried other brands like Norelco and Remington, but they just didn't work as well for me. My current Panasonic shaver still works well, but the battery is not holding a charge , so I did some research and put this model on my Amazon wish list and got it for Christmas. I really like the digital readout showing the battery life, and as I stated it gives a really close shave. The pop up trimmer is not quite as good as the one I have now, meaning that it is not as effective at trimming my side burns and mustache. Overall, I am satisfied with the ES8103S.

  2717. Bought it to replace an older Panasonic shave with a dying battery. I get a much closer shave thanks to the higher blade speed. The only negative is the blade spacing seems to be just such that a lot of dead hair gets trapped between them requiring a more through cleaning than the old one.
  2718. I had been a dedicated user of double-edge razors. But after years of on/off DE shaving, my skin could no longer take the abrasion of a metal blade. I tired many different razors, blades, shave soaps, and post-shave products, but the results were the same. Rough and abrasive shaves that were the cause of razor bumps, ingrown hairs, and raw skin, and these effects increased throughout the day, making my skin extremely sensitive. Enough! I had used this razor years ago and decided to return to it. This Panasonic is an excellent alternative to using a double-edge blade. Shaves are close and smooth. If I use the razor with a freshly whipped lather, the shave is very close; when I use it dry, with the assist of a pre-shave powder (Remington SP-5 Pre-Shave Talc [[ASIN:B002SJ4ADO Remington SP-5 SP5 Face Saver Pre-shaver Powder Stick (6 pack)]] I still get a fine shave, just not as close as a wet shave with this razor, but far better than acceptable. Best of all, my skin feels fine during and after shaving. I get five to six shaves per charge; and the razor performs much like a mild DE razor like Gillette's vintage Tech razor; and it shaves closer than Feather's AS-D1 razor. This is good razor that delivers day-after-day of DFS to good quality shaves. I found that canned lather Gillette Foamy works about as efficiently as whipped lather that one applies with a brush. In fact, the emollients in some canned lathers deliver more moisture than whipped lather. The only suggestion I would make is be sure to clean the razor thoroughly after each use and it will perform even better than razors selling for three times the cost. I compared this razor with a Norelco 1280X [[ASIN:B006W2SYGM Philips Norelco 1280X/47 SensoTouch 3D Electric Razor with Jet Clean System, Frustration Free Packaging]], about $240, and the Panasonic outperformed the Norelco for both comfort and overall shave. No electric shaves as close as some of the modern and vintage DE razors; but this electric does a great job and it will not damage your skin.
  2719. My wife bought this razor to replace her old Remington R845. The Panasonic razor does a pretty good job, the shave is almost as good as a manual razor (on legs anyway), but its pretty loud. It charges quick and is easy to hold while using it.

  2752. I've done traditional wet shaving for the last few years and was getting slightly tired of all the time it takes to shave properly. My neck hairs grow at a very close angle to my skin, so I always have some sort of irritation regardless of the shaving method. I decided to give the ES8103S a try and after about six weeks I've been pretty happy with it. The shave isn't as close as what you get with wet shaving (as is expected), but I do notice the irritation on my neck has gone down considerably (though I don't think it will ever go away totally). I'll still have instances where irritation will flair up and I have to wait an extra day to shave again, but other than that the razor has been great. If you have irritation issues with your neck when you shave, consider giving this razor a try.

The only con's are some initial razor burn that goes away after a couple of weeks and (like other reviews) the battery does not last for more than a week for me. But those are minor issues considering the amazing shave and smooth skin that results. I'm committed to this model for the foreseeable future.

  2780. I purchased this as a replacement for a Braun series 5 razor, as the plug stopped working. Unfortunately, it was a discontinuted plug style, so I wasn't able to find a replacement at a reasonable price. I have used a Braun electric razors for the past 12 years, and have been quite pleased with how they worked. Unfortunately, I wasn't expecting to need a new razor ASAP, and didn't have a large amount of money to spend on the replacement.<br /><br />I looked at the Sensotouch, but as I used the three circular blade arrangement on a Norelco shaver before I moved to Braun, I had found that the razor's blade arrangement worked far better for me. Also, I found a fantastic review someone wrote about the different electrics under Sensotouch & the Arc 4 review section...which is worth a view if you want to go deeper. Knowing this, and knowing my price points, I started my own research.<br /><br />Firstly, I found out that Braun had made some changes and their quality had decreased over the last few years. This, combined with their top tier pricing, simply made them too expensive of a risk for me to take. I looked at the new Arc 4 options for Panasonic, and while they have good reviews, I found out that the replacement blades were very expensive, and didn't make a large enough difference in the shave to warrant the price. Therefore, I settled on this version for a very reasonable price and I've been happy so far (been using it about a month).<br /><br />Pros:<br />Efficient - It does the job quickly. You can tell that the 13,000 RPM motor makes a difference.<br />Quick Charge - I haven't watched it extremely closely, but it seems to charge in a couple of hours.<br />Build Quality - For the price (I got it with a $15 discount coupon through Amazon), it is a very high quality razor.<br />Wet/Dry - I like the fact that I can clean it with water, as opposed to the expensive Braun alcohol cleaning system. I haven't used it for actual wet shaving with foam (which may helpwith stragglers, see in Cons), but it's still neat relative by my Braun.<br />Trimmer - While the placement is odd, it works better than any other trimmer I've ever had on an electric razor (including my $200+ previous razor). It works VERY well.<br /><br />Cons:<br />Loud - Yes, it's loud, but less loud than my Braun. For me, it's no big deal, but if guys are REALLY that sensitive, this makes some noise.<br />Charge Doesn't Hold - It's odd, but it seems like the charge dissipates on it's own quite quickly. Say, maybe about 20% every 3-4 days. That may not be a big deal for me as I keep it plugged in, and am anal about bringing a charger, but it is strange as my Braun held charges forever.<br />Not Heavy Duty - This is a minor irritation for me, but I find that this misses about 5-6 neck hairs each time. I have to look in the mirror, use the trimmer to shorten them, and then clean it up. It isn't the end of the world, but it is surprising. I can't seem to understand why it can be so great on all the other hairs, but not be able to get those last hairs.<br /><br />Overall I like the shaver, and am pleased with how it has worked for me so far. If you have very thick strong beard hair like I do, be prepared to check in the mirror for stragglers after a good shave...at least if you shave dry like I do.
  2781. Why I chose this rating:<br />The title of my review says it all. After 1 month and 5 days of use it stopped recharging. I never had this product in the shower so it cannot be due to water. Also, when shaving with this electric shaver it constantly pulls hairs.<br /><br />***Shaving with this thing is the most painful activity I have ever attempted in my life. ***<br /><br />I do like the sideburn trimmer, it was a neat feature.<br /><br />To who would I recommend this<br />Wouldn't recommend this to anyone, unless you're looking for that 'special' gift to your father in law. Before this shaver I had a $20 Remington that worked for years (it still works, but the blades are so dull it pulls my hairs like this shaver does brand new), which is what compelled me to purchase a more expensive one.<br /><br />My suggestion would be to find another electric shaver on amazon.com

  2794. Havent bought a shaver in years. Saw this on sale so I jumped on it. The 2K+ reviews on it with 4.5 stars cant be ignored. Ive used it once so far and it went great. Not pulling of hairs and it glided like butter. Plan on buying the square trade warranty. Its only $7.99 for 2 years, or $10.99 for 3 years. I think its worth it IMO. Look them up. Theres no deductible or anything.
  2795. This is the best shaver I have ever owned. I have only had it about a month so I don't know its reliability yet, but it works fantastic.
  2796. I have sensitive skin and a beard that grows in many different directions. The foil makes a blunt perpendicular above surface cut on the whisker where rotary and blades lift and cut at angles. If you have a tendency for in-growns this doesn't help. It will take a week or 2 for your face to adjust and the lotion will help. Electric razors in general require daily use over a blade which might let you skip a day depending on your beard.<br /><br />I prefer a dry shave and I follow it with lotion that has touch of hyrocortisone in it. It can be bought over the counter you just have to look for it. I use Lotrimin HCL -your pharmacist can order it for you or it is easily found on line. My shave is closer than a blade.<br /><br />If you suffer like me the Arc 3 will help you - The bigger head really reduced shave time to my last Panasonic and it goes a week with out a charge plus being wet dry gives you easy cleaning or the ability of a wet shave.<br /><br />Don't buy into all the gimmicks - Buy this razor first -it can be bought for under $80 w/ free shipping on Amazon. If you want more, Panasonic offers a 30 day guarantee and you can try one of their more expensive self cleaning units. However, if you have sensitive skin I would stray away from the 4 foil.
  2797. This is much better than using a razor. I always would cut myself the first few times using a razor no matter how careful I was, Now I can shave anywhere I want and it is safe and comfortable. It is also easy to clean. It is a little hard to shave around my chin.
  2798. It met my every expectation and surpassed it. So says my husband that I bought it for. A very nice smooth shave and works great.

  2809. I am very pleased with the Panasonic razor. I usually get a new razor every year (in the past I had terrible issues with losing cords or charge stands). It was always a simple xmas or bday gift to ask for. I also switch back and forth from straight razors to electrics, depending on time and how close I want to shave. Not again. I love this razor. I had been turned off by non-rotary razors due to bad experiences in the past. So glad I took a chance on this one! No pulling of hair. No pain. I shave daily and ask alot of my razor. It may be hard to believe but I actually received a closer shave with this than my normal straight blade, and I wasn't even using the wet-shave option. An now, many months later, it works as well as the day I first used it. My fiancee works in an assisted living environment, and I recommended this razor for shaving the residents who complain alot about the ones they use now. I have also recommended this to my friends and family. My only complaint is it can't be used while charging, Though with the very quick charge time, it's not much to complain about. Don't be turned away by the price. It's worth every penny. Great product!!

  2823. I like my Norelco better, but then again, that cost $80. I bought this at $55, I think it is way overpriced. You would think this brand new shaver would beat out a 5 year old one.<br /><br />The issues....<br /><br />1. It takes more than multiple passes to shave. This is usually an issue with most electric shavers, but this one take A LOT of passes. If you just have some stuble, this shaver sucks. You need grow it out a little before it becomes effective. If you are a clean cut guy who does not like the been up for 5 days straight rock star look, then avoid this since you will have to grow it like that for this shaver to shave.<br /><br />2. It does not shave that close at all. Of course, this means no irritated skin, which is a good thing. But that means it does not shave close at all.<br /><br />3. The battery seems to go pretty fast. One session of shaving is about 20%-30% of battery.<br /><br />4. You cannot plug it in and use it at the same time.....Usually it's you can plug it in and use it at the same time (but it will not charge will you use it). With this unit, it can only charge when plugged in.<br /><br />5. It is pretty dam loud.
  2824. I have been using this for over 2 years and it still shaves as well as day one. I would say that the quality of the shave is appropriate to the price level (which is in the middle). A charge lasts several weeks and cleaning the blades is simple since this is a wet/dry shaver. I own cheaper and more expensive electric shavers but this own has outlasted them all. Sure, there are all sorts of self cleaning shavers out there with plenty of fancy schmancy options but it's just hard for me to justify the significant difference in price. I am very happy with this shaver and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good electric shaver at a fair price.

  2837. I purchased this for my son last year, and also bought a Norelco PT730 for myself. This shaver delivers a nice clean shave, very efficiently, without any pulling or skin burn. I have a light beard and so I only shave twice a week so the stubble is quite long when I shave. This shaver had no problem with the longer stubble. Now, it has some downsides, first of all it's LOUD AS HELL compared to the Norelco. Nobody in the house will sleep through your morning shave with this baby. Also, it goes through the battery in a couple shaves. Lastly, it fell of the bathroom countertop once, the trimmer popped open and a little piece of plastic flew out. That was the end of the trimmer. We sent it back and had a replacement in a couple weeks. No problem.<br />By comparison, the Norelco was whisper quiet, the battery live was 10 times longer despite the fact that with the longer stubble it took the Norelco twice as long to deliver the same shave as the Panasonic. The Norelco had to make numerous passes over the same long stubble to clean it all up, but eventually it got there, and it's so quiet that nobody sleeping would care how long you kept at it. Both good shavers, depends what your requirements are.<br />You need to have a way to charge the Panasonic every couple shaves, whereas the Norelco could get you through a week's worth of shaving on one charge easily.
  2838. This is not the best electric shaver I have ever used but it gets the job done. One complaint I have is that it only works in cordless mode. When it's plugged in (recharge mode) it doesn't work so keep an eye on the battery life light.

  2862. I have thick, dark hair, and shave my whole head daily. I use wet shaving techniques: badger brush from Parker Safety, Proraso Green soap, plus Shave Secret as a pre-shave. As far as a razor, I use my S4 Eclipse headblade, and a Double Edge for my face. I never get razor burn or bumps from this method.<br /><br />For some reason, I began to break out on my face and the sides of my head (non-razor bumps, mainly acne). Most likely it is related to allergies, but I needed a shaving solution in the mean time. I research electric razors, and found that most guys had success with the Panasonic Linear series, mainly due to the high speed of the blades. So I purchased one at a discounted price from a department store.<br /><br />The verdict: The shave is extremely close. It is almost... and I mean so very almost as close as shaving with a razor blade against the grain. In fact, unless you stretch out your skin to feel stubble, you can't tell. The best part is the fact that it does not irritate my skin at all. My bumps have completely cleared up in the three days I have used it. It works well with a pre-shave oil, Proraso, and my badger brush, though I would recommend making the lather a tad bit more watery than usual to allow the razor to glide.<br /><br />It works good dry as well- I went over my face bumps without lather or water and they did not flare up. However, this shaver is way better when used wet.<br /><br />I would urge you to purchase one. It's perfect for head shaving (my scalp hair is thicker than anyone's beard I promise), as well as face shaving. This model is a great price point, and it works fine, though I wouldn't go for one that has a speed of less than 13,000 (which is what this model has). I will be a panasonic user for life and plan on buying a more expensive model when the time comes for replacement. I am beyond happy. It is just as amazing as my headblade.<br /><br />Update 9-18-2012:<br /><br />Still working fine. I would recommend changing your shaving routine if you are still having problems, or have problems with sensitive skin. I bought Thayers Lavender Witch Hazel to use as an after shave, and it is possibly the best after shave you can buy. My allergy bumps have almost 99.99% cleared up, and the few remaining are constantly shrinking.<br /><br />I most likely will be using an electric razor on my head for the rest of my life.<br /><br />I have also used Lab Series Electric Shave enhancer. If you enjoy a dry shave, it helps a lot. However, I do not believe that it is better than a pre-shave oil and a shaving cream such as Proraso.
  2863. Incredibly close shave. No pulling of hairs like with the rotary shavers
  2864. I have used many different types and brands of electric razor, and this is the best one I have had. Gives a close enough shave, and does not irritate my skin.

  2867. Although I like the way this razor handles and recharges quickly, bottom line is it does not give as close a shave as my old Norelco. Probably spend at least an extra 2 minutes each day working at it. Also cleaning instructions are confusing.
  2868. Let me start by saying that I have extremely sensitive skin so I have all but given up on razor shaving, it always makes my skin scaly, blotchy and red (a real eyesore and sometimes painful). So I gave the Braun Series 7 shaver a try about 5 years ago and it gave me razor burn on my neck (gave it 30 days). I have a fairly light beard but the hairs on my neck/under chin are pretty dense. I have been using just an electric beard trimmer to \\"shave\\" for the last couple years and obviously it does not get close nor is it intended to. I had an interview coming up so I decided to try electric again and with the reviews on this device I thought \\"why not?\\". After about 2 weeks of use and using only about 3x/week here are my observations:<br /><br />PROS<br />-I don't mind the higher pitch hum at all, definitely not noisy enough to complain and I have very sensitive ears. Lot of reviews on \\"hear\\" indicate that is a problem, it is not IMHO.<br />-Shaves closer than any other electric I've owned hands down and I've owned several Brauns, several Norelco's. ***But see cons.<br />-Does not give me razor burn or irritation on any part of my face (I use Remington FaceSaver).<br />-Charges very quick (about 1 hour) or a quick 5 min charge is possible.<br />-Nice LED display displays % of charge remaining making it easy power management.<br />-Best cleanup of any shaver out there (Panasonic in general), very cost effective (soap/water) and very quick.<br />-Wet/Dry is a plus for clean up by I'm skeptical of using shaving cream to shave with electric. Nonetheless, wet/dry gives it more versatility than other razors.<br /><br />CONS<br />-takes quite a bit of time to shave, to me the advantage of electric is the ability to shave in under 10 mins. This typically takes about 10-12 mins for me to shave.<br />-takes a lot of passings to get a close shave (see above).<br />-Long(er) hairs are not easy to cut. If you go without shaving for 2-4 days it has a harder time with that length of hair. The side trimmer is helpful with longer hairs but does not completely solve the problem.<br />-Side trimmer is not engineered properly so you can see where you are cutting, creates a \\"blind spot\\" and is a guessing game where you are shaving.<br />-Does a very good job of shaving under chin but struggles mightily at shaving north/south below side burns. I end up using a straight razor to get the 2 inches below my sideburns straight and clean every time since this is very poor at shaving in this area in particular. This creates more time/cleanup time shaving which is what we are all trying to mitigate.<br />-Because shaves take so long this does not hold enough charge for two weeks of shaves, which it advertises. More like 1 week's worth of shaves (3x/week) which is pretty sub-standard.<br />-Need to allow corded shaving, this is a must for any good shaver in my opinion.<br /><br />All in all, I think is a slightly above shaver but I am captivated enough to try their Arc IV which adds an additional blade with the hopes it will take less passings to shave. I will be returning this within 30 days and looking for a Black Friday deal for a Arc IV since the 4th blade adds quite a bit in price (questionable value for 4 blades).<br /><br />If anyone has any tips or best practices for the shaver please let me know (particularly shaving below side burns and creating a straight side-burn end). As Bill Murray/Harold Ramis once said, I want to be a fan of this shaver \\"but I am willing to learn\\".<br /><br />Hope this helps...th of hair. The side trimmer is helpful with longer hairs but does not completely solve the problem.<br />-Side trimmer is not engineered properly so you can see where you are cutting, creates a \\"blind spot\\" and is a guessing game where you are shaving.<br />-Does a very good job of shaving under chin but struggles mightily at shaving north/south below side burns. I end up using a straight razor to get the 2 inches below my sideburns straight and clean every time since this is very poor at shaving in this area in particular. This creates more time/cleanup time shaving which is what we are all trying to mitigate.<br />-Because shaves take so long this does not hold enough charge for two weeks of shaves, which it advertises. More like 1 week's worth of shaves (3x/week) which is pretty sub-standard.<br />-Need to allow corded shaving, this is a must for any good shaver in my opinion.<br /><br />All in all, I think is a slightly above shaver but I am captivated enough to try their Arc IV which adds an additional blade with the hopes it will take less passings to shave. I will be returning this within 30 days and looking for a Black Friday deal for a Arc IV since the 4th blade adds quite a bit in price (questionable value for 4 blades).<br /><br />If anyone has any tips or best practices for the shaver please let me know (particularly shaving below side burns and creating a straight side-burn end). As Bill Murray/Harold Ramis once said, I want to be a fan of this shaver \\"but I am willing to learn\\".<br /><br />Hope this helps...
  2869. It's ugly, I do not like this new faux chrome look mens grooming tools are taking. It fits the hand well enough yet I found my fingers wanting to slide up to the pivoting head. It works well in the shower or with a gel, and the shave is smoother than my rotary triple head - so far.

  2917. I've used base model Panasonic wet/dry shavers for 15 years and been satisfied. I've tolerated reduced cutting performance of those old style units as the replaceable parts aged because replacement is nearly the cost of new shaver. By contrast, the first shave with this model was amazingly close and the high-speed motor is pleasantly smooth, though the high-pitched sound is reminiscent of a buzzing wasp. After about a month the cutting performance has declined a little, presumably as the fresh edges lose their perfect sharpness. My whiskers are not tough, but they tend to lie along the skin so I've always had trouble getting an electric to pick them up cleanly. The ES8103 does well at this but isn't perfect, hence the loss of one star. Charging is very fast. Hope the Li-ion battery lasts 7 to 10 years like the old shavers, but probably NimH batteries are more durable.
  2918. I originally got the one with only 2 foils, but found it didn't cut several-day-old stubble. That didn't seem like a problem at first except if I missed a few hairs one day I'd have major problems the next day. I wound up first using my Norelco to cut the longer hairs and then finishing with the Panasonic for a close shave.<br /><br />This 3-blade Panasonic solves the problem with 2 close cut foils with a third long-hair foil sandwiched between. This is by far the closest cutting electric I've ever used. Unlike some lower-cost models, the battery fully recharges in an hour and will last me 2 weeks.
  2919. I really love it! As instructed, you can wash it directly with tap water. This is very convenient for me.

  2921. I have owned this razor for over a month now and am very pleased with it.<br /><br />PROs:<br />- Clean smooth shave<br />- Very easy to clean - just use liquid soap and water<br />- Very low maintenance - just clean. No special solution like my previous Braun. No other maintenance.<br />- Lasts for about a week of shaving on one charge.<br />- Very quick to charge - less than an hour.<br />- Very good ergonomics - fits the hand well and easy to hold<br />- Fairly quiet, low vibration.<br /><br />CONs:<br />- Very minor issue.   2922. My Norelco of many years was getting pretty dull and I didn't want to spend the money on new shaving heads and I was never really happy with it. I had to keep going over the same area half a dozen times before it felt close enough. I invested in the Panasonic and am very happy with it. It does the job faster and with no irritation. I wash mine under hot water using the regular motor speed then into turbo speed to finish up. Then I use canned air to dry it off and it removes any stray hairs that the water didn't get. put it back together and I'm ready to start shaving the next time. It is noisier that my Norelco, but also it has a speed of 13000 rpm's, while the Norelco has only half the speed. Some people don't like the extra noise, but it doesn't bother me.The battery last only about half of the Norelco,but I think it is because of the higher motor speed. I like this shaver very much, and will buy new heads when it needs it.
  2923. My husband really likes this product. It is a little more expensive than other, but is well worth the price.
  2924. ...so I was looking for a way to cut some time out of my morning routine.   2925. works better than any electric i have owned-- cleans itself - holds charge-- close as a blade if used twice a day-- would recommend !
  2926. I have had Brauns for the past 20 years, I went through (3) of them in just the last twelve years. That's not too bad of usage, except when you pay a small fortune for them, they should last longer and that isn't just changing the screen or the cutters.<br /><br />I decided to try this Panasonic after reading several reviews and ordered from Amazon. I received the shaver really fast and took less than an hour to charge it as it was already at 50% charge. Having had Brauns I thought I was getting close shaves but this shaver really takes the prize! The shave is so close that a blade couldn't get any closer. I also tried several different pre-shaves including shampoo, Xtra Virgin Olive Oil, etc. but the best I found for myself is the Nivea Shaving Gel.<br /><br />There is no way a Braun can compete with this shaver, also the cleaning is incredibly simple and the shaver is always clean for the next shave. One thing I noticed was I can only get 4-shaves per charge and I sure can't shave in 4-5 minutes as some claim, but then everyone is different. On the 4th shave I'm down to 10% charge but it lasts through the shave and then a quick 1 hour charge and its ready again, no problem. For myself, I think the body is a bit long but then again that's just a personal opinion but doesn't take away from the shavers performance at all. I was surprised that you cannot shave with this plugged in, can only use when unplugged, that's not a big deal for me though. I would rate this at 4.5 overall
  2927. I have been using this for a number of months and am so happy with it. It's great to take away on holiday, easy to clean, looks great and is very functional so it's so much better than its predecessor which was so expensive and heavier by comparison (a Braun).

  2929. I had a Braun shaver forever and thought nothing could ever top it. I have found its replacement.   2930. I have a coarse beard so ingrown hair is a huge issue with me.   2931. This is my second Panasonic Shaver. The first one lasted 5 years at which time the battery would not keep a charge. I got my money's worth on that shaver. I hope this one lasts as long. Even if it would last two or three years I will be pleased. Compare it to the cost of conventional blades now days and it is more cost efficient for the electric shaver. I will say this to potential buyers when you get it follow the instructions as listed. If you are just starting new to use an electric shaver it will take 3 to 4 weeks for your beard to get use to an electric shaver. I would recommend using a pre-shave such as &#34;Williams Lectric Shave&#34; or something comparable.
  2932. easy to use and clean. performs well. i can get a weeks shaves from one charge. i won't have to take the charger along for short trips.

  2934. For the price, a very good shaver. There are definitely better shavers out there, but you will be shelling out a BUNDLE to purchase them. This shaver is perfect for the man who razor shaves occasionally, and wants to stay smooth in-between. It's pivot (soft) action is great for uneven terrain. A full charge holds for 5-6 FULL shaves.
